story:
What is 'Any Night'?

EVN Productions & The Filigree Theatre will present the Los Angeles Premiere of Any Night, by Daniel Arnold & Medina Hahn, directed by Elizabeth V. Newman,  starring Zac Thomas & Marie Rose Fahlgren,  at The Sacred Fools Theatre, Hollywood.  July 2017.  

Website: AnyNightAustin.com

Our journey with Any Night by Daniel Arnold & Medina Hahn, began over two years ago as a part of Austin's seminal FronteraFest Fringe Festival.  When the festival lost the performance space at the last minute - exactly 27 hours before our opening night - our Any Night Team - in one day -  pulled together to mount our production in an historic barn (after all, Austin is in Texas, y'all...).  We performed at the Barn to sold out audiences.  Thanks to the support and enthusiasm of our FronteraFest audience at the Barn, we were able to mount the official Austin Premiere in September 2016 at the City Theatre.  

We were thrilled to have our playwrights, Daniel & Medina, come down to Austin (from Canada!) to attend the performance and hold a special playwright talk-back event.

The positive response to Any Night during our Austin premiere was breathtaking from the engagement of the audience and the discussion sparked during the  post-show talkbacks - we knew we had to share Any Night with a broader audience.

ANY NIGHT Today...

The world has changed dramatically in the two years since we first began our work on Any Night.  The themes presented & questions posed by the play - Trust, Truth, Privacy, Psychological Manipulation & Violence against Women - have all taken on a chillingly deeper, more urgent resonance.  Never have we needed the Arts more than now as a way to shed light on some of these darker aspects of our current society and culture. 

How You Can Help...and How We Can Say Thanks...

  • Please keep in mind that…

    $25 will pay for the cost of copying scripts

    $50 will help pay for costumes

    $100 will help pay for the magical set that makes this show so exciting

    $500 will pay for postcards and posters announcing the production

    $1,000 will pay for the lighting and sound equipment

    $2,500 will be help rent the theatre space &  will be noted in the program as a Production Sponsor

    $5,000 will help pay the artists for their incredible work & will be noted in the program as an Underwriter Sponsor

Even though the show itself will go up in Los Angeles, we have perks for wherever you are - from autographed posters and production stills, to limited-edition swag to Inaugural Season Tickets for The Filigree Theatre in Austin.  For those joining us in LA,  we have everything available from a pre-show  'Dress Circle' VIP champagne cocktail party to a late-night LA Opening after-party for the night owls!  

  • Keep your eyes wide open for our 'Spotlight Series'!  Each week, we will shine the 'spotlight' on a different aspect of the production & members of our Any Night team!  Don't snooze and lose out on the unique Surprise Spotlight Perks coming each week and available only till midnight on Saturday!

Meet the Any Night Team...

Daniel Arnold & Medina Hahn - playwrights

Elizabeth V. Newman - director/producer

Stephanie Moore - producer

Zac Thomas & Marie Rose Fahlgren - starring cast

Ben McLemore - cast (voice)

Eliot Fisher - sound designer

Erica Gionfriddo - choreographer 

Chris Conard - lighting designer & technical director

Vanessa Montano - set designer/props designer

With Very Special Thanks to our Extended Any Night Family:  

Stef Sayer, Christina Barbosa, Hannah Enright, Taylor Tolleson

For more details about our Any Night team, the show’s production history and press & reviews from our Austin production please visit the show’s website: AnyNightAustin.com

EVN Productions is an independent production company with the goal of creating innovative projects through championing new voices and emerging talent in film and theatre. Our creative emphasis lies in telling in stories that embrace strong female characters who stand at a crossroads or at the brink of transition. To date, EVN Productions has produced critically-acclaimed works in New York, Los Angeles and the company's new home, Austin, Texas. 

For more about EVN Productions - reviews and details about past productions in Los Angeles, New York and Austin, please visit: evnproductionsATX.com

The Filigree Theatre embraces the dual roots of the word 'filigree' (seed & thread)  in our company's mission: with an aim to serve both as a 'seed'  by incubating, supporting and celebrating emerging theatre artists in Austin and as a 'thread'  by connecting Austin to theatre communities in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles & London. 

For more about The Filigree Theatre, please visit: filigreetheatre.com

Risks & Challenges

  • Transferring a production (set pieces, costumes, a team of actors, designers and crew) requires much logistical coordination - even just to get travel the 1,400 miles to Los Angeles from Austin!

Other Ways You Can Help...

Even if you feel you cannot support us monetarily, there are countless ways of helping out! 

  • Attend a performance in Los Angeles
  • Please spread the word on Facebook, Instagram or Twitter - or even good old fashioned  'word-of-mouth' 
  • Remember, you can use the Indiegogo share tools to make some noise about the Any Night Los Angeles Premiere

Any gift that you can make, be it contributing money or time or spreading the word about the show, will both be greatly appreciated and help us as we mount this production in July 2017!

Please spread the word on Facebook, Instagram or Twitter - or even good old fashioned  'word-of-mouth' 
Remember, you can use the Indiegogo share tools to make some noise about the Any Night Los Angeles Premiere

Any gift that you can make, be it contributing money or time or spreading the word about the show, will both be greatly appreciated and help us as we mount this production in July 2017!

story:
Art for Progress Founder Frank Jackson, Director Alexis Confer and Executive Producer Bill Hyers are proud to announce their upcoming production of Cymbeline at Theatre 80 St. Marks this spring. This production will use the classic language of Shakespeare, but approach the Bard’s “fairytale” with a modern lens. The audience will be transported to a world floating between the blurred morality and frenetic energy of a Vegas-like kingdom and the stark, colorful beauty of the American Southwest. The company is made up of a variety of performance backgrounds from musicians to stand up comedians, from classically trained Shakespearean actors, to improvisors. All profits from the show will go to Art for Progress’s programs for children and young adults--helping to empower New York City’s young artists.

Art for Progress is a 501(c)3 nonprofit arts organization committed to the cultivation and support of emerging artists working in diverse genres: the visual arts, fashion, music, film, and new media. Based in New York City, AFP seeks to increase the visibility of talented artists, to raise the awareness of the importance of arts education in public schools, and support those same arts through its arts education program.

Art for Progress Arts Education Program provides underserved youth with dynamic artistic programming that promotes reflection and self-expression.  By connecting youth with working artists, their communities and each other we hope to transform the way they see themselves, their communities, and the world around them.   http://www.artforprogress.org

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please help us spread the word about our fundraising campaign, Art for Progress: Cymbeline, and our upcoming performances!

  • Share our campaign with your friends
  • Like our Facebook page and share our updates

Show Dates: April 27th - May 14th Tickets go on sale late February.

story:
Unfortunately 7% of all children in India are orphaned as a result of disease, violence and poverty. Without a substantial welfare system in place in India, orphanages rely on donations and volunteers. The orphanage in Faridibad, Delhi, is just over two decades old and currently houses 85 girls aged from 6-24. These vulnerable children need volunteers to help fund their safety and wellbeing within the orphanage, as well as teach them valuable skills such as English and computer science which will help them once they leave the organisation.

The money I raise will go towards both my volunteering expenses, as well as helping to fund the indian orphanage I will be volunteering in. I would love to be able to use my teaching and TEFL skills, as well as my work experience with children to enable these children to have a brighter future.

To fundraise for this I will be doing a whole host of activities, both enjoyable and not. I will be competing in the Women's Nike 10k Run in London, those of you who know me well know this is my ultimate nightmare... I will also be doing heaps of babysitting, tutoring, doing people's makeup and other odd jobs. Hopefully I will reach my target by the time I leave in mid july.

Any donation/sponsorship would be more than appreciated! I'm not joking when I say every penny counts!. Thank you so much everyone for your support!

story:
Help us raise money to market and produce In Vestments-

"When people will not weed their own minds, they are apt to be overrun by nettles.' - Horace Walpole

A new play by award winning playwright, Sara Fellini, In Vestments, is about four priests and a sacristan living and working in an old church that is falling apart around them. Haunted by the ghosts and demons of their pasts they find themselves fighting each other and their own destructive natures as they struggle to rebuild the church. After a chalice of sanctified communion wine is poisoned by a piece of asbestos falling from the ceiling, the ensuing argument over what do with the poisoned but holy wine sets off a chain reaction of destructive events that tears apart the fragile balance holding the church together and reveals the terrible secrets holding each of the priests and the sacristan to the church.

story:
Nothing But Nonsense

"Hold the phone and hide the good China!

Steve and Ryan, the Sultans of Slapstick, present their new show, Nothing But Nonsense, a hilarious cavalcade of singing, dancing and visual gags that has people everywhere asking, “Who hired these two?!”

Mirroring the lives of Steve & Ryan, Nothing But Nonsense is a raucous romp filled with music, magic, and other underwhelming achievements that will have you laughing so hard rubber chickens will shoot out your nose!

Come and get in on the act with Nothing But Nonsense, an exciting extravaganza of pure entertainment that you’ll never forget….no matter how hard you try. "

We are Steve Copeland and Ryan Combs, and our passion is making people laugh. We have spent the past thirteen years touring the United States and abroad doing exactly that.

It has been our dream for many years to bring our unique brand of entertainment to people all over the world with our own show.

Nothing But Nonsense is that show. Your contribution will make our dream come true, and we can continue doing what we do best: making people of all ages roar with laughter.

P.S- We did not win the $1.6 billion Powerball drawing, so this campaign is our Plan B! 


What We Need 

Since we have spent the majority of our careers as circus clowns, we are not exactly rolling in dough! 

We are raising funds to purchase the following:

  • Original music: $2,000
  • Microphones and other sound equipment: $4,000
  • Costumes: $1,000
  • Steel, wood, foam, coating, and paint for set and prop construction: $3,000

Your donations can earn you many exciting perks, which you can read more about below.


What You Get

$2 USD: Our Gratitude

You will have our eternal gratitude and a fond place in our hearts.

$10 USD: Public Thank You

For every donation of $10 or more, your name will appear alongside the names of all our other contributors on the Nothing But Nonsense website (coming soon).

$20 USD: Facebook Thank You

You will receive a personalized thank you on the Steve & Ryan Facebook page.

$50 USD: Video Thank You

You will a receive a personalized thank you video on the Steve & Ryan Facebook page.

$75 USD: Signed Photo

You will receive an autographed 8x10 Nothing But Nonsense photograph. Free shipping in the United States.

$100 USD: Orignial Art

An original piece of Nothing But Nonsense Conceptual Art drawn by Ryan Combs, plus an autographed Nothing But Nonsense 8x10. Free shipping in the United States.

$500 USD: Original Prop

An original, hand carved, foam rubber and latex prop made by Steve & Ryan, plus an autographed Nothing But Nonsense 8x10. Your choice of a hammer, a pie shell, or an anvil.

$1,000 USD: Tour Of Circus World Museum

A Family Five Pack of Tickets to Circus World Museum in Baraboo, WI to see Nothing But Nonsense in person, plus a V.I.P. tour of the Circus World Museum grounds. Transportation and lodging not included.

$5,000 USD: Tour & Workshop

A Family Five Pack of Tickets to Circus World Museum, a V.I.P. tour of the grounds, plus a two hour slapstick workshop taught by Steve & Ryan. Transportation and lodging not included.

$10,000 USD: The Whole Enchilada

You will receive all of the perks offered, plus we will wash your car, and.....make you a whole enchilada!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any money to donate, you can help us by spreading the word about this campaign.

Simply share this link http://igg.me/at/nonsense to social media and spread the Nonsense to all your friends and enemies!

story:
Our Project

Cass/Andra is the hauntingly current re-imagining of the Trojan War as seen through the fractured eyes of one woman.  Cassandra is a prophetess blessed with knowing the future, but her rejection of her traditional place in the world leaves her impotent and cursed. In Heretic’s production Cassandra is psychologically fragmented by her visions and possessed by Agamemnon, Ajax and Clytemnestra, her enemies.  Now at the foreseen death’s door she stands at the crossroads between knowing and doing, surviving and dying.  As she ritualistically relives her journey to provoke Clytemnestra into action, she realizes the inevitable fate of mankind, and her inescapable destiny as long as fear, war and religious indoctrination are woven together. Cass/Andra brings together award winning artists from Chicago, New York and LA in collaboration with innovative sound, video and dance and pushes the boundaries of solo-performance.


Our Goal

Our fundraising goal is $10,000. This covers the budgets for our design areas (set, lights, costumes, sound, projections) and stipends for the artists working on this piece. If you are interested in the specifics we have a breakdown of our budget below.

If you like this show, our mission, and our team please share our fundraising campaign with your friends and help spread the word!

One woman, one voice speaking out can make a difference and change the world.

“Madness and witchery as well as bestiality are conditions commonly associated with the use of the female voice in public, in ancient as well as modern contexts. Consider how many female celebrities of classical mythology, literature and cult make themselves objectionable by the way they use their voice. There is the deadly voice of the Sirens and the dangerous ventriloquism of Helen and the incredible babbling of Kassandra …. There is the haunting garrulity of the nymph Echo (daughter of Iambe in Athenian legend) who is described by Sophokles as 'the girl with no door on her mouth.'
"Putting a door on the female mouth as been an important project of patriarchal culture from antiquity to present day. Its chief tactic is an ideological association of female sound with monstrosity, disorder and death.”
-Anne Carson "The Gender of Sound"


More Information

Our Budget

Personnel: $6000
We want to pay $500 stipends for the artists we work with. 12 artists=$6000 for stipends.

Design Departments: $2100
This covers cost of materials for each of our design departments- set, costumes, lighting, sound, and projections. This money will be used to cover everything from lumber for the set to lighting and projections equipment.

Marketing: $1000
Our marketing costs cover everything from the cost of production photos to the fee for setting up the bank account for our production funds.

Miscellaneous: $900
This covers the cost of everything else- first aid, rehearsal space rental, and our slush fund.


History of the Project

Writer/performer Lyndsay Kane began working on this project in 2001 as part of a Graduate Course when 9-11 happened.  She began to recognize an eerie similarity to the events, and more particularly the religious rhetoric unfolding in the world, with those in Cassandra’s story.  Kane realized the myth still had potent lessons to teach. Kane felt compelled to give a voice to the protestors of war and submitted the production to the LA Edge Fest, unfortunately life and health events stepped in and brought the production to a halt.  Shortly after she and her fiance moved back home to the Midwest, where one of her first auditions in Chicago was for Kate Hendrickson (director of Cass/Andra).  After working together, Kane recognized Hendrickson’s talent for directing and cultivating new work.  Coupled with a deep friendship and artistic like-mindedness, Kane decided she had found the perfect director to help see Cass/Andra to fruition.  Together they enlisted the brilliant and dedicated minds of Deirdre Connelly and Taylor Bibat to help produce the show. These four women, who make up Heretic Productions, brought together members of the original design team along with some of the greatest designers Chicago has to offer.


Our Team

Lyndsay Kane - Writer/Performer

Lyndsay Rose Kane been performing on stage since she was 12. She graduated from Macalester College with a BA, where she created her own Major in Dance Theater in 1999. In 2002 she earned her MFA in Acting from CalArts. She has extensive training in voice, Ballet, Modern Dance, Mask Improvisation, Bhuto, Aerial Arts, Suzuki, and is a 200 hr Moksha Certified Yoga Instructor where she developed an Archetypal Based Yoga Sequencing Method for Actors.

As an actress Lyndsay has performed as the Duchess in Duchess of Malfi (Jeff Recommended*), Harriet Panini in Cookie Play*, Girl in Blood on The Cat's Neck* (Trap Door) Narrator in Stadium Devildare (Red Tape) Canary Mary in Fucking A* (Urban Theatre Co.) Estrella in Life as a Dream* (Vitalist) Gertrude in Hamletmacine (Trap Door) Sirah in Zero and The Woman Scotland Road (Oracle Theater) and the One-Woman production of Le Liste for Premiere Theatre's International Voices and the Alta conference. She has performed in New York City, LA, and London in multiple shows from American Magic directed by Matthew Wilder, to King Lear directed by Travis Preston, and The Tempest directed by Edward Taylor. Lyndsay has also worked as a movement director/ choreographer on the critically acclaimed productions of No Beast So Fierce, The Mother,* Woyzeck,* and Blood Wedding (Oracle), Dance Party at the End of the World (Walkabout Theater) Three Graces (Pivot Arts Festival), and Hamletmachine, No Darkness Round My Stone, The Unconquored, Me Too I'm Catherine Deuvre, and Anger/Fly (Trap Door). Kane has also directed Box and Cox for the Bucktown Arts Festival, and Philip Marlow and Hairpin Turn, and Gunsmoke for Oracle Outreach and annual Radio Goggles performance. A founding company member of Filament Theater Co. in LA, she is currently the Casting Director and Associate Company Member at Oracle Theatre, and a proud company member of Trap Door Theater

Kate Hendrickson -  Director

Kate Hendrickson is a resident director at Trap Door Theatre, Chicago's foremost avant garde theatre, where she specializes in directing new work. For Trap Door Kate, has directed numerous critically acclaimed and award-winning world premieres. A graduate of Bennington College in Vermont, Kate has worked as an actor and director in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and abroad. She performed internationally at the Komedia Theatre in Brighton, England; the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland; and with the Dutch performance collective Lupus Ludens. While in Los Angeles, Kate did script analysis and casting work for films and television, and played small roles in several films (credits: imdb.com/name/nm0376789/). Kate is also the founder and director of Summerdale Workshop. Located in Andersonville, Summerdale Workshop provides children with high-quality acting instruction in a playful yet focused setting.

Leon Rothenberg - Sound Designer

Leon is a Tony award-winning Sound Designer based in New York City who has designed for a number of environments including theater, film, dance, installation and the circus. Recent credits include musicals and plays across the country at venues such as the Old Globe, Arena Stage, Seattle Repertory Theater, New York Stage and Film, La Jolla Playhouse, New York City Center, The Theater at Madison Square Garden and on Broadway. He designed sound for Cirque du Soleil’s Kooza, currently touring the world, and Wintuk, Cirque’s winter holiday show in New York City. 

Recent designs on Broadway include Violet, The Realistic Joneses and The Nance, for which he won the Tony for Best Sound Design of a play. Other recent work includes The Last Five Years at Long Wharf, The Happiest Song Plays Last at Second Stage, the critically acclaimed February House at The Public Theater, August Wilson’s Jitney at Two Rivers and Some Lovers written by Stephen Sater and Burt Bacharach at The Old Globe. 

In addition to theater, other work includes sound score for the innovative multimedia dance duo Bridgeman|Packer, feature film and documentary sound, and several short films both live action and animation.

Leon served on the Theater faculty at CalArts, and has taught at Bennington College in Vermont. He holds a B.M. in Composition from Oberlin Conservatory, a B.A. from Oberlin College in Computer Science and an M.F.A. from California Institute of the Arts.

Irina Kruzhilina -  Costume Designer

Irina Kruzhilina is a New York-based costume designer for the performing arts. Her work has been shown all over the world, from BAM to the National Theatre in Prague, and from Fischer Center at Bard College to a floating barge on the East River in Queens. Ms. Kruzhilina designed costumes for dozens of theatre, dance, opera, and puppetry performances, including with David Chambers (Merchant of Venice, Don Juan in Prague), Ruth Margraff (Three Graces), Else-Marie Lauvik (Arctic Hysteria), Mabou Mines (Song for New York), DNA works (HaMapah), SCRAP performance group (Tide) and Adam McKinney (Heliotrope). Her work has appeared at the Philadelphia Live Arts, Spoleto Fringe and DAH Teater (Belgrade, Serbia) festivals. A native of Moscow, Russia, Ms. Kruzhilina is dedicated to connecting Western and Eastern European theatre through international collaborations, which led to multiple productions with Plovdiv Dramatischen Theatre in Bulgaria and director Stayko Murdjev, and with director Alexander Sharovsky at the Russian Drama Theatre in Baku, Azerbaijan. She received the 2007 NEA/TCG Career Development Program For Theatre Designers, and is a Chashama resident.

Phillip Livingston - Set Designer

Philip Livingston is a sculptor/designer with ties to theatre and architecture. His work explores themes of memory, the tension between reality and illusion, the relationship of physical to spiritual, gravity and lightness, and other perplexing contrasts. But never all at once! Different themes emerge in different materials in pieces created in series that have taken periods of one to five or so years.

Livingston has a B.A. from Brown University and an M.F.A. from the university of Wisconsin. He is a Fellow of the American Academy in Rome. His sculpture is in the collections of the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis; the Knoxville Museum of Art; the Knoxville Convention Center; the Tennessee Valley Authority (on three sites); Oakton Community College, Des Plaines, IL; and many private collections. He has been represented by Adele Rosenberg Gallery, Chicago; Ward-Nasse Gallery, New York; Sonia Zaks Gallery, Chicago; James Tigerman Gallery, and Perimeter Gallery, Chicago.

Paul Deziel - Projections Designer  

Paul Deziel designs theatrical projections and video in and around Chicago. He graduated from Columbia College Chicago in May of 2014 with a degree in Technical Theatre. While his focus in theatre may be niche, his interest is voluminous, working as an actor, stage manager, run crew, carpenter, electrician, props designer, and video technician. He has worked with a variety of companies, including: Steppenwolf, The Neo-Futurists, Strawdog, Congo Square, The Mercury Theater, Red Tape Theatre, Cold Basement Dramatics, Route 66, Adventure Stage Chicago, Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and Collaboraction, and has even had his work seen internationally. He is an Artistic Affiliate with American Blues Theater and SoloChicago. Paul is also a member of the MegaGame Society of Chicago. Outside of theatre, Paul enjoys playing table-top games, watching silent films, and thinking of finishing those plays he has started to write.

Michael Banks - Lighting Designer

Beth Miller - Draper

Beth Laske-Miller is a Chicago-based costume designer. Midsommer Flight designs include Much Ado About Nothing and Romeo & Juliet.  Other design credits include Coraline for Black Button Eyes Productions, Lay Me Down Softly, The Seafarer, In Pigeon House, A Moon for the Misbegottenand That was Then atSeanachai Theatre Company,Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead, A Study in Scarlet and The Caucasian Chalk Circle at Promethean Theatre Ensemble, L’Imitation of Life at Hell in a Handbag, Saturday Night/Sunday Morning and Take Her to See the Maco Lights at Prologue Theatre Co. Beth was recently nominated for a 2013 Non-Equity Joseph Jefferson Award in Costume Design for A Study in Scarlet with Promethean Theatre Ensemble.She holds a BA in Costume/Fashion Design from Indiana University – Bloomington, and an MFA in Costume Design from CalArts.


Big thanks to Logan Conner and Candice Conner, Oomphotography for the videos and photos!

She has performed in New York City, LA, and London in multiple shows from American Magic directed by Matthew Wilder, to King Lear directed by Travis Preston, and The Tempest directed by Edward Taylor. Lyndsay has also worked as a movement director/ choreographer on the critically acclaimed productions of No Beast So Fierce, The Mother,* Woyzeck,* and Blood Wedding (Oracle), Dance Party at the End of the World (Walkabout Theater) Three Graces (Pivot Arts Festival), and Hamletmachine, No Darkness Round My Stone, The Unconquored, Me Too I'm Catherine Deuvre, and Anger/Fly (Trap Door). Kane has also directed Box and Cox for the Bucktown Arts Festival, and Philip Marlow and Hairpin Turn, and Gunsmoke for Oracle Outreach and annual Radio Goggles performance. A founding company member of Filament Theater Co. in LA, she is currently the Casting Director and Associate Company Member at Oracle Theatre, and a proud company member of Trap Door Theater


Kate Hendrickson -  Director
Kate Hendrickson is a resident director at Trap Door Theatre, Chicago's foremost avant garde theatre, where she specializes in directing new work. For Trap Door Kate, has directed numerous critically acclaimed and award-winning world premieres. A graduate of Bennington College in Vermont, Kate has worked as an actor and director in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and abroad. She performed internationally at the Komedia Theatre in Brighton, England; the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland; and with the Dutch performance collective Lupus Ludens. While in Los Angeles, Kate did script analysis and casting work for films and television, and played small roles in several films (credits: imdb.com/name/nm0376789/). Kate is also the founder and director of Summerdale Workshop. Located in Andersonville, Summerdale Workshop provides children with high-quality acting instruction in a playful yet focused setting.
Leon Rothenberg - Sound Designer

Leon is a Tony award-winning Sound Designer based in New York City who has designed for a number of environments including theater, film, dance, installation and the circus. Recent credits include musicals and plays across the country at venues such as the Old Globe, Arena Stage, Seattle Repertory Theater, New York Stage and Film, La Jolla Playhouse, New York City Center, The Theater at Madison Square Garden and on Broadway. He designed sound for Cirque du Soleil’s Kooza, currently touring the world, and Wintuk, Cirque’s winter holiday show in New York City. 

Recent designs on Broadway include Violet, The Realistic Joneses and The Nance, for which he won the Tony for Best Sound Design of a play. Other recent work includes The Last Five Years at Long Wharf, The Happiest Song Plays Last at Second Stage, the critically acclaimed February House at The Public Theater, August Wilson’s Jitney at Two Rivers and Some Lovers written by Stephen Sater and Burt Bacharach at The Old Globe. 
In addition to theater, other work includes sound score for the innovative multimedia dance duo Bridgeman|Packer, feature film and documentary sound, and several short films both live action and animation.
Leon served on the Theater faculty at CalArts, and has taught at Bennington College in Vermont. He holds a B.M. in Composition from Oberlin Conservatory, a B.A. from Oberlin College in Computer Science and an M.F.A. from California Institute of the Arts.

Irina Kruzhilina -  Costume Designer
Irina Kruzhilina is a New York-based costume designer for the performing arts. Her work has been shown all over the world, from BAM to the National Theatre in Prague, and from Fischer Center at Bard College to a floating barge on the East River in Queens. Ms. Kruzhilina designed costumes for dozens of theatre, dance, opera, and puppetry performances, including with David Chambers (Merchant of Venice, Don Juan in Prague), Ruth Margraff (Three Graces), Else-Marie Lauvik (Arctic Hysteria), Mabou Mines (Song for New York), DNA works (HaMapah), SCRAP performance group (Tide) and Adam McKinney (Heliotrope). Her work has appeared at the Philadelphia Live Arts, Spoleto Fringe and DAH Teater (Belgrade, Serbia) festivals. A native of Moscow, Russia, Ms. Kruzhilina is dedicated to connecting Western and Eastern European theatre through international collaborations, which led to multiple productions with Plovdiv Dramatischen Theatre in Bulgaria and director Stayko Murdjev, and with director Alexander Sharovsky at the Russian Drama Theatre in Baku, Azerbaijan. She received the 2007 NEA/TCG Career Development Program For Theatre Designers, and is a Chashama resident.
Phillip Livingston - Set Designer

Philip Livingston is a sculptor/designer with ties to theatre and architecture. His work explores themes of memory, the tension between reality and illusion, the relationship of physical to spiritual, gravity and lightness, and other perplexing contrasts. But never all at once! Different themes emerge in different materials in pieces created in series that have taken periods of one to five or so years.
Livingston has a B.A. from Brown University and an M.F.A. from the university of Wisconsin. He is a Fellow of the American Academy in Rome. His sculpture is in the collections of the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis; the Knoxville Museum of Art; the Knoxville Convention Center; the Tennessee Valley Authority (on three sites); Oakton Community College, Des Plaines, IL; and many private collections. He has been represented by Adele Rosenberg Gallery, Chicago; Ward-Nasse Gallery, New York; Sonia Zaks Gallery, Chicago; James Tigerman Gallery, and Perimeter Gallery, Chicago.
Paul Deziel - Projections Designer  
Paul Deziel designs theatrical projections and video in and around Chicago. He graduated from Columbia College Chicago in May of 2014 with a degree in Technical Theatre. While his focus in theatre may be niche, his interest is voluminous, working as an actor, stage manager, run crew, carpenter, electrician, props designer, and video technician. He has worked with a variety of companies, including: Steppenwolf, The Neo-Futurists, Strawdog, Congo Square, The Mercury Theater, Red Tape Theatre, Cold Basement Dramatics, Route 66, Adventure Stage Chicago, Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and Collaboraction, and has even had his work seen internationally. He is an Artistic Affiliate with American Blues Theater and SoloChicago. Paul is also a member of the MegaGame Society of Chicago. Outside of theatre, Paul enjoys playing table-top games, watching silent films, and thinking of finishing those plays he has started to write.
Michael Banks - Lighting Designer
Beth Miller - Draper

Beth Laske-Miller is a Chicago-based costume designer. Midsommer Flight designs include Much Ado About Nothing and Romeo & Juliet.  Other design credits include Coraline for Black Button Eyes Productions, Lay Me Down Softly, The Seafarer, In Pigeon House, A Moon for the Misbegottenand That was Then atSeanachai Theatre Company,Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead, A Study in Scarlet and The Caucasian Chalk Circle at Promethean Theatre Ensemble, L’Imitation of Life at Hell in a Handbag, Saturday Night/Sunday Morning and Take Her to See the Maco Lights at Prologue Theatre Co. Beth was recently nominated for a 2013 Non-Equity Joseph Jefferson Award in Costume Design for A Study in Scarlet with Promethean Theatre Ensemble.She holds a BA in Costume/Fashion Design from Indiana University – Bloomington, and an MFA in Costume Design from CalArts.

Big thanks to Logan Conner and Candice Conner, Oomphotography for the videos and photos!

story:
In August of 2014 Sync Book Press held our first major Sync Summit in Olympia, Washington. The event was a great success and featured talks and presentations from Sync Book authors, broadcasters and sync filmmakers, including a Radio8Ball Show with Mark Hosler of Negativland, a walking tour of The Kabbalistic Tree of Olympia, a Skype appearance from Rodney Ascher (Room 237), and a constant flow of sync that is documented at thesyncbook.com/oly2014.

Now in January of 2016 Sync Book Press is releasing all the footage from the 2014 event AND launching a new season of Sync activities that includes an exclusive Spring Sync event in Boise, Idaho in March and the next Oly Sync Summit in August.



THIS IS A 3-PHASE PROJECT

The Boise Spring Sync (March 23rd-27th)  will be an opportunity to spend an intimate weekend with fellow explorers of synchronicity in a relaxed environment during Boise's Treefort Music Festival. Sort of like  our version of 'The Real World, Boise edition.' We are renting a house in downtown Boise with plans for some guerrilla sync experiments at the Treefort Music Fest as well as exploring what kind of media and artwork we can create together over the four nights and five days of our retreat.

The Olympia Sync Summit (August 18th-21st) will once again feature a Radio8Ball Show, as well as a full moon Tree Walk. In lieu of traditional presentations, the weekend will focus on screenings of new material and moderated discussions of a wide range of Sync topics. We have some ideas about topics we'd like to cover and we are also very interested in what's on the mind of our participants so please include your suggestion with your contributions.
The scope of the events we plan will be dependent upon the response to this campaign so if you want it to be something special we need you to get your tickets early and spread the word to your fellow sync enthusiasts.

A Sync Summit Documentary is just begging to be made. We captured some of the most incredible minds in some of the most sync saturated moments. Our camera crews were everywhere (as the videos we've released so far, as well as all the remaining videos we will be releasing for the full month of January, documented so well). Yet we are still sitting on a lot of excellent HD footage - which means a sync film crew doesn't have to worry about copyright issues for maybe the first time ever. If we meet our full goal, we'll pay to have the footage color corrected and have the audio mastered and will produce a completed documentary of the 2014 Sync Summit. If funded, this would premiere in Olympia this August and everyone who donated at the $42 mark or above will get a digital download of the film.



PERKS

This indiegogo is, for the most part, a ticket pre-sale. Most of the perks for this campaign cover the cost of admission to the events, and your lodging, which in Olympia includes breakfast at Fertile Ground.
But a number of you (particularly those who live in far away countries) have told us that we should make items such as T-Shirts that you could buy to support our event. You've spoken and we've listened.

We've made T-Shirts and autographed posters available as perks to our campaign as well as E-books and hey, if you've only got a small amount, we'll still shout you out on upcoming episodes of the Sync Book Radio programs "42 Minutes" and "Always Record."



Ultimately, the biggest perk of all is getting to spend time with friends and community members. The same is true of our end of the deal; we don't have a profit motive here as the money goes right back into production costs. Yet we feel the time and effort is totally worth it to make these events happen and have everyone together. We'll try and raise the money and put in the hard work to throw a great sync party, but it's up to you to join us and participate. We truly can't wait to see you there!

story:
Raggedy And by David Valdes Greenwood, featuring Delia Kropp who is returning to the stage after several years away.

In Raggedy And, a fast-paced ultramodern comedy of manners, the perfect poet is needed for the impending inauguration of America’s first female president. When Ondi Rivers is selected, her wife hits the roof and her son is torn. Imagining the glare of the media spotlight on her family’s private life, will she take the stage?

Ondi, you see, made her transition long ago, and has a great life with her wife Clem and their son Ben. With the spotlight of the inauguration shining on them, their world will be turned upside down.

Once we decided to produce the play, the search was on for a trans performer to play the trans role of Ondi. And as spoke to theater directors and administrators in town, one name - Delia Kropp - kept coming up.

Before gender transitioning, Delia Kropp trained in England and Chicago, and acted with a variety of Chicago companies including The Goodman, Red Twist, Griffin, Lifeline, and Pegasus Players. She won Best Supporting Actor for her work as Alan in “Equus” at Michigan’s renowned Boarshead Theatre. She has also directed a number of productions for Chicago storefront and educational institutions. Delia’s female acting career begins with “Raggedy And” at Pride Films and Plays in 2016.

And so we begin... launching a new play,  launching a renewed career.  It is time to step into the spotlight indeed.

I hope you can support this project, and I hope you will see the play. Your financial support allows us to increase our marketing efforts to student groups and to others interested in trans issues, as well as great theater!

Please make sure you let everyone know about our project. Your financial support helps us increase our marketing budget and reach more people across the country with this exciting production and event.

And check out www,pridefilmsandplays.com for a full schedule of our theater productions, staged readings and workshops, film festivals and film projects, and more.  

We have teams of artists working to develop new LezPlay performance pieces written by women with lesbian characters or themes. We have a team working on new musical forms and concepts, and another team developing diverse voices for the LGBT community.

Our work may be LGBT themed, but it is essential viewing for all.

Raggedy And by David Valdes Greenwood, directed by Cecilie D. Keenan, plays March 10 to April 10 at Rivendell Theater, 5779 N Ridge in Chicago. The play features Delia Kropp, Katurah Nelson, Manny Ortiz, and Averis Anderson.

Purchase tickets or get more information at www.pridefilmsandplays.com or by calling 1 800 737 0984.

story:
The Bard & Bourbon Theatre Company adds an alcoholic twist to classic plays, with a goal of introducing Shakespeare to new audiences in a fun and relatable manner. 

Each fully rehearsed and memorized production features small non-traditional casts playing multiple parts while getting one actor very drunk over the course of the show.

Our current production, Romeo and Juliet, will be performed at In Tandem Theatre over Memorial Day Weekend - May 25-29.

story:
Support a new kind of entertainment! Killer Theater is a living game where the audience takes action -- and plays a part in the show!

We Are: 

A deadly elite squad of murderous assassins.

Our Goals: 

  • Create theater that is immersive, exciting, local, and memorable
  • Create characters that are fun and original, but also iconic and universal
  • Create shows that star you, the audience!
  • Reach out and expand the theater community--not just to actors--but to other performers and new performers, making theater accessible to all!

Your small donation helps us:

  • To create unique, out-of-the-box characters: Our audiences will love to get dressed up in the costume pieces your donation will help us purchase and maintain. (Never underestimate the power of a silly hat, or disguising pair of glasses to bring the inner sleuth...or murderer, out of an audience member!)  
  • To find and create custom interactive props and set pieces: Your donations will help us transform the spaces we use into the perfect setting for MURDER! These make the experience more immersive--and thus more memorable. 
  • To print the many pages we need to tell our stories: This ranges from clues, maps, and interactive games used to help solve the mysteries, and our scripts, helping create the mystery in the first place! We will open with a roster of three scripts that can be performed in almost any venue, with all of these KEY materials. For clarity's sake, donate to keep this helpful part of our show, part of our show!
  • To purchase sound equipment: so our shows can be performed anywhere. There is nothing worse than missing key clues, or fun scenes, because you can't hear the actors speaking. Sadly, audio equipment is never cheap. Unsadly, your donation will help us purchase microphones, speakers, and a mixer, so our audiences can enjoy the game without having to say "what?" every ten seconds...like a bad rapper from the '90s.
  • PLUS! Your donations will help us obtain all the less-than-sexy necessities of a traveling theater company: like carrying cases, sandbag ballasts (so things don't fall on people! We do shy away from actual murder...most of the time), and letting people know we exist!

Many theaters ask several times what we are asking in contributions, just for one staging of a show. We will build a sustainable business that provides affordable and engaging interactive entertainment for the audience, while paying actors a sustainable rate for their time.

The Impact Your Donation Has

On Audiences:

The people of New Orleans are -- let's face it -- larger than life! Boisterous, outspoken, as unique as the city itself -- and as colorful! But...you have to admit... we're not always well behaved.
But that's no problem, our shows are MADE FOR New Orleanians (and the kind that prefer to escape here from they're quieter abodes)! Killer Theater is a social experience, an interactive art piece, and an all around great time!
On the Community:

We designed this company with actors in mind. Performers are frequently asked to donate their time and skills, over and over, to passion projects. We don't believe the most talented and skilled performers of our city should be resigned to poverty because of their own generosity! In fact, we believe in supporting our actors, we can bring better performances & better shows to the audience!

We believe there is a major opportunity for theater to be affordable, yet profitable, and an amazing experience for everyone involved!

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge will be the same as any company: proving to our audiences and clients that we are the best at what we do. 

We've assembled a strong team of actors, directors, producers, and managers with a wide range of experience in improvisation, murder mystery, comedy, design, dinner theater, and performance art. They are deadly talented individuals who together can put on shows that audiences will be dying to see.

How long it takes to reach those audiences is our biggest challenge, and we appreciate you helping us to get the word out! Share our campaign with your friends using the social media links at the top!

story:
We're opening another community oriented dance studio! Our second dance studio will be in Tri County Mall. We are able to do it for only $6,000! Anything else we need can be upgraded over time. Our other location took 2 years and almost $25,000 to complete. If this campaign nets $10,000 we will offer our first month of group classes free to everyone! If it reaches $15,000 we will offer another month of classes for FREE! Who doesn't love free classes? So please share this and help bring the most exciting new store into Tri County Mall! Please help us continue to inspire and motivate through dance!

 

Hey everybody!
My name is Greg Insco. Two years ago a team of excited instructors opened a dance studio through community involvement inside Northgate Mall. Because of the impact we had on our community, our friends at Tri County Mall encouraged us to grow and open a second location. We are thrilled to do it again! Opening these dance studios has been the funnest accident we've ever had. We love bringing people together! So stop by, WE PROMISE YOU'LL HAVE FUN! 
 
Who are we?
 
Owner/Instructor: Greg Insco
Greg has walked across America, officiated countless weddings, is an elected Trustee in Colerain Township, and done over 40 shows/movies. He even performed on dancing with the stars live tour, twice. If you only remember three words he says, remember this: LIVE YOUR DREAMS!
 
Owner/Instructor: Jeff Anderson
Jeff is a 5th grade teacher and has taught for 23 years. He has also taught line dancing for 20 years. When he's not teaching he's DJ'ing weddings or looking for Bigfoot!
 
Phoenix Rising Ballroom Owner and Instructor: Lenny & Maria teach all types of dance!
 
We are always looking for new instructors. Here are some great ones that teach at our other location:  Jeff W., Tim, Demitrious, Kathryn, Lori, Sandy, Matthew, Carolyn, Erin, and Jeannie.
 
We have the best front desk anyone could ask for. Vanessa, Lori, Jeannie, Mindy, Leslie, Keisha, and Miranda are all beyond amazing.
 
We are always interested in adding classes/instructors. Send ideas to: thereverendgreg@gmail.com
 

What We Need & What You Get

*Check out our fun perks! We will also be doing a grand opening party with raffles if anyone has something they'd like to donate for one of our raffle baskets:)

*It took us 2 years  and over $25,000 to complete our first location. Luckily this location already has hardwood floors, which saves us a fortune! So we are able to build out the new location for only $6,000. We couldn't do it without you!

*If we don't reach our entire goal we are still opening. It will just take a lot longer to get everything picture perfect.

The Impact

*We have helped countless students reach their weight loss goals. We even do competitions!

*Everyone needs to make time for themselves. If the best hour of your day wasn't at The Studio, then you've had a really good day:)

*Bringing people together is by far the best part about what we do! We bring together everyone from neighbors to sisters to friends to married couples. We've all met a new best friend at The Studio:)

* We've never turned down a charity. We do at least one event/donation per month:) We always donate passes/raffles to any cause. If it's important to you, it's important to us!

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize times are tough for lots of great people but that doesn't mean you can't help:)

*Sharing this link is free:)

*We have a ton of flyers we need to pass out to all the local business's. 

*If you can help with any raffle baskets for our grand opening party that would be awesome!

You never know where life will take you! If you only remember three words from this campaign, remember this:

LIVE YOUR DREAMS!
story_txt:
We're opening another community oriented dance studio! Our second dance studio will be in Tri County Mall. We are able to do it for only $6,000! Anything else we need can be upgraded over time. Our other location took 2 years and almost $25,000 to complete. If this campaign nets $10,000 we will offer our first month of group classes free to everyone! If it reaches $15,000 we will offer another month of classes for FREE! Who doesn't love free classes? So please share this and help bring the most exciting new store into Tri County Mall! Please help us continue to inspire and motivate through dance!
 
Hey everybody!
My name is Greg Insco. Two years ago a team of excited instructors opened a dance studio through community involvement inside Northgate Mall. Because of the impact we had on our community, our friends at Tri County Mall encouraged us to grow and open a second location. We are thrilled to do it again! Opening these dance studios has been the funnest accident we've ever had. We love bringing people together! So stop by, WE PROMISE YOU'LL HAVE FUN! 
 
Who are we?
 
Owner/Instructor: Greg Insco

Greg has walked across America, officiated countless weddings, is an elected Trustee in Colerain Township, and done over 40 shows/movies. He even performed on dancing with the stars live tour, twice. If you only remember three words he says, remember this: LIVE YOUR DREAMS!
 

Owner/Instructor: Jeff Anderson
Jeff is a 5th grade teacher and has taught for 23 years. He has also taught line dancing for 20 years. When he's not teaching he's DJ'ing weddings or looking for Bigfoot!
 
Phoenix Rising Ballroom Owner and Instructor: Lenny & Maria teach all types of dance!
 
We are always looking for new instructors. Here are some great ones that teach at our other location:  Jeff W., Tim, Demitrious, Kathryn, Lori, Sandy, Matthew, Carolyn, Erin, and Jeannie.
 
We have the best front desk anyone could ask for. Vanessa, Lori, Jeannie, Mindy, Leslie, Keisha, and Miranda are all beyond amazing.
 
We are always interested in adding classes/instructors. Send ideas to: thereverendgreg@gmail.com

 

What We Need & What You Get
*Check out our fun perks! We will also be doing a grand opening party with raffles if anyone has something they'd like to donate for one of our raffle baskets:)
*It took us 2 years  and over $25,000 to complete our first location. Luckily this location already has hardwood floors, which saves us a fortune! So we are able to build out the new location for only $6,000. We couldn't do it without you!
*If we don't reach our entire goal we are still opening. It will just take a lot longer to get everything picture perfect.

The Impact
*We have helped countless students reach their weight loss goals. We even do competitions!
*Everyone needs to make time for themselves. If the best hour of your day wasn't at The Studio, then you've had a really good day:)
*Bringing people together is by far the best part about what we do! We bring together everyone from neighbors to sisters to friends to married couples. We've all met a new best friend at The Studio:)
* We've never turned down a charity. We do at least one event/donation per month:) We always donate passes/raffles to any cause. If it's important to you, it's important to us!

Other Ways You Can Help
We realize times are tough for lots of great people but that doesn't mean you can't help:)
*Sharing this link is free:)
*We have a ton of flyers we need to pass out to all the local business's. 
*If you can help with any raffle baskets for our grand opening party that would be awesome!
You never know where life will take you! If you only remember three words from this campaign, remember this:LIVE YOUR DREAMS!

story:
About Mad Monkey Improv

Mad Monkey Improv was formed in September 2013 by Alexander McWilliam. He had a passion for improvisation and after years of watching Whose Line is it anyway and The Comedy Store Players, he decided that the home counties needed an Improv group.

They had their first show in The Cellar bar at South Hill Park in October 2013, and after a great success they were asked back to perform a regular Sunday night slot once a month there. 

Fast forward 2 years and Mad Monkey Improv have been performing to sell out shows in the Cellar Bar and have received numerous 4 and 5 Star reviews as well as being shortlisted for 'Pick of the Fringe' at the Reading Fringe Festival 2015.

5* "One word. Brilliant." - getreading

4* "Clutch-your-wobbling-belly hilarious." - Broadsheet Boutique

4* "A cracking night of comedy...Just what the Berkshire comedy scene needs" - Reading Post

“Number 1 show to see at Reading Fringe!” - Reading Unplugged

"Kept the audience laughing all night"

"A really enjoyable night of well executed fun and mischief" - British Theatre Guide

To celebrate 3 years we wanted to perform in a bigger venue, but still keep at our home, South Hill Park Arts Centre. The next biggest venue is The Wilde Theatre. This seats 3 times as many people as we can have in the cellar bar and is a big step up in performance space and audience for us.

We want to be able to perform in this lovely theatre, to a packed out crowd who either can't afford to get into London, or it is too difficult to get to.

If we manage to achieve our target, then you will enable us to perform our Improv show to hundreds of people at a more affordable cost.

What We Need & What You Get

The money we raise will:

- Hire of the Wilde Theatre.

- Pay for set, props and costume accessories.

- Help us with marketing the show to ensure that it reaches out to a wide demographic.

- Pay our hugely talented improvisers, creative and production team.

In return for your support, we have a range of exciting perks for you. Some of which are: tickets to the show, signed programmes, signed posters T-Shirts, workshops for you, your school or your company, or even your own improv show! Everyone who donates, no matter how much, will be listed as a supporter on our website, and given a social media thank you.

What Happens if we get more?

If we over reach our target then the following things can happen with our show:

Better lighting and sound equipment

Videoing the show. (If you are involved in any games on stage we can send you a copy of the clip)

Photographing the show.

A few games that require more technical equipment will be able to be played.

The Impact

Improv and comedy are very overlooked when it comes to funding. Mainly because it is not your usual mainstream art form like a play, dance piece or musical. This makes it very hard to get funding, and with all the cuts happening in the Arts, it makes it even harder.

Sometimes the best way to beat those Sunday blues before starting work on Monday is to have one last big laugh. For the past 2 years we have been making audiences laugh on Sunday nights and make people forget all about the troubles they might have in their life and have a good night out. In Berkshire there is no other Improv Troupe with a regular show. You get the odd touring one, but nothing that Berkshire can say "this is ours!" We are hoping to be that group and the support you give to this project will enable our profile to be raised and so more theatres locally and further afield will hear about this and spread Mad Monkey Improv further.

If you have seen one of our shows before you know that what you get is 2 hours of improvisation with up to 6 improvisers sweating it out on stage to give you more energy than you have seen before!  For this show we will potentially have up to 10 performers and musicians along with some special guests just for you!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to support the project financially, then we would value any support you can give us with helping to spread the word about Mad Monkey Improv's 3 Year Anniversary show. We are so grateful for every tweet, facebook post, instagram post, email or anything you can do.
On the night we'll need some Front of House help too, selling programmes and running a raffle.
Maybe you could just help us by contacting people you know who might be able to help and sharing this page with them? Or help raise our profile with the press and media.
All the tiny little things will help make this project a success.

story:
Since 2011, Patrick Dorow Productions (PDP) has worked hard to showcase incredible local artists of all ages, and serve the seacoast community, by producing Broadway-quality, live performance theater in Portsmouth, NH, and Kittery, Maine. Beloved as a professional theater and educational organization that feels like family, and renowned for consistently providing mind-blowing entertainment, PDP is excited to be growing and thrilled to have just announced a spectacular 2016 line-up of MainStage and Youth productions at The STAR Theatre in Kittery.  Our full blockbuster season includes hits such as Smokey Joe’s Café, Greenday’s American Idiot, Cabaret and Cats.  
 
We feel overwhelmingly proud and fortunate to be able to provide the best in musical theater, as we believe the Arts are critical to sustain the vibrant community we all love, and from which we all benefit, here on the Seacoast.  
 
This is where we need your help! For the past five years, we have had to rent sound equipment for our productions, and while the cost to rent is staggering, we will not compromise on quality sound.   We are at the point, now, where buying our own sound equipment is not only crucial, but also the fiscally responsible decision for our production company as we will recoup the cost of purchasing versus renting in one season.  
 
We have already received a generous sponsorship donation and need to raise additional funds.  ALL money donated from this campaign will go directly toward the purchase of our sound equipment. ALL additional money raised will be allocated toward the cost of purchasing lighting equipment—our next paramount capital expense. 
 
Thank you so much for your generosity, as any and all donations are greatly appreciated!  We invite you to come see (and hear) your contribution at one of our upcoming 2016 productions!

Who is PDP?

Patrick Dorow Productions is an award-winning performing arts organization located on the New England Seacoast, hosting performances year round in the STAR Theatre which shares the border between Portsmouth, NH and Kittery, ME. 

We specialize in the professional production of Music and Theatre and pair the best local talent with professional actors and performers from Broadway, Television and International tours. Our Performing Arts Education Program, Design Services, and annual Special Events make us a well-rounded performing arts group with extraordinary community outreach. 

Our Arts Education programming is comprised of classes and specialty workshops for children through adults. Holding regularly scheduled classes, private lessons, and workshops with renowned guest artists, Patrick Dorow Productions is home to a truly professional education experience. 

Patrick Dorow Productions strives to support local non-profit organizations. By partnering with a new organization during every production, we hope to raise both awareness and funding for their mission. With our community focused, quality-driven approach, our goal is to enrich the lives of our patrons, casts, crew members, students, and community by creating and sharing exceptional artistic experiences.

story:
Antonia Arts, Inc.

Hello, are you an artist? We at Antonia Arts believe that the world is our theater, and we are the players and creators. We create our own lives, and art is how we express it. We are Antonia Arts and we are all artists, too.

Antonia Arts is a not-for-profit 501(c)(3) arts organization based in the city of Peekskill, NY. Antonia Arts, created by Scarlett Antonia, is dedicated to educating, collaborating, and leading the community in expressing their diversity and creativity through art.

Our Value

Antonia Arts has continuously brought classic plays and musicals to life with the help of our community and fellow art lovers. Antonia Arts also always welcomes new voices, new audiences, and new works. This organization is not only valuable because it helps bring art and culture to Peekskill, but we teach the ideals that expression and collaboration contribute to real life traits that are essential to learn.

We believe in building leaders with our classes, not followers.

 At Antonia Arts we use the theater arts as our tool in order to express:

  • collaboration
  • creativity
  • leadership
  • organization
  • planning
  • problem solving

Your contributions will help this organization further spread these values. 

Our Goals:

  • To raise start up money to help us develop in our new location (925 South Street Peekskill NY)
  • Be able to offer classes in acting, dancing, writing, and producing through Antonia Arts Academy (teaching all ages and abilities) in order to execute our values.
  • Raise funds for props, costumes, set designs, and equipment for future performances.
  • Raise funds for our annual WizFest, a festival held in the spring with a Wizard of Oz theme, honoring L. Frank Baum, author of the original Wizard of Oz (food, entertainment, and art to be provided)
  • Start up funds for a summer camp where kids can learn, write, produce, and act in original plays created by students.
  • Raise funds for general operating costs.
Our minimal goal is $7,500 which we believe can help contribute to initial operating costs and our upcoming project - a rendition of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "South Pacific" (to be held at the Hudson Valley Paramount in Peekskill February 12-14, 2016). 
Your contribution to Antonia Arts will  bring theater, art, leadership, creativity, and knowledge to the community. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need a minimum of $7,500, but have hopes for more funds. All profits will go directly in to running Antonia Arts, expanding expressionism, creativity, and art for this community.
  • We encourage donors to donate any sum of money they can afford - all donations are tax deductible according to Federal Law
  • Any amount donated will get promotional recognition
  • We will be offering perks such as pens, tee shirts, hats, cups, recognition on our youtube page/facebook page, and recognition in play's programs varying on donation amount.
  • If we do not reach our entire goal all of the contributions will still go in to the organization’s plays and classes. This company is public and for the people, and we ensure all funds are going directly in to creating art. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out! Tell others about our campaign!
  • Share our facebook page! - Antonia Arts (facebook.com/antoniatheaterarts)
  • Like us on instagram - AntoniaArtsInc
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you!

story:
Science Fiction for the Stage...

What We Do:
The Navigators seek to produce new science fiction inspired theater with a clear feminist slant. We seek to engage new audiences, realize new and daring realities, and expand the boundaries of what theater can achieve through science fiction based story telling.

Who We Are:
The Company was founded in 2013, when three unique theater artists, Bella Poynton, Ariel Francoeur, and Melina Neves came together during their studies at The University of Iowa. The team worked on a number of sci-fi plays by Bella, and uncovered a true passion for genre inspired theater.

The Navigators hope to create a new paradigm for the kinds of narratives that excite us: Exploring new futures, new characters, and new stories yet unseen on stage!

Why Indiegogo:
We want to bring high quality science fiction theater to New York City. Our goal is to promote work with with strong female roles, while also employing female directors, and producing female playwrights. To do this, we need your financial support. 

The Navigators Team

Bella Poynton - Playwright, Science Fiction Scholar and Artistic Director

Ariel Francoeur - Director Extraordinaire and Resident Star Trek Enthusiast

Melina Neves - Company Actor, Dramaturg, and Deep Space Explorer

Matt Barbot - Marketing Director, Playwright, and Alien Conspiracy Specialist

Jesse Kane Hartnett - Guest Director and Artificial Intelligence Expert

Our 2016 Seaon

In addition to our Iowa based productions of The Aurora Project and Speed of Light, the Navigators produced a successful Festival of new sci-fi plays, The Lift Off New Play Series, in New York City last summer. Our Second Annual Lift-Off New Play Series will kick off our first official season. 
The Season will Include
  • The Second Annual Lift-Off New Play Series (Summer, 2016)
  • A brand new, full length sci-fi play (Announced in Spring 2016. Production in Fall, 2016). 

Expenses

Theater is a labor of love, but also an expensive endeavor. We believe in the power of Theater to change lives, and enrich cultural experiences. We also believe in the power of Science Fiction to draw powerful metaphors to the significant social and cultural issues of our time. Here is exactly what we will be using your generous contributions for:

  • Venue Rental
  • Sets/Props/Costumes
  • Paying Actors
  • Paying Designers
  • Paying Stage Managers
  • Marketing and Advertisement
  • Other Expenses


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign with your friends! (Especially the ones who love sci-fi!)
  • Follow us on facebook, twitter, and our beautiful website listed below.
  • Contact us through the website if you would like to be involved artistically in our season!
  • Send us your one-act sci-fi plays! (please visit our website for more information)
www.navigatorstheater.com

https://www.facebook.com/navigatorstheater 

https://twitter.com/_TheNavigators_

story:
"Something Inside is Broken" is a courageous success story of the Nisenan Tribe of Northern California, through the frontier of Sutter's reign on the Sacramento Valley.

This dynamic nonfictional musical is based on the survival of the once largest thriving California Tribe. It has become the beautiful romance on the tragic tale that pillaged 95% of it's population. The strong 5% has now branched out to the 7th generation of survivors ready to share their story with the world. 

Together, combining sources with local organizations, sponsors, and supporters, we are in the process of creating and finishing an artistic, story-telling, musical rock-opera of what happened (from the native perspective) during the years of 1838 to the Gold Rush. A moment in history that changed the lives of our descendants for years to come. We will showcase a story of resilience created by Alan Wallace, music composed by Goodshield Aguillar and Jack Kohler (On Native Ground), Musical Arrangement by Simon' Wilson, a script written by Jack Kohler, and support from Artists: Stan Padilla (Placer Arts), J Ross Parrelli (Universal Music Group Artist),  Auburn Hip Hop Congress, Beats Lyrics Leaders, and many other local artists and organizations. We are at a turning point where we need to call on the support and help of family and the community, the ones who are really affected by our history.


WE NEED YOUR HELP!!!! 

Funding for arts programs are extremely low. as a matter of fact.  "Less than 1/100ths of 1% of philanthropy and foundation dollars goes towards Native American artists". 

This is where we need your help.. There are rewards that you can find right here ---> find something that fits your heart in the amount that you can afford to give.. This is more than a production, it is a preservation of a language that is fading fast here on our very own land. 

"It is an honor and blessing when we, as a people, can impact a community in such a way, that it brings us not only together as humans, but allows for an organic healing to take place. In this present moment we are scripted to make a decision where the impact of history can remain silenced and within our small group of older more sophisticated Indians and families, or it can be told to inspire growth, change, and most important - healing. Our next generation is at the forefront of loosing a part of history, unknown to the general population, about the effects and perspective of settlers and gold miners, death, slavery, and OUR untold story. We face the risk of loosing a native tongue that once held so dear to this community. We face a generation that would be disconnected to the very roots that made their genetic imprints. 

We also face a pivoting moment and hopeful dream to bare the knowledge, strength and spirituality wrapped in the tongue of  the Nisenan language, spoken by our grandparents, alive and moving, to remain at the forefront of our teachings and knowledge". 


OUR TEAM 

On Native Ground is an award winning successful collaboration of storytellers who share a common vision in creating documentaries, television shows, feature films and musicals of relevance to our current society.  We are a Hoopa tribal non-profit  corporation whose mission is to promote positive visibility to Native Americans and Indigenous filmmakers, artists and leaders in the community. On Native Ground provides opportunities in media, filmmaking, citizen journalism, social networking and development of tribal-media infrastructures.   www.onnativeground.org 

Alan Wallace is presenting at the Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian in DC,  celebration of the Maiduan stories from Northern California through song, painted arts, storytelling, and interactive story learning. Sharing his in-depth knowledge in storytelling, tradition, medicine, love, and history.  Alan's passion is to tell the true story of survival and resilience  of his ancestors, that allowed him to be here today, to lead us on this musical journey.

 http://www.nmai.si.edu/calendar/?trumbaEmbed=date%3D20160227#/?i=1


Jack Kohler is an award winning film maker, actor and musician who graduated from Stanford University with an engineering degree, but followed his dream as a storyteller and media producer.  He is a Hoopa tribal member and his tribe was greatly impacted by the 1850's gold rush along the Trinity River. He teaches multi-media courses in film making and drama, and is the Director of "On Native Ground." Jack has been composing music since high school.  He has been mentoring native students for the past 15 years on film making and broadcast journalism. His first collaboration with Alan Wallace was "K'ina kil: The Slaver's Son," which has garnered many awards. Other films include: "River of Renewal" "Once We Had A River" "On Native Ground: Television Series" "Sovereign's Water" "Joseph's War Pony" "My Sunset Girl" and many others.  Jack has also won the Eagle Spirit Award from the American Indian Film Institute.  He portrayed 'Tecumseh' for 5 years in the Equity production of "Tecumseh, the Outdoor Drama" and 'Hump' in the World premiere of "Honor Song for Crazy Horse" for TheaterWorks Silicon Valley.


Stan Padila honors his Yaqui ancestors. He is immersed in traditional native learning and life ways. Stan is a multi-media artist, author, educator and social activist who’s disciplines include drawing, painting, and silversmithing.

J Ross Parrelli is BEATS LYRICS LEADERS Sultry songstress turned community cultivator. Parrelli has spoken and performed at youth leadership conferences all over the globe. Her interest in education-reform led her to co-found Beats, Lyrics, Leaders through which she is developing Hip Hop based curriculum now being piloted in schools, foster youth programs, and on native reservations. www.beatslyricsleaders.com

Simón Wilson is a young composer, producer, vocalist, and pianist currently residing in Santa Rosa, CA. He comes from a family of musicians and has been playing piano, guitar, and singing since age 9. He graduated from UC Santa Cruz with a B.A. in Music, an emphasis on Vocal Performance, and a minor in Economics. Since then, he has been actively collaborating with other artists to produce music for dance, film, poetry, musical theater, and video games. Simón is always trying to diversify his talents as a composer and enjoys working on many different kinds of projects.

Auburn Hip Hop Congress uses music, art and hip hop culture to bring a community of all ages and backgrounds together in positive and meaningful ways. This is done through the creation of youth programs, community outreach and service, artist development, cultural awareness and quality events. www.auburnhiphopcongress.com 

Timeline:

Production of  "Something Inside is Broken" begins in January, with a presentation by the end of Spring 2016, with a full running production by Fall of 2016 to tour from Los Angeles to Washington DC.  

Host auditions for actors and actresses beginning in January 2016 (TBD) 

Host auditions for musicians by mid February 2016

Begin rehearsals on the last weekend of January through to early March

Present the production in late March. 


Goals

We have the opportunity to teach an unheard perspective on California history,  and since this knowledge holds our faith and beliefs so deeply, we are asking for any and all support you can help with funding our program and ideas. Not only does it benefit all the individuals involved, whom will feel the direct healing from talking about such an epidemic, but it will also benefit everyone who gets to witness this musical performance and production. Our goal is to start by performing this production entitled "Something Inside is Broken" with our full cast at a local College and University, and ultimately spread this across the nation like a California Wildfire. 

Join us in celebrating, healing, and building a positive impact in the people and environment we call home.  Your donation will be a non-profit charitable donation to ‘On Native Ground’ whom administers the funding. All of 'On Native Ground's' staff are volunteers, so all of the funding goes towards the production.

For further questions contact:     Alan Wallace at alanwallace3@gmail.com / 530-852-2329 or Jack Kohler at jack@onnativeground.org / 707-592-9030

Who said What?

Thar's gold in them thar hills! so went the cry of the prospectors from Sutter's Mill in the Gold Rush of 1848, but in "Something Inside is Broken," you learn that the gold predated the prospectors, and the Nisenan and their stories had been there for millennia. Now is our chance to honor the true treasures. Language is the essence of being human -- it tells us who we are, allows us to meet the sky, pours words into the river that has no banks -- voila! What Alan Wallace and the team are doing for the Nisenan is the very model of how a language can survive. 

- Bob Holman, filmmaker and host of Language Matters (2015 Documentary of the Year, Berkeley Film Festival)
story_txt:
"Something Inside is Broken" is a courageous success story of the Nisenan Tribe of Northern California, through the frontier of Sutter's reign on the Sacramento Valley. 
This dynamic nonfictional musical is based on the survival of the once largest thriving California Tribe. It has become the beautiful romance on the tragic tale that pillaged 95% of it's population. The strong 5% has now branched out to the 7th generation of survivors ready to share their story with the world. 
Together, combining sources with local organizations, sponsors, and supporters, we are in the process of creating and finishing an artistic, story-telling, musical rock-opera of what happened (from the native perspective) during the years of 1838 to the Gold Rush. A moment in history that changed the lives of our descendants for years to come. We will showcase a story of resilience created by Alan Wallace, music composed by Goodshield Aguillar and Jack Kohler (On Native Ground), Musical Arrangement by Simon' Wilson, a script written by Jack Kohler, and support from Artists: Stan Padilla (Placer Arts), J Ross Parrelli (Universal Music Group Artist),  Auburn Hip Hop Congress, Beats Lyrics Leaders, and many other local artists and organizations. We are at a turning point where we need to call on the support and help of family and the community, the ones who are really affected by our history.

WE NEED YOUR HELP!!!! 
Funding for arts programs are extremely low. as a matter of fact.  "Less than 1/100ths of 1% of philanthropy and foundation dollars goes towards Native American artists". 
This is where we need your help.. There are rewards that you can find right here ---> find something that fits your heart in the amount that you can afford to give.. This is more than a production, it is a preservation of a language that is fading fast here on our very own land. 
"It is an honor and blessing when we, as a people, can impact a community in such a way, that it brings us not only together as humans, but allows for an organic healing to take place. In this present moment we are scripted to make a decision where the impact of history can remain silenced and within our small group of older more sophisticated Indians and families, or it can be told to inspire growth, change, and most important - healing. Our next generation is at the forefront of loosing a part of history, unknown to the general population, about the effects and perspective of settlers and gold miners, death, slavery, and OUR untold story. We face the risk of loosing a native tongue that once held so dear to this community. We face a generation that would be disconnected to the very roots that made their genetic imprints. 
We also face a pivoting moment and hopeful dream to bare the knowledge, strength and spirituality wrapped in the tongue of  the Nisenan language, spoken by our grandparents, alive and moving, to remain at the forefront of our teachings and knowledge".
