story:
What It Is

“Of the woman came the beginning of sin and through her we all die” is a dynamic new play about the dangers of commercializing millennial femininity, written by Lily Houghton and directed by Kylie Brown, and co-produced with Leigh Honigman and Normal Ave at the Medicine Show Theatre in October 2019.

  • We seek to continue the conversation around privilege, capitalism, and the social codes and messaging a woman+ receives living in today's world.

  • We hope to inspire others to create and produce their own work through the production of this play, and your donations will encourage and support the uplifting of young, femme-identifying voices.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're looking to raise funds to pay our artists and collaborators on this world premiere production, implement production design, engage with our audience through extra programming and activities, and spread the word about this femme led world premiere production!
  • We've got discounts at femme & nonbinary led businesses, merch, advance tickets, personal perks like a monologue from our playwright or a coaching session from our director, and more!

The Impact

  • Your donations will help pay our artistic and production team, implement our production design, create programming opportunities around the play for our audience, and increase engagement around this world premiere play.
  • As a group of emerging women theater-makers, we want to encourage others in our position to create and produce their own work.
  • We want to pay our artists in money, not exposure!
  • The play deconstructs the idea of a "safe space" to examine if and how we can avoid hierarchizing pain in these spaces as well as reconciling the ownership of privilege, a conversation which couldn't be more relevant today.

Who We Are

  • Lily Houghton (Playwright)​ ​is a twenty-three year old playwright born and raised in Manhattan. She wrote her first play at age seventeen before completing her B.A. in theater and clinical psychology with a minor in literature at Bennington College. Her plays have been developed at MCC Theater Company, The Flea, EST/Youngblood, NYU, 20% Theater Company Chicago, Yale University’s Writers’ Conference, Bennington College, University of Michigan Theater Conservatory, and the Jermyn Street Theatre in London. Shorts include NEXT (Serials, The Flea) Be Gentle with my Heart (Asking for Trouble, EST/Youngblood), The Interesting Girl (EST/Youngblood), and someone/something/someone/something (EST/ Youngblood) which just won a Sloan Foundation Grant. Lily's play, Dear, received a PlayLab with MCC Theater in the fall of 2017. This Spring she received the Elizabeth George Grant through a new play commission from Seattle Repertory Theater. She is a proud member of the Obie winning Youngblood writers group and the Flea Theater writers group.
     
  • Kylie M. Brown (Director)​ ​is a Brooklyn-based director of new work and literary manager for Normal Ave. She is currently curating the NAPseries of new work for Normal Ave. Recent directing projects: Dead Meat by Paige Zubel, little lives by Shara Feit (Furnace Festival, G45 Lightbulb series), Of the Woman Came the Beginning of Sin and through her we all die by Lily Houghton (EST Bloodworks), What We Made: Gone Missing Lobby Project (The Civilians/City Center Encores! Off-Center), and Painting Faye Salvez by Rachel Covey (NYMF, Northwestern). Short plays and readings with EST/Youngblood, 7x7, Two Headed Rep. As an assistant/associate director, she has worked with Liesl Tommy, Leigh Silverman, and Lear Debessonet, among others. Notable projects include Eclipsed, Privacy, and most recently assisted Leigh Silverman for the first fully female/non-binary creative team on Broadway for Lifespan of a Fact.
  • Leigh Honigman (Producer)​ is a multidisciplinary Brooklyn-based producer interested in breaking down social taboos and mental health stigma. She received her B.S. in psychology from Fordham University. Recent theatre productions include American Juggalo (Vital Joint), The Ugly Kids (2018 Fresh Fruit Festival at The Wild Project), Gain! (Sportslab NYC) and Phantom of the Paradise in Concert (The Secret Loft). Recent film credits include ANNIVERSARY (dir. Tina Makharadze), the upcoming Saltines! (dir. Alley Leinweber), and SLUT - The Web Series (dir. Madi Van Dam).
     
  • Normal Ave (Producer) exists as a shared desire to bring theatre to New York audiences that is socially relevant and emotionally stimulating. In New York City, we are gifted with an array of source material: the many different lives that coexist on 13 miles of an island. Normal Ave provides fresh, accessible, high-caliber programming that reflects the drive of the New York Community that we are rooted in. We are here to create to an artistic hub for up-and-coming, likeminded artists in the early stages of their careers. By giving them a space to work, we encourage and empower our actors, playwrights, directors and designers to discover their unique voice, collaborate with new storytellers, and explore what it means to break molds and redefine normal.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute right now? That's okay! Getting the word out about this brand new production helps us immensely. Share us on facebook or follow us on Instagram!

Interested in working with us, or providing an in-kind donation? Please reach out to ofthewomanplay@gmail.com.
story_txt:
What It Is
“Of the woman came the beginning of sin and through her we all die” is a dynamic new play about the dangers of commercializing millennial femininity, written by Lily Houghton and directed by Kylie Brown, and co-produced with Leigh Honigman and Normal Ave at the Medicine Show Theatre in October 2019.

We seek to continue the conversation around privilege, capitalism, and the social codes and messaging a woman+ receives living in today's world.
We hope to inspire others to create and produce their own work through the production of this play, and your donations will encourage and support the uplifting of young, femme-identifying voices.


What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise funds to pay our artists and collaborators on this world premiere production, implement production design, engage with our audience through extra programming and activities, and spread the word about this femme led world premiere production!
We've got discounts at femme & nonbinary led businesses, merch, advance tickets, personal perks like a monologue from our playwright or a coaching session from our director, and more!


The Impact

Your donations will help pay our artistic and production team, implement our production design, create programming opportunities around the play for our audience, and increase engagement around this world premiere play.
As a group of emerging women theater-makers, we want to encourage others in our position to create and produce their own work.
We want to pay our artists in money, not exposure!
The play deconstructs the idea of a "safe space" to examine if and how we can avoid hierarchizing pain in these spaces as well as reconciling the ownership of privilege, a conversation which couldn't be more relevant today.

Who We Are


Lily Houghton (Playwright)​ ​is a twenty-three year old playwright born and raised in Manhattan. She wrote her first play at age seventeen before completing her B.A. in theater and clinical psychology with a minor in literature at Bennington College. Her plays have been developed at MCC Theater Company, The Flea, EST/Youngblood, NYU, 20% Theater Company Chicago, Yale University’s Writers’ Conference, Bennington College, University of Michigan Theater Conservatory, and the Jermyn Street Theatre in London. Shorts include NEXT (Serials, The Flea) Be Gentle with my Heart (Asking for Trouble, EST/Youngblood), The Interesting Girl (EST/Youngblood), and someone/something/someone/something (EST/ Youngblood) which just won a Sloan Foundation Grant. Lily's play, Dear, received a PlayLab with MCC Theater in the fall of 2017. This Spring she received the Elizabeth George Grant through a new play commission from Seattle Repertory Theater. She is a proud member of the Obie winning Youngblood writers group and the Flea Theater writers group. 

Kylie M. Brown (Director)​ ​is a Brooklyn-based director of new work and literary manager for Normal Ave. She is currently curating the NAPseries of new work for Normal Ave. Recent directing projects: Dead Meat by Paige Zubel, little lives by Shara Feit (Furnace Festival, G45 Lightbulb series), Of the Woman Came the Beginning of Sin and through her we all die by Lily Houghton (EST Bloodworks), What We Made: Gone Missing Lobby Project (The Civilians/City Center Encores! Off-Center), and Painting Faye Salvez by Rachel Covey (NYMF, Northwestern). Short plays and readings with EST/Youngblood, 7x7, Two Headed Rep. As an assistant/associate director, she has worked with Liesl Tommy, Leigh Silverman, and Lear Debessonet, among others. Notable projects include Eclipsed, Privacy, and most recently assisted Leigh Silverman for the first fully female/non-binary creative team on Broadway for Lifespan of a Fact.



Leigh Honigman (Producer)​ is a multidisciplinary Brooklyn-based producer interested in breaking down social taboos and mental health stigma. She received her B.S. in psychology from Fordham University. Recent theatre productions include American Juggalo (Vital Joint), The Ugly Kids (2018 Fresh Fruit Festival at The Wild Project), Gain! (Sportslab NYC) and Phantom of the Paradise in Concert (The Secret Loft). Recent film credits include ANNIVERSARY (dir. Tina Makharadze), the upcoming Saltines! (dir. Alley Leinweber), and SLUT - The Web Series (dir. Madi Van Dam). 

Normal Ave (Producer) exists as a shared desire to bring theatre to New York audiences that is socially relevant and emotionally stimulating. In New York City, we are gifted with an array of source material: the many different lives that coexist on 13 miles of an island. Normal Ave provides fresh, accessible, high-caliber programming that reflects the drive of the New York Community that we are rooted in. We are here to create to an artistic hub for up-and-coming, likeminded artists in the early stages of their careers. By giving them a space to work, we encourage and empower our actors, playwrights, directors and designers to discover their unique voice, collaborate with new storytellers, and explore what it means to break molds and redefine normal.

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Can't contribute right now? That's okay! Getting the word out about this brand new production helps us immensely. Share us on facebook or follow us on Instagram!Interested in working with us, or providing an in-kind donation? Please reach out to ofthewomanplay@gmail.com.

story:
LipZinc Theatre Bio

LipZinc Theatre specialise in new writing that is current and provocative; visually stimulating material with a touch of glamour and girl power.

We are interested in taboo subjects and how we can bring them to life on stage. Our work deconstructs identity and the traditional family unit. It puts characters we do not normally see in the theatre at the forefront. We want to raise awareness of social issues through telling stories in particular those of the LGBTQ+ community and women. We work with all ages and genders in order to create a diverse and unique atmosphere in the rehearsal room

 

What We Need & What You Get

- 'Dolly' is premiering in Edinburgh Fringe at TheSpace on the Mile, Venue 39, at 1:15pm everyday from the 21st to the 25th August. 

- The main cost we are facing is accommodation in Edinburgh for our cast and crew of ten, which at this time of year is highly sought after and expensive. We also need to pay the venue rental, which is our second biggest cost. 

- Other costs involved are props, costumes, transport and marketing materials such as flyers, posters and adverts in brochures. 

- If our goal is not reached all funding will still go towards this project and/or future projects of LipZinc Theatre.

- By supporting this project, you are helping a young, unfunded company make its Edinburgh debut. To show our thanks, we are offering a number of exciting perks including a ticket to our warm-up party. Also up for grabs is our unique 'Dolly' badges and limited edition prints! 

- In this economic climate it is very challenging to make art due to the costs involved and little government support, however with this platform, you can help bring our important story to life! 

The Impact

- Anyone who has ever felt misunderstood will relate to this story and leave feeling uplifted. It is an important and moving play that will also make you laugh.

-LipZinc Theatre relies on the kindness of art supporters as we are a young company without government funding. We have successfully produced two shows in the past with the help of indiegogo, 'Daddy was a Boogie Man' and the award-winning 'Mad Cats and Divas' which both premiered in the Galway Fringe. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not donate but still want to get involved then please come to our events and share our updates on social media. 

 Thank you for reading this and for all your support!

story:
Speed Death of the Radiant Child was performed by Warwick University Drama Society in November 2017, in the Warwick Arts Centre temporary venue. The cast and crew consist of first years through to postgraduates, from disciplines as far ranging as Maths, History and International Development. We came together as a company at the beginning of the year and produced a slippery, nuclear piece of theatre that felt like it was over too quickly!

The lovely Ava Davies wrote about the show here:

https://avatalksabouttheatre.wordpress.com/2017...

In February 2018, we were delighted to find out that the production had been selected to be performed in the 2018 National Student Drama Festival in Leicester.

We’re taking an 11 strong cast and crew to the city at the end of March, showcasing it in front of students, graduates and visiting artists from all over the country. 

The festival is a brilliant opportunity for the company in terms of exposure and experience,  but costs do add up. With tickets costing £100 each, accommodation costing £950 for the week in addition to production costs such as props and costume, the total cost for taking the show to the festival is over £3000!
 

Whatever money we make from the crowdfunder will go towards subsidising transport and accommodation costs, and you can get your hands on a load of perks and creations from the show.

story:
What is Almacén 63? 

(Véase la versión en español al final)

Almacén 63 is a multidisciplinary arts space that opened its doors in 2015 under the administration of local dancer and cultural administrator Loaya I. Quesada. Since its inception, Almacén has stood out not only as a venue for artistic creation, collaboration and exploration for local artists from a wide range of disciplines, but also as a center for members of the community to access artistic proposals and explore their own creative potential. This multifaceted space featured classes, workshops, educational and cultural presentations, art exhibitions and movie nights, and served as a stage for performances where people from all walks of Puertorrican society would come to meet up and connect with their bodies and with other people from different age groups and backgrounds.

The space hosted major local companies such as Claroscuro and Taller Teatro Camándula, and was the home base for Nailah Dance Company, which stand out for their technical and artistic caliber, as well as for promoting a cultural dialogue among all levels of society. This versatile venue has also been utilized as a rehearsal space for theater productions and musicians alike, as well as a recording studio and a gallery space for local artists. One of the most significant projects to be born out of this space was the event La Leche, a forum for a new generation of Puertorrican artists to expose their work. In the three years since its creation, Almacén 63 became a vital community space that empowered and fostered creation and dialogue.

In October 2017, as a result of the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria and the socioeconomic challenges facing Puertorricans, Almacén 63’s administration made the decision to close its doors. For those who did not experience it, it is almost impossible to understand in any meaningful way the level of uncertainty, chaos and anxiety caused by Hurricane Maria, which left practically 100% of the island without power service and telecommunications networks, and a high percentage of its residents without potable water or safe access to food or medical services. To this day, about 5% of our island is still without electricity, many traffic lights and streetlights are not functional and thousands of families are facing the difficult decision of moving to the US.

About Me

I am a professional translator and interpreter, bellydancer and writer. In 2009, I left Puerto Rico to pursue a Master’s Degree in translation and interpretation in Monterey, California. Last year, after eight years in the US, I returned to San Juan, excited about finding ways in which I could help my country.

As a young person growing up in the island, I struggled with my desire to pursue art as a serious occupation and find the means to support myself financially and be able to help my family. In the environment where I grew up, there was a dearth of spaces for cultural and artistic exploration and training, in particular for those of us who could not afford private lessons.

Even though I have been successful in my profession, I have always needed art in my life. However, the narrative that art is not a stable source of income, that it is not to be taken seriously, has been ingrained in me and in those around me since we were children. I believe that having a safe space where we can foster artists is key to developing the artistic potential of the next generations.

Since I was a teenager, I dreamt of opening an arts space to bring together artists from many disciplines to teach and create, a place where I could give others what I didn't have growing up: access, encouragement and support for those dreaming of a career in the arts. I always thought it would take decades to cultivate this, but Hurricane Maria surprised us all, and it surprised me with this unique opportunity to make my dream come true way ahead of schedule. For all the above reasons, I made the decision of purchasing the space and continuing with the work begun in 2015.

What We Need

The funds raised through this campaign will allow us to rehabilitate the space with everything it needs to reopen its doors:

-dance/stage floor

-lighting system

-fans/AC system (it gets really hot in there)

-dance floor mirrors

-furniture (desks, dressing room mirrors and lights, seating/chairs, storage)

-paint

-miscellaneous repairs

-recording studio setup

The Impact

Today more than ever, as we live in the midst of an unprecedented political and financial crisis, there is a need to build community spaces that allow us to cultivate artistic creation in the island. Art is and always will be a tool that allows us to imagine other worlds, connect with other ideas and imagine that which seems impossible from our everyday lives.

Upon reopening, Almacén 63 will be registered as a non-profit organization, allowing it to apply for state and federal funding, accept private donations for its ongoing projects and grant scholarships to provide access to classes and supplies for disadvantaged people.

Risks & Challenges

The Puertorrican economy has certainly seen better days. Hurricane Maria dealt a deathly blow to our vulnerable power infrastructure on September 20th, 2017. As previously mentioned, even six months after the hurricane, about 5% of the population still lacks power service. Flying into San Juan Airport, you can see hundreds of blue tarps covering people's roofs. It is estimated that between 100,000 to 200,000 people have left the island, and more leave every day, which represents an alarming level of brain drain and a severe loss for our economy. Yet some of us have decided to stay —or return— in order to rebuild.

I believe in my country. I returned with a tiny seed of a vision to do something, because it's up to us, not some unspecified other, to create the community we want to see. Since I returned to Puerto Rico less than a year ago, I have met lots of creative and extremely talented people that fire up my imagination and inspire me with their ideas. These visionaries are very knowledgeable, have a lot to offer and yet are very humble. I truly believe these people are my country's hope for a better future. It begins with a place where they can come together and collaborate. Almacén 63 provided such a safe space for artists and for the community to interact with art, and we need that space once again.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute monetarily, I totally get it. Here are some other ways you can help!

  • Spread the word! Your community is also your wealth. All those friends and followers you've gathered on Facebook, Instagram and elsewhere could maybe help us. Send them a link to the campaign and ask them to donate.
  • Have a skill we could maybe use? Let us know in a message (on our Facebook page or by email at info@almacen63.com) and we'll figure out a way to make it work! We need all the help we can get recreating the amazing arts space that was Almacén 63 before closing.

What You Get

Depending on your contribution level, you may receive corresponding perks. Perks are still being finalized, but they will include stickers, t-shirts and art prints with a cool kickass design. Stay tuned for more details and be sure to follow us on Facebook! We’ll be posting more details about the perks really soon!

What Is Crowdfunding?

“Crowdfunding” refers to a fundraising mechanism to collect funds for an initiative, project or product through the Internet and social media.

This financing model allows people to become donors in order to allow the initiative to take place by donating money and generally receiving in-kind rewards.

--ESPAÑOL--

¿Qué es el Almacén 63?

Almacén 63 es un foro multidisciplinario que abrió sus puertas en el 2015 bajo la dirección de la bailarina y administradora cultural local Loaya I. Quesada. Desde sus inicios, el Almacén se ha desempeñado no solo como sede de creación artística, colaboración y exploración para artistas locales de diversas disciplinas, sino también como un centro que permite a la comunidad que lo rodea acceder a propuestas artísticas y explorar su propia capacidad creativa.  En este versátil espacio se ofrecían clases de baile, talleres de artes escénicas y funciones de música a los cuales acudían personas de todos los sectores de la sociedad puertorriqueña para congregarse y conectarse con su cuerpo y con otras personas de distintas edades y clases sociales.

El Almacén acogió a importantes compañías locales como Claroscuro y Taller Teatro Camándula, y sirvió de sede para Nailah Dance Company, las cuales se destacan por su calibre técnico y artístico, así como por promover el diálogo cultural entre todos los ámbitos de la sociedad. Este multifacético foro también se ha utilizado como espacio de ensayo para producciones teatrales y grupos musicales, así como estudio de grabación y espacio de exposición de artistas locales. Uno de los proyectos más significativos nacidos de este espacio fue el evento La Leche, un foro para que una nueva generación de artistas puertorriqueños exponga su arte. En los tres años desde su creación, el Almacén 63 se convirtió en un baluarte de la comunidad que facilitaba y fomentaba la creación y el diálogo.

En octubre de 2017, a raíz de la devastación ocasionada por el huracán María y los grandes retos socioeconómicos a los que se enfrentaban todos los puertorriqueños, la gestora toma la decisión de cerrar las puertas del Almacén 63. Para quien no lo vivió, se hace casi imposible entender de forma cabal el nivel de incertidumbre, caos y ansiedad que produjo el huracán María, el cual dejó a prácticamente el 100% de la población sin servicio eléctrico y sin redes de telecomunicación, y a un alto porcentaje de habitantes sin servicio de agua potable ni acceso seguro a alimentos o servicios médicos. Al día de hoy, aproximadamente un 5% de la isla todavía carece de servicio eléctrico, muchos semáforos y postes de alumbrado público permanecen sin funcionar y miles de familias se enfrentan a la difícil decisión de mudarse a los Estados Unidos.

Quién soy

Soy traductora e intérprete profesional, bailarina de bellydance y escritora. En 2009, me fui de Puerto Rico para cursar una maestría en traducción e interpretación en Monterey (California). El año pasado, después de ocho años en EE. UU., regresé a la isla, entusiasmada con poder encontrar maneras de ayudar a mi país.

De joven, mientras crecía en Puerto Rico, tuve muchas dificultades para reconciliar mi deseo de dedicarme seriamente a una carrera artística y tener los medios para mantenerme económicamente y poder ayudar a mi familia. En el ambiente en el que me crié, escaseaban los espacios de exploración y educación cultural y artística, en particular para aquellos que no podíamos costear clases privadas.

A pesar de que he tenido éxito en mi profesión, siempre he necesitado el arte en mi vida. Sin embargo, la narrativa de que el arte no es una fuente estable de ingresos, de que no se debe tomar en serio, es algo que se nos ha inculcado a mí y a los que me rodean desde que éramos niños. Mi creencia es que disponer de un espacio seguro donde podamos acoger al artista resulta clave para el desarrollo del potencial artístico de las próximas generaciones.

Desde que era adolescente, he soñado con abrir un espacio artístico para reunir a artistas de muchas disciplinas donde estos puedan enseñar y crear, y un lugar donde pueda darles a otros lo que yo no tuve de joven: acceso, aliento y apoyo para aquellos que sueñan con una carrera en las artes. Siempre pensé que me tomaría décadas cultivar este sueño, pero el huracán María nos tomó a todos por sorpresa, y me sorprendió a mí con esta oportunidad única de hacer mi sueño realidad mucha antes de lo previsto. Por todo esto, tomé la decisión de comprar el Almacén y continuar con la labor iniciada en 2015.

Qué necesitamos

Los fondos recaudados a través de esta campaña nos permitirán rehabilitar el Almacén con todo lo que necesita para reabrir sus puertas:

-piso de baile/escenario

-sistema de luces

-ventiladores/sistema de aire acondicionado (hace mucho calor allí)

-espejos para el piso de baile

-muebles (escritorios, espejos y luces de camerino, asientos/sillas, almacenamiento)

-pintura

-reparaciones misceláneas

-creación del estudio de grabación

Impacto

Hoy más que nunca, mientras vivimos una crisis política y financiera sin precedentes, existe una necesidad de forjar espacios comunitarios que nos permitan fomentar el quehacer artístico en la isla. El arte es y siempre será una herramienta que nos permite imaginar otros mundos, conectarnos con otras ideas y vislumbrar aquello que nos parece imposible desde nuestra cotidianidad.

Tras reabrir sus puertas, el Almacén 63 se registrará como organización sin fines de lucro, lo cual nos permitirá solicitar fondos estatales y federales, así como aceptar donaciones privadas para futuros proyectos y otorgar becas a fin de brindar a las personas menos privilegiadas acceso a clases y materiales.

Riesgos y desafíos

La economía puertorriqueña ha visto mejores tiempos. El huracán María supuso un golpe mortal para nuestra vulnerable infraestructura eléctrica ese 20 de septiembre de 2017. Como ya se mencionó, aún a seis meses del huracán, aproximadamente 5% de la población carece de servicio eléctrico. Al llegar al aeropuerto de San Juan, se pueden ver desde el avión cientos de toldos azules que cubren los techos de las casas. Se calcula que entre 100,000 y 200,000 personas se han ido de la isla, y muchas más se van cada día, lo cual representa un nivel alarmante de fuga de cerebros y una grave pérdida para nuestra economía. No obstante, algunos hemos decidido quedarnos —o regresar— a fin de reconstruir.

Yo creo en mi país. Regresé con la semillita de una visión de hacer algo, porque depende de cada uno de nosotros, no de cualquier otra persona, crear la comunidad que queremos ver. Desde que regresé a Puerto Rico hace menos de un año, he conocido a muchísimas personas creativas y sumamente talentosas que encienden mi imaginación. Son visionarios con mucho conocimiento que tienen mucho que ofrecer y que, sin embargo, son personas sumamente humildes. Yo de verdad creo que estas personas son la esperanza de mi país para un mejor futuro. Todo comienza con un lugar donde puedan encontrarse y colaborar. El Almacén 63 proporcionaba ese lugar seguro para que los artistas y la comunidad interactuaran con el arte, y lo necesitamos de nuevo.

Otras formas de ayudar

Si no puedes hacer una aportación monetaria, lo entiendo perfectamente. ¡Hay otras formas de ayudar!

  • Haz correr la voz. Tu caudal también incluye a tu comunidad. Todos esos amigos y seguidores que has acumulado en Facebook, Instagram y las demás redes quizás puedan ayudarnos. Envíales el enlace de la campaña y pídeles que donen.
  • ¿Tienes una destreza que podríamos necesitar? Háznoslo saber enviándonos un mensaje (por Facebook Messenger o por correo electrónico a la dirección info@almacen63.com) y encontraremos la forma de hacer que funcione. Necesitamos toda la ayuda posible para recrear el increíble foro artístico que era el Almacén 63 antes de cerrar.

Qué recibirás a cambio

Dependiendo del nivel de tu donativo, podrías recibir una recompensa. Aún estamos finalizando las recompensas, pero incluirán calcomanías, camisetas y arte impreso con un fabuloso diseño que te encantará. Mantente atento a más detalles, ¡y procura seguirnos en Facebook! Muy pronto publicaremos más detalles sobre las recompensas.

¿Qué es el “crowdfunding”?

El término “crowdfunding”, o “financiación colectiva”, se refiere a un mecanismo de recaudación de fondos para una iniciativa, proyecto o producto por medio del Internet y las redes sociales.

Mediante este modelo de financiación, las personas se convierten en donadores para la realización de la iniciativa, al aportar dinero y generalmente recibir a cambio recompensas en especie.

One of the most significant projects to be born out of this space was the event La Leche, a forum for a new generation of Puertorrican artists to expose their work. In the three years since its creation, Almacén 63 became a vital community space that empowered and fostered creation and dialogue.
In October 2017, as a result of the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria and the socioeconomic challenges facing Puertorricans, Almacén 63’s administration made the decision to close its doors. For those who did not experience it, it is almost impossible to understand in any meaningful way the level of uncertainty, chaos and anxiety caused by Hurricane Maria, which left practically 100% of the island without power service and telecommunications networks, and a high percentage of its residents without potable water or safe access to food or medical services. To this day, about 5% of our island is still without electricity, many traffic lights and streetlights are not functional and thousands of families are facing the difficult decision of moving to the US.
About Me
I am a professional translator and interpreter, bellydancer and writer. In 2009, I left Puerto Rico to pursue a Master’s Degree in translation and interpretation in Monterey, California. Last year, after eight years in the US, I returned to San Juan, excited about finding ways in which I could help my country.
As a young person growing up in the island, I struggled with my desire to pursue art as a serious occupation and find the means to support myself financially and be able to help my family. In the environment where I grew up, there was a dearth of spaces for cultural and artistic exploration and training, in particular for those of us who could not afford private lessons.
Even though I have been successful in my profession, I have always needed art in my life. However, the narrative that art is not a stable source of income, that it is not to be taken seriously, has been ingrained in me and in those around me since we were children. I believe that having a safe space where we can foster artists is key to developing the artistic potential of the next generations.
Since I was a teenager, I dreamt of opening an arts space to bring together artists from many disciplines to teach and create, a place where I could give others what I didn't have growing up: access, encouragement and support for those dreaming of a career in the arts. I always thought it would take decades to cultivate this, but Hurricane Maria surprised us all, and it surprised me with this unique opportunity to make my dream come true way ahead of schedule. For all the above reasons, I made the decision of purchasing the space and continuing with the work begun in 2015.
What We Need
The funds raised through this campaign will allow us to rehabilitate the space with everything it needs to reopen its doors:
-dance/stage floor
-lighting system
-fans/AC system (it gets really hot in there)
-dance floor mirrors
-furniture (desks, dressing room mirrors and lights, seating/chairs, storage)
-paint
-miscellaneous repairs
-recording studio setup
The Impact
Today more than ever, as we live in the midst of an unprecedented political and financial crisis, there is a need to build community spaces that allow us to cultivate artistic creation in the island. Art is and always will be a tool that allows us to imagine other worlds, connect with other ideas and imagine that which seems impossible from our everyday lives.
Upon reopening, Almacén 63 will be registered as a non-profit organization, allowing it to apply for state and federal funding, accept private donations for its ongoing projects and grant scholarships to provide access to classes and supplies for disadvantaged people.
Risks & Challenges
The Puertorrican economy has certainly seen better days. Hurricane Maria dealt a deathly blow to our vulnerable power infrastructure on September 20th, 2017. As previously mentioned, even six months after the hurricane, about 5% of the population still lacks power service. Flying into San Juan Airport, you can see hundreds of blue tarps covering people's roofs. It is estimated that between 100,000 to 200,000 people have left the island, and more leave every day, which represents an alarming level of brain drain and a severe loss for our economy. Yet some of us have decided to stay —or return— in order to rebuild.
I believe in my country. I returned with a tiny seed of a vision to do something, because it's up to us, not some unspecified other, to create the community we want to see. Since I returned to Puerto Rico less than a year ago, I have met lots of creative and extremely talented people that fire up my imagination and inspire me with their ideas. These visionaries are very knowledgeable, have a lot to offer and yet are very humble. I truly believe these people are my country's hope for a better future. It begins with a place where they can come together and collaborate. Almacén 63 provided such a safe space for artists and for the community to interact with art, and we need that space once again.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute monetarily, I totally get it. Here are some other ways you can help!

Spread the word! Your community is also your wealth. All those friends and followers you've gathered on Facebook, Instagram and elsewhere could maybe help us. Send them a link to the campaign and ask them to donate.
Have a skill we could maybe use? Let us know in a message (on our Facebook page or by email at info@almacen63.com) and we'll figure out a way to make it work! We need all the help we can get recreating the amazing arts space that was Almacén 63 before closing.

What You Get
Depending on your contribution level, you may receive corresponding perks. Perks are still being finalized, but they will include stickers, t-shirts and art prints with a cool kickass design. Stay tuned for more details and be sure to follow us on Facebook! We’ll be posting more details about the perks really soon!
What Is Crowdfunding?
“Crowdfunding” refers to a fundraising mechanism to collect funds for an initiative, project or product through the Internet and social media.
This financing model allows people to become donors in order to allow the initiative to take place by donating money and generally receiving in-kind rewards.
--ESPAÑOL--
¿Qué es el Almacén 63?
Almacén 63 es un foro multidisciplinario que abrió sus puertas en el 2015 bajo la dirección de la bailarina y administradora cultural local Loaya I. Quesada. Desde sus inicios, el Almacén se ha desempeñado no solo como sede de creación artística, colaboración y exploración para artistas locales de diversas disciplinas, sino también como un centro que permite a la comunidad que lo rodea acceder a propuestas artísticas y explorar su propia capacidad creativa.  En este versátil espacio se ofrecían clases de baile, talleres de artes escénicas y funciones de música a los cuales acudían personas de todos los sectores de la sociedad puertorriqueña para congregarse y conectarse con su cuerpo y con otras personas de distintas edades y clases sociales.
El Almacén acogió a importantes compañías locales como Claroscuro y Taller Teatro Camándula, y sirvió de sede para Nailah Dance Company, las cuales se destacan por su calibre técnico y artístico, así como por promover el diálogo cultural entre todos los ámbitos de la sociedad. Este multifacético foro también se ha utilizado como espacio de ensayo para producciones teatrales y grupos musicales, así como estudio de grabación y espacio de exposición de artistas locales. Uno de los proyectos más significativos nacidos de este espacio fue el evento La Leche, un foro para que una nueva generación de artistas puertorriqueños exponga su arte. En los tres años desde su creación, el Almacén 63 se convirtió en un baluarte de la comunidad que facilitaba y fomentaba la creación y el diálogo.
En octubre de 2017, a raíz de la devastación ocasionada por el huracán María y los grandes retos socioeconómicos a los que se enfrentaban todos los puertorriqueños, la gestora toma la decisión de cerrar las puertas del Almacén 63. Para quien no lo vivió, se hace casi imposible entender de forma cabal el nivel de incertidumbre, caos y ansiedad que produjo el huracán María, el cual dejó a prácticamente el 100% de la población sin servicio eléctrico y sin redes de telecomunicación, y a un alto porcentaje de habitantes sin servicio de agua potable ni acceso seguro a alimentos o servicios médicos. Al día de hoy, aproximadamente un 5% de la isla todavía carece de servicio eléctrico, muchos semáforos y postes de alumbrado público permanecen sin funcionar y miles de familias se enfrentan a la difícil decisión de mudarse a los Estados Unidos.
Quién soy
Soy traductora e intérprete profesional, bailarina de bellydance y escritora. En 2009, me fui de Puerto Rico para cursar una maestría en traducción e interpretación en Monterey (California). El año pasado, después de ocho años en EE. UU., regresé a la isla, entusiasmada con poder encontrar maneras de ayudar a mi país.
De joven, mientras crecía en Puerto Rico, tuve muchas dificultades para reconciliar mi deseo de dedicarme seriamente a una carrera artística y tener los medios para mantenerme económicamente y poder ayudar a mi familia. En el ambiente en el que me crié, escaseaban los espacios de exploración y educación cultural y artística, en particular para aquellos que no podíamos costear clases privadas.
A pesar de que he tenido éxito en mi profesión, siempre he necesitado el arte en mi vida. Sin embargo, la narrativa de que el arte no es una fuente estable de ingresos, de que no se debe tomar en serio, es algo que se nos ha inculcado a mí y a los que me rodean desde que éramos niños. Mi creencia es que disponer de un espacio seguro donde podamos acoger al artista resulta clave para el desarrollo del potencial artístico de las próximas generaciones.
Desde que era adolescente, he soñado con abrir un espacio artístico para reunir a artistas de muchas disciplinas donde estos puedan enseñar y crear, y un lugar donde pueda darles a otros lo que yo no tuve de joven: acceso, aliento y apoyo para aquellos que sueñan con una carrera en las artes. Siempre pensé que me tomaría décadas cultivar este sueño, pero el huracán María nos tomó a todos por sorpresa, y me sorprendió a mí con esta oportunidad única de hacer mi sueño realidad mucha antes de lo previsto. Por todo esto, tomé la decisión de comprar el Almacén y continuar con la labor iniciada en 2015.
Qué necesitamos
Los fondos recaudados a través de esta campaña nos permitirán rehabilitar el Almacén con todo lo que necesita para reabrir sus puertas:
-piso de baile/escenario
-sistema de luces
-ventiladores/sistema de aire acondicionado (hace mucho calor allí)
-espejos para el piso de baile
-muebles (escritorios, espejos y luces de camerino, asientos/sillas, almacenamiento)
-pintura
-reparaciones misceláneas
-creación del estudio de grabación
Impacto
Hoy más que nunca, mientras vivimos una crisis política y financiera sin precedentes, existe una necesidad de forjar espacios comunitarios que nos permitan fomentar el quehacer artístico en la isla. El arte es y siempre será una herramienta que nos permite imaginar otros mundos, conectarnos con otras ideas y vislumbrar aquello que nos parece imposible desde nuestra cotidianidad.
Tras reabrir sus puertas, el Almacén 63 se registrará como organización sin fines de lucro, lo cual nos permitirá solicitar fondos estatales y federales, así como aceptar donaciones privadas para futuros proyectos y otorgar becas a fin de brindar a las personas menos privilegiadas acceso a clases y materiales.
Riesgos y desafíos
La economía puertorriqueña ha visto mejores tiempos. El huracán María supuso un golpe mortal para nuestra vulnerable infraestructura eléctrica ese 20 de septiembre de 2017. Como ya se mencionó, aún a seis meses del huracán, aproximadamente 5% de la población carece de servicio eléctrico. Al llegar al aeropuerto de San Juan, se pueden ver desde el avión cientos de toldos azules que cubren los techos de las casas. Se calcula que entre 100,000 y 200,000 personas se han ido de la isla, y muchas más se van cada día, lo cual representa un nivel alarmante de fuga de cerebros y una grave pérdida para nuestra economía. No obstante, algunos hemos decidido quedarnos —o regresar— a fin de reconstruir.
Yo creo en mi país. Regresé con la semillita de una visión de hacer algo, porque depende de cada uno de nosotros, no de cualquier otra persona, crear la comunidad que queremos ver. Desde que regresé a Puerto Rico hace menos de un año, he conocido a muchísimas personas creativas y sumamente talentosas que encienden mi imaginación. Son visionarios con mucho conocimiento que tienen mucho que ofrecer y que, sin embargo, son personas sumamente humildes. Yo de verdad creo que estas personas son la esperanza de mi país para un mejor futuro. Todo comienza con un lugar donde puedan encontrarse y colaborar. El Almacén 63 proporcionaba ese lugar seguro para que los artistas y la comunidad interactuaran con el arte, y lo necesitamos de nuevo.
Otras formas de ayudar
Si no puedes hacer una aportación monetaria, lo entiendo perfectamente. ¡Hay otras formas de ayudar!

Haz correr la voz. Tu caudal también incluye a tu comunidad. Todos esos amigos y seguidores que has acumulado en Facebook, Instagram y las demás redes quizás puedan ayudarnos. Envíales el enlace de la campaña y pídeles que donen.
¿Tienes una destreza que podríamos necesitar? Háznoslo saber enviándonos un mensaje (por Facebook Messenger o por correo electrónico a la dirección info@almacen63.com) y encontraremos la forma de hacer que funcione. Necesitamos toda la ayuda posible para recrear el increíble foro artístico que era el Almacén 63 antes de cerrar.

Qué recibirás a cambio
Dependiendo del nivel de tu donativo, podrías recibir una recompensa. Aún estamos finalizando las recompensas, pero incluirán calcomanías, camisetas y arte impreso con un fabuloso diseño que te encantará. Mantente atento a más detalles, ¡y procura seguirnos en Facebook! Muy pronto publicaremos más detalles sobre las recompensas.
¿Qué es el “crowdfunding”?
El término “crowdfunding”, o “financiación colectiva”, se refiere a un mecanismo de recaudación de fondos para una iniciativa, proyecto o producto por medio del Internet y las redes sociales.
Mediante este modelo de financiación, las personas se convierten en donadores para la realización de la iniciativa, al aportar dinero y generalmente recibir a cambio recompensas en especie.

story:
Summary

Seven Starving Artists is a new, emerging Canadian theatre company in Calgary, Alberta with a passion for telling new stories that give the underrepresented a voice. Producing All That's Left will not only contribute to Canada's theatre culture, but will also allow our company to begin to make a name for itself. This play will not be possible without your help to raise these funds, and we appreciate any and all donations you can make!

What We Need 

Here is a general breakdown of our expenditures:

  • $1100 facility rental fee
  • $500 damage deposit (refundable)
  • $200 production costs 
    • Costumes, set, makeup, etc.
  • $75 marketing
  • $60 insurance
  • Small honorariums of $50 to $75 for all artists involved 
    • Director and Assistant Director
    • Stage Manager and Assistant Stage Manager
    • Set, Costume, Lighting, and Sound Designers
    • Six actors

The Impact

Art is the lens through which we understand and view our experiences; we believe in the importance of queer theatre and of seeing yourself represented on stage. All That's Left is about processing and healing from the communal trauma and violence that the LGBTQ+ community faces as part of our daily reality. We hope that this production will help to build connections among the community and its allies in Calgary.

All That's Left has had two successful workshops so far, the first through the University of Lethbridge's TheatreXtra, and the second through Sage Theatre's IGNITE! Festival for Emerging Artists

Risks & Challenges

Starting a new theatre company and producing a new and unknown play will always be risky- we know that there is always the chance that we won't be able to find an audience for our work. We are prepared to market actively and invest our own money into this project as necessary. 

Queer theatre can also be challenging, particularly in Southern Alberta; that's why we plan to reach out to local LGBTQ+ programs and organizations for their connections and support. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out about All That's Left by sharing this campaign, and be sure to buy tickets to attend the production this July!

story:
My name is Cai Brigden. I graduated from the Guildhall school of music and drama in 2011 and now work as a professional actor in Theatre, Film and Television.

For the last couple years, I have been involved with Soho Theatre's SYC  - writing and performing Sketch and Stand Up Comedy.

Now I’ve written a brand new play called Entropy, about Love and Quantum physics. The aim of this campaign is to raise funds needed to premiere the play in Edinburgh. 

Entropy is unique in that it deals with Love from the perspective of Quantum Physics, exploring scientific concepts such as chaos and uncertainty, and their place within human relationships.


The plot involves a physicist on the brink of being able to explain the mysteries of the universe, but he still can’t figure out his volatile relationship with a rising star. In his struggle to grasp answers, he begins to lose his grip on everything.
A volatile hour of clashes and kisses: Entropy is a war of head vs heart and logic vs impulse.
It's funny, sad, and thought provoking.

SO FAR...

I am thrilled to have teamed up with The Space Venues in Edinburgh and to be performing at the Perth Theatre, on Northbridge - a charming 50 seater venue that is perfect for our piece.
The folks at The Space have offered us a wealth of information about everything from marketing strategies and technical help, to industry contacts, deadlines and affordable Edinburgh accommodation.

Onboard so far are:

David Kirkbride - Director
We have enlisted the sharp, energetic directorial mind of David Kirkbride who also trained at Guildhall.
David has been directing and assistant directing since the age of 15 when he started creating theatre shows. He was the Assistant Director of the Arden Theatre Company from 2003-7. Then helped create Vivid Theatre Company from 2007-2010.

He has continued to work and direct shows for The Vaults, The Caravan, Newcastle Theatre Royal, Arc, Richmix and the Union Theatre including various schools, colleges and universities.

Producers
Two actor parents and a film maker sister have put forward the money to help us book the venue and get this ball rolling.
This campaign is asking for your help to create a quality production and  promote the show extensively.

What we are asking for, here, is your help in making this production into a SUCCESS. We want to create a production that people will SHOUT about.

WHAT WE NEED

Here are the areas in which your donations can make this happen!

ACTORS
A brilliant cast could deliver this play to a high standard. However, acting is a profession and talented actors can only deliver their best if they aren’t worrying about rent or their next meal.
We want to pay our Actors £300 a week. It’s not a huge amount, but this will enable us to secure a talented, dedicated cast that can put their full focus on making this play special. 

ADVERTISING
Flyers, posters and press interviews will help make this production take off. That’s why we see advertising as a huge priority.
£400 will pay for Flyer & Poster design and distribution. Any money we raise beyond that will go towards PR and professional media coverage such as newpapers or radio.

REHEASALS
Allowing the company time to tackle the depth and complexity of the play will help us enormously in delivering this story. We need a space to rehearse in London for a full working week.

TRAVEL + ACCOMODATION
This may seem like a luxury to some, but this is probably the part I am most scared of. We have a booking on a 4 bedroom flat (3 actors and the Director) that will cost us £1000 for the entire stay. We think that’s a great price… but we can't actually pay for it yet.
Putting a roof over the company’s head would REALLY improve the quality of this show. Please help!

COSTUMES
Costumes are a vital part of theatre and story telling. Not only do costumes help the audience understand characters, they also help actors portray and develop them.
This is a contemporary play, and we will endeavour to source costumes from family, friends, and charity shops. The more of a budget we have here, the faster we can find the perfect wardrobe for this piece.

SET + PROPS
Entropy is set in a London flat that has been designed to look reminiscent of the 1920s-1930s. There is a degree of Nostalgia about the set that is integral to the story.
As part of the set we hope to source: a sofa, a coat stand, two free standing stage doors, a chair, carpets, a small coffee table, a drinks cabinet with glasses and decanters, another chair, a stool, and a telescope.
We will beg for & borrow what we can, but any money raised to help us source these items responsibly would be tremendous. Help us build the world of the play!

We have great perks for every catagory so please do have a look below and help us out!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't donate anything, please share our cause and it'll mean the world to us!
Find us on twitter @EntropyPlay

 

ITEMS & REWARDS:

ETERNAL THANKS - Our gratitude for any donations will resonate until long after the heat death of the universe.

MENTION AS BACKER - You’ll be put down in our  programme as backer.

SHOW FLYER - You will receive an official flyer from our show in Edinburgh. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company.

REHEARSAL PHOTOS - You will receive a pack of images of the company during our rehearsal process. See what we get up to and how your money has helped. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company.


FREE PROGRAMME - You will receive a free copy of our official programme from our Edinburgh production. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company.

INVITE TO REHEARSED READING - You will be invited to an exclusive rehearsed reading of Entropy, in London. Don’t worry about dates - if you can’t make it, we'll endevour to find a date you can. If you aren’t able to come to London, we’ll send you a video/recording with a thank you message from us!


FREE TICKET TO SHOW - If you can’t make it to Edinburgh, we’ll put you at the top of our list for future performances in London.


PERSONAL THANK YOU VIDEO - We, the company, will record a very special thank you message just for you, to show our gratitude for your generous contribution!

PRESS PACK - This pack includes Flyers x 2, Official Entropy Media Image x 1, Free Programme x 1 and Rehearsal Images. Choose whether you’d like them signed by the company.

COPY OF SCRIPT - As a thank you for your contribution, we will send you an exclusive copy of Entropy, as it exists in it’s final draft before opening in Edinburgh. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company!

DRINKS WITH CAST - Come and join us for a drink and a laugh. You can meet us in London, or catch us after a show in Edinburgh. Don’t be shy, we can’t wait to say thank you for helping us!

REFERENCE WITHIN PLAY - We will leave a little “easter egg” within the production as a commemoration of your outstanding contribution! A little refrence to you will remain in the play forever. We will be in touch to discuss how best to implement this unique perk!

60-90 PAGE ORIGINAL PLAY - Ever had an idea that you never got around to writing? You needn’t worry! With this perk, Cai Brigden will write you a 60-90 page play. You’ll get to discuss your idea in detail, and have it turned into a real theatre script! Once the 1st draft is complete, you will be entitled to another 4hrs of consultation and up to 4 redrafts to bring your idea to life. On top of this, you will maintain 100% ownership of the play and any creative rights.

SHOW FLYER - You will receive an official flyer from our show in Edinburgh. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company.
REHEARSAL PHOTOS - You will receive a pack of images of the company during our rehearsal process. See what we get up to and how your money has helped. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company.
FREE PROGRAMME - You will receive a free copy of our official programme from our Edinburgh production. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company.
INVITE TO REHEARSED READING - You will be invited to an exclusive rehearsed reading of Entropy, in London. Don’t worry about dates - if you can’t make it, we'll endevour to find a date you can. If you aren’t able to come to London, we’ll send you a video/recording with a thank you message from us!
FREE TICKET TO SHOW - If you can’t make it to Edinburgh, we’ll put you at the top of our list for future performances in London.
PERSONAL THANK YOU VIDEO - We, the company, will record a very special thank you message just for you, to show our gratitude for your generous contribution!
PRESS PACK - This pack includes Flyers x 2, Official Entropy Media Image x 1, Free Programme x 1 and Rehearsal Images. Choose whether you’d like them signed by the company.
COPY OF SCRIPT - As a thank you for your contribution, we will send you an exclusive copy of Entropy, as it exists in it’s final draft before opening in Edinburgh. Choose whether you’d like it signed by the company!
DRINKS WITH CAST - Come and join us for a drink and a laugh. You can meet us in London, or catch us after a show in Edinburgh. Don’t be shy, we can’t wait to say thank you for helping us!
REFERENCE WITHIN PLAY - We will leave a little “easter egg” within the production as a commemoration of your outstanding contribution! A little refrence to you will remain in the play forever. We will be in touch to discuss how best to implement this unique perk!
60-90 PAGE ORIGINAL PLAY - Ever had an idea that you never got around to writing? You needn’t worry! With this perk, Cai Brigden will write you a 60-90 page play. You’ll get to discuss your idea in detail, and have it turned into a real theatre script! Once the 1st draft is complete, you will be entitled to another 4hrs of consultation and up to 4 redrafts to bring your idea to life. On top of this, you will maintain 100% ownership of the play and any creative rights.

story:
ABOUT THE ARTIST 

Victor Morales is a Venezuelan Artist based in New York City since 1991. He completed a Master’s degree in Technology Applied to the Arts at New York University's Gallatin Division, in 1992. He is a director, performer and designer, whose work includes video animation and design, text, sound design, and digital puppetry. His work has travelled the world and he has collaborated with international artist such as Chris Kondek (Berlin), Joseph Silovsky (NYC), Jim Findlay (NYC), Findlay/Sandsmark (Norway), Joachim Schloemer (Germany), Wolfgang Mitterer (Austria) among others. He is Currently the Digital Technical Director at 3 Legged Dog in NYC.

Since 2003, Victor has been obsessed with the art of video game modifications and has implemented different game engines into most of the works he has produced. His solo work consists of an exploration of video game engines as simulation environments, where death and physics are transformed into dramatic and comedic real time performance.

ABOUT THE PROJECT

Esperpento is a virtual space, inspired on the aesthetic vision of Spanish painter Francisco Goya. Specifically the War Paintings and his famous, Caprichos.

The project is a universe where tragedy, sarcasm, and comedy are portrayed as a deformed and apocalyptic mirror of reality; In this world, circumstance is the source of tragedy, and the grimace produced by this tragedy is what rules its form.

Esperpento is an exploration about the rejection of the different and the dehumanization of the stranger. Why the foreigner (who looks different) is often shunned, despised and criminalized?

This virtual universe will work primarily as an immersive interactive installation and performance its first iteration will take place on the all Fall of 2018 at 3 Legged Dog Art and Technology Center in NYC.

Esperpento (a Spanish literary term for “monstrosity”) is a digital performance event - a charged visual performance that allows the viewer to see through a monstrous lens. Rather than using the “monster” to critique societal ills, Esperpento embraces strangeness and deformity in order to challenge conventions of beauty, familiarity, and what is “normal” or “native” to the human condition.

Esperpento is a series of 3D digital events which explores the dehumanization of the stranger. In a vivid sequence of natural and manmade disasters, rendered through a real-time video game engine, victims and perpetrators collide with increasingly interchangeable ethnic, class and cultural markers. These "Esperpento Events" are a digital meditation on the rejection of foreignness, and why we shun those who look (or appear to look) different from the people in the US.

Goya’s War Disasters and Black Paintings are, in substance and form, a template for Esperpento. These paintings are a testament of genuine protest, full of style and piercing opinion, that simultaneously document and comment on reality.

The performance aspect of Esperpento is a play written by Billy Burns called “Two Black Lights and One Red”. The play is a free adaptation from a Spanish play “Luces de Bohemia” by Valle-Inclan. The show is about the vicissitudes of a blind Poet, Max Starpower,  who suffers through his blindness and the economic hardships of the “Esperpento” world. “Two Red Lights and a Red One" is a full-on digital puppetry extravaganza, utilizing new techniques specially developed for the show. It will be delivered by performers and 2 puppeteers. We are happy to announce that “Max Starpower” will be played by the great “Flako” Jimenez!

The Latino community and other minorities will be the main focus group for this production. The technology and the delivery of the animations are the major points for connection with these communities, basically promoting technology made by and for Latinos.

 

What We Need & Where Does the Money Go? 

  • Artists (Creator + Writer + Animators + Performers) 
  • Software Programmers
  • Equipment
  • Space
  • System Development 

We firmly believe in paying our Artists so that they can produce the highest quality of work and give the audience an experience they will not forget. This is the first time that this concept and script will be developed for live performance devised with live actors, voice, and music. 

A majority of the funds raised will also go to the development of the necessary systems required to run the show such as motion controllers, camera tracking techniques,  sound reactive technology, and much more.

This unique experience in both the installation and performance requires time and space to dig deeper into Esperpento's core. By donating you will give us access to space, equipment, and resources. 

 

By Donating To This Project You Will Support: 

  • Diversity in the Arts + Technology Development 
  • Immigrant Empowerment 
  • Community Creation 
  • Digital Performing Arts

The traditional animations will be a marketing tool for the VR animations and the Live Performance. These animations will create an impact since they are simulations of catastrophes using different avatars representing different groups of people: minorities, ethnicities, and gender. The live performance will have large sections in Spanish and will be a highly technical show, Our marketing will be aimed at the Latino community and tech sectors to promote the idea of minorities working with technology.

The Latino community and other minorities will be the main focus group for this production. The technological part of the show and the animations is the major point for connection with these communities, basically promoting technology made by and for Latinos.

 

Other Ways You Can Help :)

BUY A TICKET
You can buy a ticket for the installation and/or the performance through the link below: 

 

INSTALLATION  

Dates: September 4th - October 28th Tuesday - Thursday 2 pm - 6 pm 

 

PERFORMANCE

Dates: October 5th - October 28th Friday - Sunday 7:30 pm - 8:30 pm

 

SHARE THIS LINK
Share our Indiegogo on your social media and/or via email with your friends and family! 

LIKE OUR PAGE
Like our page on Indiegogo and Facebook 

SPEAK UP 
Start the conversation with your friends and family about unrepresented people. Ask them the question - Why the foreigner (who looks different) is often shunned, despised and criminalized?

Thank you so much for your love and support! 
We greatly appreciate your contribution!

story:
Greetings Future Supporters

Thank you for taking time to consider supporting us in our new endeavor. We were extremely saddened by the closure of Patrick Dorow Productions (PDP), and knew immediately that we wanted to be able to continue to work with the students who were enriching our lives each day. This fundraiser is our attempt to continue the work that we were doing with the youth and teens of the seacoast area. Funds raised will be used to secure a space to hold both classes and, hopefully, performances. Time is of the essence as we don't want to miss working with these incredibly talented students. 

We both strongly believe the seacoast area is home to some of the most talented and professional youth and teen performers we have ever seen. These students work passionately to produce performaces that rival those of adult, professional actors. We have seen them all grow and thrive through theatre and hope to be able to give them a home to continue to do so with us. 

Please help us continue this important work. Every dollar helps and no amount is too small... or large for that matter!

We thank you for your support and look forward to starting this new chapter with you. 

Joe and Rachel

story:
Our Show, in threes, is a collaboration of trios created by choreographers Alison Daley, Miles Gosse and Tracey Norman. Each of the three works is coming from a place of depth and curiosity in its continued development. Alison Daley's trio is stemming from a short duet she began in the fall of 2017 (on Justine Comfort and Niko Markakis) exploring the physicalization of communication styles, which was presented in an informal setting as part of an event pairing musicians and choreographers. This process assisted her in clarifying her interest in researching communication in a larger sense and exploring listening as a key element involved in the act of communicating. Tracey Norman's conceptual idea is new, however she has been developing working with this group of collaborators over the past year as she has built her 15 minute work from last summer's Fringe Festival into a full length work with the same cast for her April 2018 production. Developing an understanding of "how" to work with each of them has influenced and inspired her current interest in this trio.  Miles Gosse's choreography is premiere piece looking at the manipulation and physicalization of memories. 

The Fringe gives us an opportunity to take risks artistically while not risking it all financially-speaking. It provides a great platform for the emerging artists of Half Second Echo (Justine Comfort, Miles Gosse and Denise Solleza) and guest Oriah Wiersma. People need to see more dance and we're offering a highly physical and thought-provoking performance with concepts and content that hold currency.

Fundraising Goals 

We need your help to cover the costs of: 

  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Costumes/Props
  • Print Material/Marketing
  • Artists'/Choreographers/Stage Crew Fees
  • Travel and Accommodation 

About the Team

All 6 of the main cast of performers and choreographers are emerging and mid-career artists who are all graduates of York University (both BFA and MFA programs). Additionally, our Stage Manager/Lighting Designer, Kiera Shaw, is our most recent York grad. There is something special about this connection and we represent different generations of this program coming together. We are at different stages of our careers so there is some mentorship happening naturally through the process.

The performers, Half Second Echo, are a collective of very different dancers with different strengths, backgrounds, ethnicities, identifications, and bodies. Often what brings a collective together are the things that are similar about them while in this case it's the differences that make them compelling together. The resulting dance work for this show relates to dismantling ignorance, discrimination, isolation and barriers, and the wildness and erotic experience of being human.

Julia Sasso is our outside eye on this creation project. She has worked with Tracey Norman for several years as her outside eye and she has a relationship with all of the artists involved. We trust her implicitly and appreciate how she challenges and supports us as creators and collaborators. There is a natural three-tier mentorship model involved in our project with three generations of dance artists. This multi-generational dialogue will allow for tremendous growth of all involved.

If you can't contribute... 

Don't worry! Keep your eyes and ears peeled for both our Montreal and Toronto Fringe Festival Dates. We will also keep you updated on other shows that we have going on within the GTA at the same time. Try to come out to one of our shows or share one of our events with some friends. Any social media love that we can get will go a long way!

With Love,

Alison Daley, Tracey Norman & Half Second Echo
