story:
MAGNET THEATRE is one of South Africa’s best known independent physical theatre companies that has been operating in and outside of South Africa for the past 31 years. In March 2019, we were recognized by the  provincial Western Cape Government  with an award for outstanding contribution to Arts and Culture in the Drama category.

Magnet Theatre runs the only suite of bridging programmes in theatre arts for unemployed youth in the Western Cape.   The programme responds to the national crisis of youth unemployment. In South Africa,  52%  of young people between the ages of 15 and 24 are jobless. Magnet Theatre's Full- time Training and Job Creation Programme attempt to caplitalise on the creative potential of our youth, ensuring that they have access to education and employment.

The objectives of the  Full- time Training and Job Creation Programme are to:

  • Provide a bridge to tertiary education; 
  • Provide a bridge to employment;
  • Skill marginalized youth so they can create their own income generating projects;
  • Meaningfully occupy young people’s time;
  • Transform the theatre industry into one that is more inclusive and representative of all South Africans.

The beneficiaries of the programme include:

  • Unemployed youth from previously disadvantaged areas with limited resources and no perceived access to tertiary arts education. 
  • Young people who are battling the harsh socio-economic realities of unemployment, gangsterism, high levels of crime, violence against women, HIV/Aids, alcoholism, and teen-age pregnancies.

It costs Magnet Theatre  7,000 USD (100,000 ZAR) per student for 2 years study on the Full Time Training and Job Creation Programme.

We are trying to raise  3,500 USD (50,000 ZAR)  for  each of 10 trainees for 2020 – the first year of  6th cohort of the  2 year Full-time Training and Job Creation Programme. 

    The Magnet Theatre training programme was originally designed by Professor Mark Fleishman (Artistic Director and Managing Trustee) (BA, Perf. Dip in Speech and Drama, UCT; MA. UCT, PHD UCT); Jennie Reznek (Artistic Director and Trustee) (BA Perf. Dip in Speech and Drama, UCT; Ecole Jaques Lecoq, Paris; MA, UCT); and Mandla Mbothwe (Artistic Director and Trustee) (BA Perf. Dip in Speech and Drama, UCT; MA, UCT; PhD Candidate, UCT). The classes are taught by highly experienced theatre practitioners and teachers and specifically incorporate modules which prepare youth from the Cape Town townships/flats to either further their studies at university level; join the creative economy by being professionally employed at Magnet Theatre or other institutions as performers, teachers, facilitators and directors; or create registered entities that are established to support their own income generating projects.

    According to 2018 tracking,

    • 98% of our graduates are either employed or self-employed in the creative industry or furthering their studies
    • 7 registered NPOs, 1 trust and 1 closed corporation have been established by graduates
    • Magnet has been instrumental in facilitating access for 31 first generation university attendees; of these 16 have graduated, 6 are still studying, 5 began studies in 2019 with 3 furthering their studies at a post-graduate level
    • Graduates have toured professionally to Hong Kong, Germany, Dubai, India, USA, UK, Italy, Australia, Japan, China, Spain, Canada, Belgium, France, Reunion Island, Sweden and Russia.
    • 9 trainees won awards in the 2019 professional Fleur Du Cap Theatre Awards for Best New Director and Best New South African Script (Lwanda Sindaphi) and Best Ensemble for Lwanda Sindaphi's KUDU.

    In order to ensure the continued upskilling of a new 6th cohort of trainees, please donate to this campaign – every contribution, no matter what size, counts. Contributions to the campaign will go towards:

    • A monthly stipend to cover food and transport for each trainee (all the trainees come from economically disadvantaged backgrounds and require support to attend the programme);
    • Skills classes and training modules in voice, movement, dance and singing, physical theatre, theatre making, performing identity and community memory, mime story teller, community theatre, South African, African and world theatre;
    • Theatre tickets and late night transport;
    • Educational support materials;
    • The Magnet Theatre space – Magnet  Theatre has a rented space that we have developed over the years into a 150 seat theatre, ideal for training young people and showcasing their work. It is the home of all Magnet Theatre’s activities including training, administration and performance;
    • Participation in Magnet Theatre community based projects in Clanwiliam and Cape Town townships.

    If the full goal is not reached, Magnet Theatre  will initiate a training with whatever has been donated, whether that means with only half the number of trainees, a half-day programme, or a firm commitment to begin the programme once more funds are raised.

    Should you contribute, you can look forward to:

    • A signed postcard of one of the Early Years works created with the trainees who have graduated ($150)
    • The latest design of the Magnet Theatre t-shirt with our new logo ($350)
    • 4 FREE TICKETS to any one Magnet Theatre Production of your choice in 2019, and your name on the website as a Training Programme Crowdfunding Campaign Donor($750)

    • 4 FREE TICKETS to ALL 3 Magnet Theatre Productions in 2019, your name on the website as a Training Programme Crowdfunding Campaign Donor ($1500)

    • A plaque with your name  mounted on one of the chairs in Magnet Theatre in Observatory, Cape Town, 2 free tickets to opening nights of all Magnet Theatre productions in the future, your name on the website as a Training Programme Crowdfunding Campaign Donor ($3500)

    The programme continues to grow, gaining greater visibility in the townships and Cape flats because of the national and international successes of the graduates. Because of this it seems vitally important that alternative training spaces like Magnet Theatre are maintained.

    Even if you are unable to contribute financially to the campaign, please make sure to help share the campaign across your networks and spread the word!

THE PROJECT

“In the woods where the men work” was just some wacky words on a page until this group of artists joined forces in the Spring of 2018. Thanks to each of these creators, the world of this play came to life and a life-sized ox puppet roamed amidst magnolia trees and television screens, as businessmen moved in choral disharmony amongst the audience. 

THE JOURNEY

Our work garnered us two esteemed recognitions in the Spring of 2018:

1) a short-listing for the Leslie Scalapino Award for Innovative Female Performance Writers

2) The Sherman-Fairchild Grant for Art & Technology, which funded our first production

AND NOW, we have two amazing opportunities to take a huge step forward and share this piece with new and broader audiences in New York City and Prague. 

Our performance venues are SET, all we need is your support to get us there.

WHAT WE NEED

$5,000 FOR NEW YORK WINTERFEST THEATER FESTIVAL

Includes: Festival Participation fee, rehearsal space in NYC, publicity, stipends for cast & crew, production expenses, materials & software (light, set, costume, props, sound)

$7,500 FOR THE INTERNATIONAL PRAGUE FRINGE FESTIVAL 

Includes: Travel expenses (airfare, lodging & food stipend for a 9 person company), performance venue cost, shipping puppet & set, and publicity.

THE IMPACT

Winterfest will grant us:

  • A three-show run at a 96 seat theatre in Chelsea!

  • Our first full production in New York City.

  • The chance to win festival awards in writing, performance, design & production.

The Prague Fringe Festival will offer:

  • A six-show run on the festival’s MAIN STAGE!

  • International exposure & future touring opportunities.

  • The chance to meet & network with other companies.

With YOUR help, we would be able to:

  1. Take a HUGE step forward in our artistic paths with TWO festivals in ONE season.
  2. Mount TWO full runs in front of more than 500 audience members!
  3. The chance to perform in front of industry professionals. 
     

WHAT YOUR DONATIONS WILL PROVIDE

$10 - One hour of rehearsal space in NYC OR our monthly insurance fee.

$25 - Food stipend for one company member for a day in Prague

$50 - Printing 10 posters for NYC or Prague productions

$150 - The cost of renting our sound software for both productions OR the cost of the performance venue for one performance in Prague OR the modest stipend for one performer.

$500 - All production expenses and software for our production in NYC OR one month of rehearsal space in NYC OR the entirety of our marketing & printing expenses for both festivals

$1,000 - The performance venue costs for both productions OR our company's lodging in Prague OR food stipends for half the company in Prague.

$3,000 – Round-trip flights to Prague for the whole company.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand not everyone can donate money. Here are some other ways you can help us:

  1.  Sharing this Indiegogo page with all your millions of friends, you popular stud!
  2. Liking or sharing our Facebook and Instagram with family and friends. Please stalk us.
  3. Visiting and subscribing to our website.
  4. Coming to our performances! We have 3 in NYC in March. Buy tickets here!
  5. If you’re an artist or production-savvy person: HIT. US. UP. Send us an e-mail here.

 

WHY SUPPORT THIS PROJECT?

"In the woods where the men work" was written by Sarah Finn in the Fall of 2017 when Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria were tearing through the Atlantic, and California was (as it continues to be) ablaze. This play is a timely exploration of corporate power amidst global destruction. We have made this piece to examine & challenge our complicity while imagining a world in which justice is possible. 

Your support would allow us to start dialogue with audience on what our responsibility is as individuals in creating a more hopeful and just future for our world.

Thank you for any & all help you're able to provide.

 

All our love & gratitude,

The IN THE WOODS team
story_txt:
THE PROJECT“In the woods where the men work” was just some wacky words on a page until this group of artists joined forces in the Spring of 2018. Thanks to each of these creators, the world of this play came to life and a life-sized ox puppet roamed amidst magnolia trees and television screens, as businessmen moved in choral disharmony amongst the audience. THE JOURNEYOur work garnered us two esteemed recognitions in the Spring of 2018:1) a short-listing for the Leslie Scalapino Award for Innovative Female Performance Writers2) The Sherman-Fairchild Grant for Art & Technology, which funded our first productionAND NOW, we have two amazing opportunities to take a huge step forward and share this piece with new and broader audiences in New York City and Prague. Our performance venues are SET, all we need is your support to get us there.WHAT WE NEED$5,000 FOR NEW YORK WINTERFEST THEATER FESTIVALIncludes: Festival Participation fee, rehearsal space in NYC, publicity, stipends for cast & crew, production expenses, materials & software (light, set, costume, props, sound)$7,500 FOR THE INTERNATIONAL PRAGUE FRINGE FESTIVAL Includes: Travel expenses (airfare, lodging & food stipend for a 9 person company), performance venue cost, shipping puppet & set, and publicity.THE IMPACTWinterfest will grant us:
A three-show run at a 96 seat theatre in Chelsea!
Our first full production in New York City.
The chance to win festival awards in writing, performance, design & production.
The Prague Fringe Festival will offer:
A six-show run on the festival’s MAIN STAGE!
International exposure & future touring opportunities.
The chance to meet & network with other companies.
With YOUR help, we would be able to:
Take a HUGE step forward in our artistic paths with TWO festivals in ONE season.
Mount TWO full runs in front of more than 500 audience members!
The chance to perform in front of industry professionals.  
WHAT YOUR DONATIONS WILL PROVIDE$10 - One hour of rehearsal space in NYC OR our monthly insurance fee.$25 - Food stipend for one company member for a day in Prague$50 - Printing 10 posters for NYC or Prague productions$150 - The cost of renting our sound software for both productions OR the cost of the performance venue for one performance in Prague OR the modest stipend for one performer.$500 - All production expenses and software for our production in NYC OR one month of rehearsal space in NYC OR the entirety of our marketing & printing expenses for both festivals$1,000 - The performance venue costs for both productions OR our company's lodging in Prague OR food stipends for half the company in Prague.$3,000 – Round-trip flights to Prague for the whole company. OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPWe understand not everyone can donate money. Here are some other ways you can help us:
 Sharing this Indiegogo page with all your millions of friends, you popular stud!
Liking or sharing our Facebook and Instagram with family and friends. Please stalk us.
Visiting and subscribing to our website.
Coming to our performances! We have 3 in NYC in March. Buy tickets here!

If you’re an artist or production-savvy person: HIT. US. UP. Send us an e-mail here.
 WHY SUPPORT THIS PROJECT?"In the woods where the men work" was written by Sarah Finn in the Fall of 2017 when Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria were tearing through the Atlantic, and California was (as it continues to be) ablaze. This play is a timely exploration of corporate power amidst global destruction. We have made this piece to examine & challenge our complicity while imagining a world in which justice is possible. Your support would allow us to start dialogue with audience on what our responsibility is as individuals in creating a more hopeful and just future for our world.Thank you for any & all help you're able to provide. All our love & gratitude,The IN THE WOODS team

story:
High school theater that makes you a high school theater fan! 

"I went to my first show (Thoroughly Modern Millie) thinking I was going to see some kids being kids who only wanted to be in the show for the fun of it. However, these young men and women gave it everything they had and it was AMAZING! I left with my jaw on the floor. I would rather pay to watch a show at SEHS than any other venue because I get to support this wonderful program while getting something greater in return. The students never cease to shock me with their ability to draw me in as if I were a part of the show. Support this program and go to every show! I promise it will be worth your while."- Jen Dawson, Parent and Community Member

  

 

 

 

 

If you are an adult who was a "drama kid" yourself, or who has had your offspring experience this strange path, you know that sometimes--at least in high school--the aspiration is higher than the achievement, you've been through your share of, well, "not perfect" shows... But...not at South!

 

This is South Eugene High School Theater.

There is something special about the South Eugene High School Theater program, directed by Pat Avery. The shows they put on feel almost professional. This pre-professional conservatory within a public high school has fostered aspiring actors, lighting, sound, and set designers, and playwrites/directors for years. SET is an amazing gift to the Eugene community, to these public high school students, and ultimately, to the future of theater.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If it's a musical, these students will sing like stars, and their orchestra will NOT hit a bunch of sour notes, but be rich and full. Dancers will inspire you, and stretch to a level that makes you feel it.

 

 

If it's a play, you will not only understand every word from the back row, but you will also feel the characters--being drawn into their emotions, their context, their entire story. You will be enthralled, maybe challenged, and you will come out of the theater changed.

 

Going to Nationals--with award winning One Acts -- Both to inspire others and to be inspired!

South Eugene Theater (SET) has produced three one-act plays which were selected at the Oregon State competition in Salem to represent Oregon at the International Thespian Festival in Lincoln, Nebraska this June. Thirteen members of the SET troupe will be presenting these plays on a stage at the festival:

  1. “Less Than Kind” by junior Elena Freck, Oregon Thespians’ 2017 playwriting champion.
  2.   2nd place winner “Bare Stage” by senior Zack Harris.
  3.  Tennessee Williams’s “The Long Goodbye” , directed by Pat Avery.

These shows have a theme of deeply looking at the challenges and connections of family in an imperfect world. 

What is "Nationals"???  Why do they need to go? 

The International Thespian Festival, also known by the kids as simply "Nationals", is an experience of Theater students from all over the country coming together to share what they do, learn from one another, and gain skills through workshops, classes, clinics taught by professionals in the theater world. 

Here is the description from the festival's website:

"Every summer, thousands of middle school and high school Thespians bring their love of all things theatre to the International Thespian Festival, a celebration of student achievement in the performing arts. Organized by the Educational Theatre Association and hosted at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln, Festival is a one-of-a-kind, weeklong immersion experience in singing, dancing, acting, designing, directing, creating, writing, and memory-making. Festival features workshops presented by theatre professionals, individual and group performances, programs for technical theatre students, and opportunities to audition for college admission and scholarships. Whether you're just beginning your theatrical journey, a seasoned senior with an impressive resume and great headshot, or an educator seeking enriching professional development—the International Thespian Festival has something to offer you! Start planning now! We hope to see you in Lincoln this summer."

The South Eugene Theater program is excellent because of the incredible training and performance opportunities they have at South, but also at these festivals. It is an honor to be chosen to present their one-acts, and that alone is a reason to go, but even more, it is what they will learn, the connections they will make, and even the potential for scholarships to performing arts programs around the country which will help them hone and perfect their craft--and prepare them for even better work in the future. 

For this particular group of students, this is a once in a lifetime chance, and no matter what their future endeavors, they will gain so much!  

More reviews:

Here is what so many people have said on the Public South Eugene Theater Facebook page:

Leslie Anderson Freck · January 24, 2016

This is a thoughtful, dedicated and artistic troupe who go to great pains to create and present consistently excellent productions. They push themselves professionally, beyond the expectations of most high school programs. Highly recommend.

 

Amy Isler Gibson reviewed South Eugene Theater — 5 star

October 16, 2015 · 

Consistently great, risky, fantastically talented theater, year after year after year. My three kids long graduated but we still go!

 

Jennifer Hubbard Geller reviewed South Eugene Theater — 5 star

November 4, 2015 · 

Love the work of this theater! This is no ordinary high school theater department. Consistently, the shows are of professional quality.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

This is a talented, dedicated, and amazing troupe of actors, but this is a public high school on a shoe-string budget, and not all of the students' families can afford to send their young actors on this valuable trip.

Each student's festival cost is $1500, including airfare and other travel expenses, and tuition/room/board for the festival itself. 

Each student's family was asked to complete a permission form, confidentially stating whether they could afford all, half, or none of the cost. Talent comes from all walks of life, and SET wants to make sure nobody is left behind for lack of funds. 

$7500 will be a scholarship fund to allow all who need help.

  • We have already raised $1500 towards this fund, through ticket sales, refreshment sales, and a "1-minute donation spree" at two weekend performances of the three one-acts, and through individual fundraising efforts by the students.
  • That leaves $6000 still to raise. 
  • Because the Indiegogo platform and credit card/Paypal systems take a percentage of the contributions, we are adding $200 to the goal to help cover this cost.

Perks- Tokens of our appreciation for you

While it would be impossible to truly give back what we receive by your generous contribution, we do have a selection of "perks" that you may choose at different contribution levels.

Everything from a postcard from Nebraska, to a poster of one of the SET shows of this past season, to a pair of season tickets to the 2017-18 SET season, if you are in the area, and want to guarantee yourself some great theater that you helped create! 

The Impact - You are helping to fund the Arts and Education!

In this day of reduced funding for the Arts, for Education, and for the things that give our lives meaning, but take money to do, it is even more important to support our youth.

   

You can be part of this!

If you help these students go to Nationals, you will be helping an excellent high school theater department do even more, helping public school students know they are supported in the arts, and helping, maybe, to develop a young actor who just might do something important in the future to change the world!  

 

 

Risks & Challenges

What if we don't reach our goal?  We are determined to leave no one behind. Every dollar you give, even if you ONLY give a dollar, will be one more moment on the stage for a student. ALL money will be used towards the scholarships for students whose families have financial hardships preventing them from being able to simply put this trip on a credit card.

What if we go OVER the goal? 

 That would, of course, be amazing! If we go over the total goal of $7500, then any additional funds will go directly to the South Eugene Theater program for the upcoming year. To produce more student works. To upgrade equipment for lighting and sound and sets. To make better costumes. Anywhere needed.

Other Ways You Can Help

Money is obviously what we need, and even a "tiny" contribution of a few dollars is very welcome. You can use a credit card, or Paypal, to very conveniently do so.  

Strength in Numbers-- 

  • Share the campaign!  
  • Make a commitment to raise $100--100 friends giving $1 each, 50 friends giving $2 each, 20 friends giving $5 each, 5 friends giving $20 each.  You get the idea! Reach out to your community to help this next generation of the performing arts!
  • Use email, Facebook, Twitter FROM this campaign once per day--to increase our "gogo factor"--every time Indiegogo's platform detects that activity has happened from the campaign itself, that raises our campaign to the top of the search engine, so that others can see us and contribute.
  • "Like" the campaign-- Same thing...."gogo factor".
  • Talk to your local businesses-- Is there someone you know who would like to be mentioned in a program in next Fall's musical?  Perhaps have ad space? Ask them to contribute!  
  • Spread the word!  Make little flyers or cards or slips of paper with our campaign info and link on them, explain what it takes to train young actors, tell them about a public high school that is committed to keeping the performing arts in the curriculum and what it is doing.

Thank YOU!!!!

story:
Dear PTW friends, and others in the International Development Community

It is my pleasure to announce that I have been accepted to continue my training as a Dance Therapist at the 92nd Streeet Y in New York City. After being part of the International Class at the East Side Institute, I decided to take the next step. Joining my love of dance with Social Therapy is the realization of that step. Training as a dance therapist will allow me to help with greater precision and passion the thousands of people in Peru and in other parts of the world have been affected by environmental pollution and the effects of climate change.

For several years I have taken a great interest in, and have committed myself to the creation of climate dances. The purpose of this work was to raise awareness of the climate induced ecological problems we face and to prevent these problems. Though satisfying, this work has not been enough. As a teacher I discovered that it is not possible to make changes in humanity, if first we do not help to heal the inner world. I know with all my strength that my reason for existence is to generate deeper changes through dance, but I need your help.

Recently my home country (Peru) has suffered tremendous economic losses and emotional damage due to widespread flooding and the rock slides caused by that flooding. Most hard hit by these losses have been the countless children who have lost their play spaces, have seen their homes destroyed, along with losing their loved ones and animals.

Although I have been selected, and will receive a deduction in the fee for attending this intensive training (3 weeks in New York from June 12 to 30 this year) the costs for transportation, accommodation, food, and other incidental expenses are high. The program itself encompasses a three year process. Beginning in 2018, I will have to engage in clinical work which will mean a longer stay in New York, as will be the case in 2019, which will bring my training to its end.

As you know, Peru is a developing country, marked by poverty and facing tremendous problems due to the natural disasters we are experiencing. This has affected everyone directly and indirectly and makes raising funds here extremely difficult. And so I am turning to my friends in the International development community for help.

To make this all possible, I have created this IndieGogo Campaign so that people who wish to collaborate with me can participate in my project this year.  Since this is a long term project, I will have to make appeals in the upcoming years also.  My sincerest appreciation for all your help.

story:
The Revivalists

Revivalists are those who look to restore important facets of our shared culture.  During the 2017 Philadelphia Neighborhood Fringe Festival, the Revivalists will be presenting UNITED in the courtyard of the historic Betsy Ross House September 9, 15, 16, 22, & 23.  UNITED is a new, immersive musical drawing on stories and songs from American history and folk tradition to challenge audiences to reinvest in our country's founding principles.  We look to revive the experiences of those who chose to forgo the comfort of their day to day lives and engage with the ideals of independence, liberty and and the equality of all Americans.

Where Does My Donation Go?

In order to complete UNITED we need to raise $1,500.  These funds will be used for:

  • Rehearsal and performance space rental:  $850
  • Design elements:
    • Set & props:  $350
    • Lighting:  $150
  • Insurance:  $150

For Me?

We want to ensure that all donors to this production are able to join us for the performance in September! Every $50 donated entitles you, the donor, to one free ticket to Opening Night or another performance of your choosing.  We cannot express enough how grateful we are for your generosity, and we look forward to standing united with you to celebrate our shared liberties during the run of this show!

Challenges of UNITED

Creating a new, original piece that draws on founding American principles requires blending both our unique personal beliefs and found text from American history built on the beliefs of others. This challenges the entire team behind UNITED to build on what makes us unique as people and Americans in order to share the universalities of our Americaness with our audience. Another challenge of UNITED is garnering support for new works of theatre. We are fortunate to build UNITED in Philadelphia, the birthplace of American liberty, among so many other great artists building shows for the Fringe Festival.  We have to do our best to not only stand out, but also support the other artists who are creating in conjunction with UNITED.

Are There Other Ways You Can Help?

Absolutely!  Now, while any donation is greatly appreciated, we understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially.  But you can still help by talking about UNITED!  Word of mouth will go just as far as a donation!  Tell your friends, family, post about UNITED on Facebook, share it, retweet it,  and help us get the message of UNITED to as many people as possible! And come see the show!

story:
Students and Teachers from Rooselvet High School attending Cottonwood in the Flood 2106

VANPORT MOSAIC FESTIVAL 2017

Team Afloat is asking for your support to assure that this year's crowd funder is a success. The generosity of last year's campaign made possible 257 subsidized tickets available to the sold-out play Cottonwood in the Flood by the award-winning playwright Rich Rubin. The success of last year's campaign created important relationships with the public school system and communities across Portland to help the Vanport Mosaic Festival's mission to involve and educate the community to ensure that the Vanport Story of Oregon history is not forgotten.

$4000 make possible: 

  • Free Private Matinee for Public Schools: Your donation will subsidize a free student-only matinee, to support the developing of Vanport-centered curriculum at Portland Public Schools, hosted by Roosevelt and Jefferson High Schools. Featuring two new one-act plays about the American Dream, displacement & Hurricane Katrina from the African American perspective by award winning playwrights Don Wilson Glenn & Michael Jones.
  • Community Outreach: Your donation will subsidize a community outreach plan to underserved schools, churches, and senior centers based in North/Northeast Portland that will encourage their participation in a source of entertainment that isn't normally afforded in their community.
  • Discounted Public Tickets for Seniors and Students: In addition to a free PPS student matinee, your donation will subsidize a significant percentage of heavily discounted tickets available to students and seniors at each public performance.

Your $25 contribution will go to securing 120 tickets for a student or senior to see the stage reading performance at the Interstate Firehouse Cultural Center during the Vanport Mosaic Festival 2017, the cost of production fees for two private student only for the students of Roosevelt and Jefferson High Schools, and our community outreach plan to engage underserve neighborhoods.

AFLOAT 2017 

This year's request for your support is just as worthy to fund. Afloat - two new one-act plays about the American Dream, displacement & Hurricane Katrina from the African American perspective by award winning playwrights American Summer Squash by Don Wilson Glenn & Hercules Didn't Wade in the Water by Michael Jones,

Cast:La’Tevin Alexander, Anthony Armstrong, Arlena Barnes, Kenneth Dembo, Jasper Howard, Eric Island, Rickey Junior, *Anya Pearson, *Seth Rue, Andrea Vernae and Damaris Webb, photo credit Antonio Harris *Courtesy of Actor’s Equity Association

 

 THE VANPORT FLOOD OF 1948

The tragedies of Katrina and Vanport are often referred to as isolated events, in reality they are opportunities to reflect on the similar circumstances that have lead to the disenfranchisement of entire generations of Americans who were displaced before Hurricane Katrina ever made landfall or the levees were breached. 

HURRICANE KATRINA 2005     

About the Plays

AFLOAT the American Dream, Displacement from the African American Perspective

"After hearing accounts from both Vanport and Katrina survivors - I heard them saying the same things-  They felt their country had abandoned them, and they had become excluded from the American Dream... but displacement was the worse, having gone through the worse thing in your life; and still uncertain that the worse isn't over." - Don Wilson Glenn  

American Summer Squash by Don Wilson Glenn

Cast from right to left Jasper Howard, Ricky Junior, Kenneth Dembo, Anthony Armstrong & Damaris Webb, photo by Antonio Harris.

AMERICAN SUMMER SQUASH (directed by Jocelyn Seid) tells the story of a family that have followed their Patriarch, Rev. Ratliff Blount, to his original hometown in rural East Texas to wait out the storm. Homeless like millions of others, Ratcliff now realizes he has been displaced twice: the people of his old hometown are all gone, and with them the Native American culture and language of his youth.

Hercules didn't Wade in the Water by Michael Jones

Cast from right to left standing Kenneth Dembo, La'Tevin Alexander, *Anya Pearson, Eric Island, sitting *Seth Rue and Andrea Vernae, photo credit by Antonio Harris

HERCULES DIDN’T WADE IN THE WATER (directed by Damaris Webb) begins on a rooftop in New Orleans during Hurricane Katrina, where two men are stranded after traveling to the city to find work. As the story unfolds we see the personal and systemic forces that have led them to be so far from home as they cling to life, surrounded by murky water, festered with disease and the unknown literally and metaphorically.

Stage Management: *Jory Bowers & Judith Yeckel,  Costume Design: Wanda Walden, 

Technical Direction: Lara A. Klingeman 

The Vanport Mosaic is committed to offering these new works to Portland audiences as together we grapple with gentrification, homelessness, and the question of what responsibilities are tied to our individual privileges. We look forward to creating dialogue that reflects the diversity of the city, building engaged community and healing discussion.

We thank our project sponsors & funders thus far:

Portland Parks & Recreation 

Ronni Lacroute

The Regional Arts & Culture Council

The Multnomah County Cultural Coalition 

The Oregon Cultural Trust

The Vanport Mosaic is a collective of artists, historians, educators and media makers 

seeking to engage the public in remembering the silenced histories of The Pacific Northwest to better understand our present. 

info@vanportmosaic.org 

*  www.vanportmosaic.org *  971-319...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your donation of any size will be greatly appreciated & We ask you to please share our campaign with friends and family.

Video Credits

Director/Editor: Meredith Lawrence (meredithalawrence.com)

Beatrice Gilmore Interview: Sommer Martin, Richard Percy, Jing Wong, James Burke

Extra Photos: Lara Klingeman,Antonio Harris, FEMA, City of Portland Archives

Music: "Twinkle Twinkle Instrumental" by David Mumford (davidmumfordmusic.bandcamp.com)

Special Thanks to: Beatrice Gilmore

Students and Teachers from Rooselvet High School attending Cottonwood in the Flood 2106

VANPORT MOSAIC FESTIVAL 2017
Team Afloat is asking for your support to assure that this year's crowd funder is a success. The generosity of last year's campaign made possible 257 subsidized tickets available to the sold-out play Cottonwood in the Flood by the award-winning playwright Rich Rubin. The success of last year's campaign created important relationships with the public school system and communities across Portland to help the Vanport Mosaic Festival's mission to involve and educate the community to ensure that the Vanport Story of Oregon history is not forgotten.

story:
We would be stupendously grateful for every single solitary donation. Your contributions will allow us to take this show to more places within the Chicago theatre community and beyond. Our brand of comedy and production quality is perfect for festivals across the country and abroad. In order to send Acme Theatrics out into the wild, we need the financial support to rent vans, buy equipment, and pay our talent. We are professionals, and your donations will keep us growing in a professional capacity.

So why does this matter?

Acme Theatrics performs interactive, immersive variety shows, designed to provide entertainment, catharsis, and immediacy. We want to give you art that is in the moment. Why does that matter? Because Art and comedy are awesome! We at Acme Theatrics want to make that positive impact on as many people as possible. We want to give you a unique experience that you will remember for years to come.

What will my donation do?

Contributions to Acme will help us secure: Licensing, marketing materials, wardrobe, performance space rental, rehearsal space rental, traveling fees, submission fees (ya it costs money to see if you can get a chance to make money), money for our film production team (kidding it’s just one dude named Derek. But he’s super nice and I can’t keep paying him in hugs), and money for our performers and talent. It costs money to produce live theater, plain and simple. Your donations go directly to those production costs first, then making sure the creatives involved in the process see some compensation for their time, talent, and hard work.

What do I get out of it?

Acme’s perks are designed to provide ya’ll with a little bit of love and art. We will create personalized shout-outs, musical jingles, sketches and comedic doodles. If we don’t meet our goal we will use the funds to rent the theater space, licensing and any leftovers towards marketing. Every dollar we make will go toward the production, whether we reach the goal or not.

Why should I care?

People say theater is a dying industry. Overall there are fewer patrons going to the theater and buying tickets. We’ve managed to fill theaters by creating something worth seeing. We’re using our diverse theatrical experiences to create a show that is truly unique and brings people out into the world.

Where/when can I see you perform?

Depending on when you see this, we either have a show coming up Feb 16 & 17 at the Playground Theater in Chicago, or you can catch us next at Electric Forest in Michigan.

Is there anything else I can do (other than give you money)?

Acme needs your help not only with donations but with spreading the word. Go to the highest mountain (or wherever you get wifi) and spread the word! Any sharing via social media, email, or even word of mouth helps.

story:
You wanna know how far a dollar can stretch? Talk with an indie theatre company! We can transport you into a whole new world on very limited funds!

 

Naked Goddess has done just that with every awesome show we have presented! This time around, we would like some help to take our shows to the next level and ensure that our entire creative team gets paid, too!

Naked Goddess is a Jessie award nominated theatre company that presents fabulous shows that audiences love. We love theatre and we know you do, too! It takes a lot to put on a play...from renting a venue to paying for the rights to use the playwright's words to costumes, lighting and set!

That's why we are asking for your help! Those of you who have seen our shows....you know we do good! And those of you who haven't yet...check out www.nakedgoddessproductions.com and learn all about us!

Thank you for your help! Every dolla dolla helps!!!! THANK YOU from the bottom of our naked hearts!!!!!!!!!

story:
Summary of the Dance Film

“Embodying Emily: Death and Letters” is a dance film inspired by the poems and letters written by Emily Dickinson, particularly during the period of 1858-1865. This work is a creative imagining of a moment of self-reflection and illumination by Dickinson. The choreography in particular seeks to examine and to embody the intersection of several of Emily's extraordinary life experiences, including her dynamic emotional states, her heightened intellect, her creative productivity, and her purported mental illness. 

 

Dickinson encapsulated into poems a period of immense personal suffering - a time she referred to in her letters to few as “the terror” - that carried her into a life of near-total isolation. Although she was incredibly productive as a writer during this eight-year period, her sister-in-law Susan H. G. Dickinson concluded that Emily "was never willing to face the world" through the publication of her poems because of the vulnerability and exposure such a publication would require. Perhaps this vulnerability is best described in Emily's own words, 'This is my letter to the world, That never wrote to me.... sweet countrymen, Judge tenderly of me!"

 

As the choreographer of “Embodying Emily,” I researched the life of Dickinson and her struggles with agoraphobia and a myriad of personal torments and fears. Dickinson was hardly recognized in her time as an artist of value because of her gender, her class position, and the dearth of published work in her lifetime. Although she wrote thousands of poems, only ten were said to have been published while she was alive, sometimes anonymously. My movement was directly influenced by specific poems by Dickinson, including “He Fumbles at Your Spirit” and “How Many Flowers Fail in Wood.” I am inspired by Emily Dickinson's artistic life as both a unique creative experience and as a lens through which to understand the experiences of many artists past and present. I have used movement to explore the existential questions so many creative people face as they struggle to embody and express the value of a life dedicated to making art; as they continue to pursue their craft through seasons of plenty and productivity, and seasons of want and isolation.


Every aspect of the film's production will engage with the life and legacy of Emily Dickinson's intersecting creative and personal experiences as she expressed them in her writings, attending especially to questions of seasonality and nature. The filming will take place in a secluded area of the Virginia woods with a piano on site. The music is the first movement of Opus 90 by Franz Schubert. The costuming is designed specifically to handle the snags and tears that will come with dancing on the forest floor. Careful thought has gone into the development of a storyboard to make sure the best light hits at opportune moments in the choreography to convey the several layers of significance in the embodied movement.

What We Need

I am looking for your support in this two-part fundraiser to raise a total of $6,500. The vast majority of the funds (90%) will go towards paying the artists involved for their labor; to be able to fairly compensate all artists involved is a prime goal of this project. As experts in their fields, the artists who bring this project to life have carefully and passionately developed their craft over years of work; recognizing the value of their labor and accomplishments, particularly considering Dickinson’s own complicated experiences as an underrecognized artist during her lifetime, is essential. Such support is especially crucial in this time of uncertainty for artists in the United States, and around the world, during the pandemic. 

 

The first round of fundraising, which aims to raise $3,000, will support the artists in the rehearsal process, costume design, set design, and the filming. Filming is set to begin at the end of August or beginning of September. The second round of fundraising, totaling $3,500, will support post-film work, including editing, finalizing, premiering, and distributing the film. My hope for this film is not only to premiere it for my sponsors and audience members but also to submit the final product to dance and film festivals, arts competitions, and make it available for widespread educational outreach. 

Performing Arts and COVID-19

In the times of COVID-19, performing artists all over the United States are struggling with how to present their art while keeping their audience members and supporters safe. By supporting “Embodying Emily” you will contribute to the salaries of five artists across several avenues of art:

 

Ellie de Waal: Dancer, Choreographer, Director, Producer

Joy Weaver: Pianist

Josh Gooden: Videographer, Editor

Emily Marsh: Rehearsal Assistant, Assistant Director

Erica Johnston: Costume Design

 

Dickinson once wrote: “I shall have no winter this year…I thought it best to omit the season…” Let’s continue to support artists and their work, and let’s make something beautiful together. Perhaps in so doing we can also choose to “omit the winter” of great uncertainty that many artists are currently facing--or at least we can face this season united by art.

story:
We’re taking our first theatre production THE FALL into the next phase of its development. Help us tackle Mental Health stigma in the workplace via an innovative and provocative theatrical format inspired by video games and dystopian thrillers.

We are RUCKLE Theatre Ltd. Founded by 2020 Drama School graduates and proud recipients of the Fourth Monkey Experimental Fringe Bursary.

What is it?

Imagine Black Mirror, 1984 and Battle Royale meeting up with multidisciplinary theatre.

THE FALL is  an immersive and interactive digital live theatre show exploring the impact of stress in the workplace on Mental Health. The project, inspired by role playing video games, will feature multiple scenarios regarding Mental Health in the workplace in which the audience will become players.

Why?

Burnout, “the disease of our generation”, a phenomenon disturbingly increasing, and now affecting young adults at the beginning of their careers. From individuals to health professionals, we have spoken to various people about their experiences of stress in the workplace and its impact on mental health. Their stories are distressing. 

“Over 11 million working days are lost each year because of work-related stress, and stress can contribute to conditions such as anxiety or depression. And nearly half a million people in the UK have work-related stress at a level that makes them feel ill.”

- Dr Adrian Raby, General Practitioner.

 97% of people who responded to our first round research survey indicated an experience with one or more symptoms of burnout in the workplace but 41% of people hadn’t heard of or were unsure about what burnout even was. 

These stories are important. They deserve to be told and we want to put you in the driving seat.

 

What are we doing?

Through this campaign, we’re raising funds for the next phase of THE FALL so that we can:

  • Develop stories and characters
  • Explore our concept
  • Collaborate with a diverse and international team
  • Test our concept on diverse and targeted audiences, collecting feedback.
  • Open conversation with Mental Health professionals.
  • Connect with future collaborators and partners.

 

In parallel with rehearsals, we’ll organise various outreaches via surveys, interviews and workshops to a wide demographic. We believe discrimination in the workplace increases stress and therefore we will have a special focus on underrepresented groups.

Who are we?

RUCKLE Theatre is a new female-led theatre company founded by Emilie Largier and Libby Symons. We are two creatives, actors and physical theatre trained performers.  We met training at Fourth Monkey Actor Training Company (2018-2020), where we were taught by inspiring theatre makers such as Alexandra Spencer-Jones (Action to the World), Simone Coxall, Guillaume Pigé (Theatre Re) and Rich Rusk (Gecko Theatre), to name but a few. Inspired by neuroscience, sociology and psychology, we make visual and political work that challenges our audience, highlighting voices that are often left unheard.

Emilie is our director and a physical theatre force to be reckoned with, she is also part of the Young Vic Director Program. Libby is a fierce and instinctive actor who joined  Em in this adventure with selfish intentions, having always wanted to explore these themes through theatre. 

We both have volunteered with the British Red Cross as Roleplay actors to train the Psychological Support Team and are experienced in immersive theatre with a gameplay aspect, (Boomtown 2019, The Vaults 2019).

We are grateful to be strongly supported by an incredible and talented team of artists, from performers to production team, all passionate about making this project a reality.

Learn more about us

Meet the Team

Cast

  • Matisse Ciel Pagès - They/Them - France
  • Imogen Alvares - She/Her - UK
  • Adeola Yemitan - She/Her  - UK
  • Libby Symons - She/Her - UK

Production Team

  • Jean-Daniel Piccolo - Dramaturge - He/Him - France 
  • Nick Gilbert - Sound Designer - He/Him - UK 
  • Piotr Sell - Director of Photography - He/Him - Poland 
  • Emilie Largier - Director - She/Her - France
  • Libby Symons - Head of Production - She/Her - UK

Our performers are fierce movers and inspirations to us both. We have also collated an impressive team of collaborators. You can meet all of them via our website.

 

What we need?

We are proud to be supported by Oxfordshire Mind and if we reach our goal of £3000 we are committing ourselves to donate 10% of the funds to them! Oxfordshire Mind provides vital support to anyone needing support for a Mental Health problem, ensuring that nobody is alone in their time of need. 

Your donation will support one weeks wages for our Director, Performers and marketing promotion as well as a donation of £300 to Oxfordshire Mind. 

We’re very grateful to be supported in kind by our partners and we are currently applying for the under £15k Arts Council England Project Grant but we still need your help. 

This first stepping stone will support the beginning of an exciting adventure: a first R&D before the summer with a live and digital scratch night in July, in which we will organise a post show-talk and Q&As with our audience, collecting their experiences to help the growth of our project.

We have poured over budgets, fought with our calculators and we are raring to go! 

Times are tough 

We understand! You’ve made it this far and so we know that you care about supporting the arts. Here are three things you can do now to support our campaign without spending a penny:

  • Share this page with 3 friends
  • Engage with us on social media (Twitter/Instagram)
  • Support us in kind, get in touch via info@ruckletheatre.com

We are so grateful for whatever you can give. Please help us make this project that we are so passionate about. 

THANK YOU

Further resources:

https://www.ruckletheatre.com/

https://www.oxfordshiremind.org.uk/

Call Samaritans for emotional support on the phone, 24 hours a day 365 days a year by dialing 116 123.

With special thanks to...
story_txt:
We’re taking our first theatre production THE FALL into the next phase of its development. Help us tackle Mental Health stigma in the workplace via an innovative and provocative theatrical format inspired by video games and dystopian thrillers.
We are RUCKLE Theatre Ltd. Founded by 2020 Drama School graduates and proud recipients of the Fourth Monkey Experimental Fringe Bursary.
What is it?
Imagine Black Mirror, 1984 and Battle Royale meeting up with multidisciplinary theatre.
THE FALL is  an immersive and interactive digital live theatre show exploring the impact of stress in the workplace on Mental Health. The project, inspired by role playing video games, will feature multiple scenarios regarding Mental Health in the workplace in which the audience will become players.

Why?
Burnout, “the disease of our generation”, a phenomenon disturbingly increasing, and now affecting young adults at the beginning of their careers. From individuals to health professionals, we have spoken to various people about their experiences of stress in the workplace and its impact on mental health. Their stories are distressing. 
“Over 11 million working days are lost each year because of work-related stress, and stress can contribute to conditions such as anxiety or depression. And nearly half a million people in the UK have work-related stress at a level that makes them feel ill.”
- Dr Adrian Raby, General Practitioner.
 97% of people who responded to our first round research survey indicated an experience with one or more symptoms of burnout in the workplace but 41% of people hadn’t heard of or were unsure about what burnout even was. 
These stories are important. They deserve to be told and we want to put you in the driving seat.


 
What are we doing?
Through this campaign, we’re raising funds for the next phase of THE FALL so that we can:

Develop stories and characters
Explore our concept
Collaborate with a diverse and international team
Test our concept on diverse and targeted audiences, collecting feedback.
Open conversation with Mental Health professionals.
Connect with future collaborators and partners.

 
In parallel with rehearsals, we’ll organise various outreaches via surveys, interviews and workshops to a wide demographic. We believe discrimination in the workplace increases stress and therefore we will have a special focus on underrepresented groups.

Who are we?
RUCKLE Theatre is a new female-led theatre company founded by Emilie Largier and Libby Symons. We are two creatives, actors and physical theatre trained performers.  We met training at Fourth Monkey Actor Training Company (2018-2020), where we were taught by inspiring theatre makers such as Alexandra Spencer-Jones (Action to the World), Simone Coxall, Guillaume Pigé (Theatre Re) and Rich Rusk (Gecko Theatre), to name but a few. Inspired by neuroscience, sociology and psychology, we make visual and political work that challenges our audience, highlighting voices that are often left unheard.
Emilie is our director and a physical theatre force to be reckoned with, she is also part of the Young Vic Director Program. Libby is a fierce and instinctive actor who joined  Em in this adventure with selfish intentions, having always wanted to explore these themes through theatre. 
We both have volunteered with the British Red Cross as Roleplay actors to train the Psychological Support Team and are experienced in immersive theatre with a gameplay aspect, (Boomtown 2019, The Vaults 2019).
We are grateful to be strongly supported by an incredible and talented team of artists, from performers to production team, all passionate about making this project a reality.
Learn more about us
Meet the Team

Cast

Matisse Ciel Pagès - They/Them - France
Imogen Alvares - She/Her - UK
Adeola Yemitan - She/Her  - UK
Libby Symons - She/Her - UK

Production Team

Jean-Daniel Piccolo - Dramaturge - He/Him - France 
Nick Gilbert - Sound Designer - He/Him - UK 
Piotr Sell - Director of Photography - He/Him - Poland 
Emilie Largier - Director - She/Her - France
Libby Symons - Head of Production - She/Her - UK

Our performers are fierce movers and inspirations to us both. We have also collated an impressive team of collaborators. You can meet all of them via our website. What we need?

We are proud to be supported by Oxfordshire Mind and if we reach our goal of £3000 we are committing ourselves to donate 10% of the funds to them! Oxfordshire Mind provides vital support to anyone needing support for a Mental Health problem, ensuring that nobody is alone in their time of need. 
Your donation will support one weeks wages for our Director, Performers and marketing promotion as well as a donation of £300 to Oxfordshire Mind. 

We’re very grateful to be supported in kind by our partners and we are currently applying for the under £15k Arts Council England Project Grant but we still need your help. 
This first stepping stone will support the beginning of an exciting adventure: a first R&D before the summer with a live and digital scratch night in July, in which we will organise a post show-talk and Q&As with our audience, collecting their experiences to help the growth of our project.
We have poured over budgets, fought with our calculators and we are raring to go! 
Times are tough 
We understand! You’ve made it this far and so we know that you care about supporting the arts. Here are three things you can do now to support our campaign without spending a penny:

Share this page with 3 friends
Engage with us on social media (Twitter/Instagram)
Support us in kind, get in touch via info@ruckletheatre.com

We are so grateful for whatever you can give. Please help us make this project that we are so passionate about. 
THANK YOU
Further resources:
https://www.ruckletheatre.com/
https://www.oxfordshiremind.org.uk/
Call Samaritans for emotional support on the phone, 24 hours a day 365 days a year by dialing 116 123.
With special thanks to...

story:
Teatro SEA is Celebrating 35 Years of Success!

Teatro SEA is a Latino Bilingual Art-in-Education and Theatre Company based in the Lower East Side of New York City, and with offices in Puerto Rico and Florida  This vital organization seeks to empower and advance the latinx community and culture in the United States. 

In its 35 year journey, Teatro SEA has performed over 5,000 shows and reached more than one million people. 

SEA’s growing repertory encompasses 25 original musical productions, seasonal festivals, plays and educational workshops. Our work is all original - performed simultaneously in English and Spanish, and is rooted in classic fairytales and folktales from acrossLatin America - but put in a new context designed to educate, entertain and provoke discussions in the community about latino culture, immigration and more.   

We are proud to be making a difference in the lives of children and their families, building self-esteem and celebrating heritage and diversity. 

 

It is a Critical Time for Teatro SEA 

As many arts organizations are being forced to dissolve, we are more passionate than ever about our mission. We are proud to be celebrating our legacy with a special fundraising program to help equip us to continue our work as we set our sights on the next 35 years.  

We are expanding our efforts to include virtual programming, “Libros Teatro - Theatre Books” - a new children's book series, video productions, our new web series and musical project El Avion The Airplane...and more! 

Before the pandemic, Teatro SEA employed more than 80 artists, arts-administrators, designers, puppeteers, technicians and teaching-artists. We are working hard to develop strategies so that we can continue to be a vital force of education, enrichment, and employment in the theatrical community.
 

Act Now to Help Ensure we Can continue to Enrich the lives of Children for 35+ years more! 

Our goal is to raise $35,000 in celebration of our 35 years of success and to help secure the future of SEA! We invite you to join us, no matter the size of your gift. Whether you give $35, $350, or $3,500 -- please show your pride and support for Teatro SEA by donating today. 

Your donation will help to ensure that Teatro SEA can survive beyond the pandemic and give us the boost we need to successfully reinvent our programming while our “real world” theatre is closed.  We have the vision and potential to amplify our programming to a virtual world, creating a resource for education and entertainment that is more far-reaching than we ever imagined.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help!

Please help us to spread the word and share this opportunity with your friends and colleagues! 

Together, we can make a difference!

story:
Our Mission:

Dance In Color’s mission is to create lasting systemic change in the performing arts. Not only by bolstering young dance students of color, but also by ensuring that young Black artists who are striving for professional dance careers receive the support they need to have their aspirations become their realities. At Dance In Color, we make it a priority to expose students to dance teachers and choreographers from a variety of racial and ethnic backgrounds. We want to hold performing art studios accountable. And we dream to one day expand the change beyond dance to other forms of performing arts to create lasting change throughout the entire industry.

What We Need: 

Our goal is to raise $55,000:

  • $10,000 to continuing to support our scholars next year ($5000 for each student). 
  • $30,000 for one year at a pre-professional program for one of our merit scholars ($120,000 for 4 years).
  • $15,000 for building a fund for a summer program to promote diversity in ballet and ballet education.

What You Get: 

  • FROM TODAY ON ANY DONATION WILL RECEIVE A MANTRA T-SHIRT!!! 
    •  Chelsea Austin's Original Mantra T-shirt “Love immensely. Deep breaths. Gratitude. Belief” (pictured below) 
  •  Donation of $5-$25 will receive: A Social Media Shout out from the Co-Founders of Dance In Color                                                                    
  • First 5 Donations of $100-$150 will receive: Personalized Stationary from Polk Paper
    • https://www.polkpaper.com/custom-stationery  
  • Donation of $200-$499 will receive: An Hour "Worthiness" Coaching Session with Chelsea Austin  
  • Donation of $200 -$499 will receive: An Hour Private Ballet Class (focusing on technique on the basics) with Adrian Mitchell 
  • First Donation of $500 will receive: "Love Victor" Poster Signed by Ana Ortiz 
  • Second Donation of $500 will receive: A Signed Poster of Adrian Mitchell, Photographed by a Well Known Photographer 
  • Donations of $1000-$4,999: Mezzanine Donor Level
    • ​ Your name on our website for the 2021-2022 Fiscal Year and a Special Gift Item 
  • Donations of $5000-$9,999: Orchestra/Parterre Level 
    • ​ Your name on our website for the 2021-2022 Fiscal Year and Special Gift Items
  • Donations of $10,000- $10,999: Box Seats Level 
    • ​ Your name on our website for the 2021-2022 Fiscal Year and Special Gift Box 
  • Donations of $10,000 or above: Directors Level
    • Your name on our website from 2021-2023 and Special Gift Box

story:
Short Summary

Louisville Fringe festival (LouFringe) seeks to serve the Greater Louisville Metropolitan area of theatre artists and audiences. We define theatre as ANYTHING you do with live people for live people. Our festival is open to anyone who wants to submit, with an emphasis on artists from Indiana and Kentucky.

The purpose of LouFringe is to support the growing number of performance artists who choose to live and work in our exciting city. This ranges from emerging to established, professional, to semi-professional, to student and amateur theatre artists. In order to accomplish this, we strive to be inclusive and intersectional and to remove the financial barriers so that artists can focus on their work.

Our Mission is to establish a home for bold and fearless artists in order to create bold and fearless work. To embrace the imaginative and the weird. To encourage experimentation and innovation while providing an affordable and accessible outlet for exciting work that enriches our creative community.

What We Need & What You Get

This is our second year, and as we continue to grow, we need some help funding the festival. Paying the hosting venues, getting our website going, and buying online advertising and posters costs a lot of money. 

Any amount you donate can help LouFringe! Perks for helping out are:
- $1-$10 : Our undying love and a high five.
- $20 (or more!): A mention in our program as an official supporter, and our undying love and a high five.
-$50+ : An all-access festival pass (normally $75), a one-year Louisville Public Media Membership with starting level membership perks, a special Festival Pin only for backers, and all the other benefits listed. 

The Impact

If you're already planning on coming to the festival, donating $50 gets you a festival pass for a great deal! Help keep Louisville art scene weird. With your support we can make this Louisville a Fringey city.

story:
WISE NORLINA: AN OVERVIEW

What's the deal with this show anyway?

Who: Stacy Collado  (dancer, choreographer, producer), Hillary Pearson (dancer, choreographer, producer), Kat J. Sullivan (dancer, choreographer, producer), Mackenzie Connor (dancer), Alex Rogowski (dancer), Antonia Z Brown (dancer), Evalina Carbonell (dancer), Jamin Freas (dancer), Olivia Danni (dancer)

What: Three new works specifically made for the Philly Fringe Festival

When: September 18th, 21st, and 24th, 7:30pm

Where: The Sculpture Courtyard, 1714 N Mascher Street, Philadelphia PA 19125

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT IT GOES TOWARDS

In order to make this show happen, we need to raise $3000. If you are willing and able to donate, your funds will go towards:

$100 - Registering for the Philly Fringe Festival

$1,000 - Renting The Sculpture Courtyard in Kensington

$128 - Paying for insurance for our performance venue

$1,500 - Paying our dancers for rehearsal, tech/dress, and performances

$150 - Paying for postcards, adspace, and other marketing needs

$100 - Covering the 5% of the donations that Indiegogo takes

*Note: We would already like to thank Paul Taylor for generously helping us with a portion of the registration fee.

I'M UNABLE TO DONATE! 

Hey man, times are tough. Here's what you can do to help us anyway:

Send this Indiegogo to people who you think would be interested and are able to donate.

Come see the show!

Bring other people to the show!

Volunteer as an usher during the show! Email katjsullivan6@gmail.com if this interests you.

Thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you!

ABOUT THE CHOREOGRAPHERS

STACY COLLADO is originally from Eastern Pennsylvania and graduated in May 2016 with a BFA in dance from Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University. There she worked with choreographers Netta Yerushalmy, Kyle Abraham, Nick Bruder, LeeSaar the Company, Shen Wei Dance Arts, Pam Tanowitz Dance, Randy James, John Evans, Julia Ritter, and Keith A. Thompson. She was also a Bates Dance Festival scholarship recipient. In the summer of 2014 Stacy was given the opportunity to travel to Istanbul, Turkey to work with choreographer Julia Ritter and director Ayrin Ersoz on an immersive dance theatre project, Frozen Dream. Stacy Collado has shown her own choreography in various venues in New York City and continues to explore dance-making. She is interested in the merging of art forms and collaboration, including music, visual art, theatre, and film. Her process works with the ideas of manipulating shape and color, and she works with her dancers to create a variety of landscapes. While maintaining a subtly ridiculous or satirical nature, Stacy is also aesthetically interested in challenging physical habits in human nature and then putting them into performance-art perspective using gesture and the functionality of the human body. Pedestrian notions and ideas are inherent and integral in the developing of her work; she is interested in creating awkward, quirky and visceral realities that might be disconnected, that contain moments in which things might be glimpsed at and abandoned, and that glorifies pedestrian nature to its very strange core. 

KAT J. SULLIVAN is a dancer, choreographer, and writer currently based in Philadelphia. After graduating from Franklin & Marshall College with a degree in dance, she has worked with many companies and individual makers, including Antonia & Artists, Evalina Carbonell, Meredith Stapleton, and Sean Thomas Boyt. Her own work has been shown throughout Pennsylvania, New York, and North Carolina, notably in the Ruby Slipper Fringe Festival (NC), Triskelion’s Comedy in Dance Festival (NYC), and Koresh’s Come Together Festival (PHL). In addition to her performing and choreographic pursuits, Kat is a writer for thINKingDANCE.

HILLARY PEARSON is a Philadelphia based dancer and choreographer, originally from Brighton, Michigan. At the age of 29, Hillary began pursuing her modern dance training at Rutgers University, Mason Gross School of the Arts. During her time there she worked with artists such as Stefanie Batten Bland and Julie Bour. Upon receiving her BFA in dance, Hillary has danced with Company Stefanie Batten Bland, Robert Mark Dance and Antonia & Artists. Hillary continues to choreograph through exploring the medium of film, in collaboration with other artists. Choreographically, Hillary’s aesthetic is to create movement as form, engaging with physical sensations through the interplay of various elements: repetition, momentum, relationships with the floor, and periphery. The significance of pushing the physical body and the cognitive self beyond the conventional compels her to explore movement through a lens of reverberating possibilities. Her creative objective is to offer experiences that allow for transformation within the mind and body. Within the creative process it is important for Hillary to engage with other artistic minds beside her own to create beyond the physical body.

story:
Short Summary

Hi,

We're Rosa and Annie, and we're making an experimental puppet show.

 

The Impact

Above everything we want our show to tackle pressing issues relating to the environment in an innovative and arresting way. It's important that as humans we have these conversations again and again, in a million different ways, so that it sticks in our brains and we can save the planet... before it's too late.

Our show is specifically for families and will be suitable for children ages 7 and up. In the piece we'll address 5 problems: the great pacific garbage patch, micro plastics, oil, dead zones and climate change in the deep ocean. We'll talk briefly about solutions too, but the main idea is to introduce these concepts and inspire conversation within families.

 

Where Your Money's Going.

Our budget looks like this....

Space, (build and rehearsal space for 3 months, Jan 2017-Mar 2017) £800

Materials, (materials will mostly be free!) £300

Transport (hiring a van to move our piece to venues) £100

We are making a range of goodies and prizes for people who contribute to the show! Everything is handmade with love, from illustrated cards, to screen printed goods, to jewellery.

Other Ways To Get Involved.

One of the biggest way to get involved is by collecting. We're looking for all types of plastic packaging (it's best if it's one solid colour.), plastic bags, straws, aluminium cans, and anything else that you think is worth saving. We trust your magpie instincts!

We can easily collect materials from anywhere in Sheffield, London, Brighton or Norwich, if you're not in one of those places, drop us an email anyway and we'll try and work it out!

We can always use volunteer makers. If anyone is interested in getting involved creatively let us know. The whole project is one big experiment and so anyone with a brain and ideas is more than welcome to come and have a go!

Contact us:

Email: rosaandannie@gmail.com

Mobile: 07772286191

One of the biggest way to get involved is by collecting. We're looking for all types of plastic packaging (it's best if it's one solid colour.), plastic bags, straws, aluminium cans, and anything else that you think is worth saving. We trust your magpie instincts!
We can easily collect materials from anywhere in Sheffield, London, Brighton or Norwich, if you're not in one of those places, drop us an email anyway and we'll try and work it out!
We can always use volunteer makers. If anyone is interested in getting involved creatively let us know. The whole project is one big experiment and so anyone with a brain and ideas is more than welcome to come and have a go!
Contact us:
Email: rosaandannie@gmail.com
Mobile: 07772286191

story:
What We Need & Where Your Money Goes

It goes without saying that independent theatre gets nowhere without the generosity of financial backers. Staging a theatrical show, and musicals in particular, incurs significant overheads which cannot be avoided.

Having covered the initial upfront expenses of venue hire and licensing fees with the proceeds from our summer 2016 crowdfunding campaign, we have now moved into the main production stages of our show. The next step for us now is to build and design sets, costumes, props - all the stuff which ends up on stage for an audience to see! Marketing the show and other 'behind-the-scenes' expenses such as rehearsal space hire also need to be met. Currently, as of December 2016, we have so far raised around £500 for these key production elements through private sponsorships, an amount which we are seeking to match with contributions to this IndieGogo campaign.

Check out our perks to see which size donation is right for you. We are always incredibly thankful for every act of generosity, no matter the size!

 

The Production Team

Director Chris Stone has had years of experience in staging musicals, including having been Musical Director for the Welsh premiere of 'A Theory of Justice', originally written in 2013, and as a crew member for one of the first officially licenced amateur productions of 'The Phantom of The Opera' in 2012. He also holds a degree in music from Cardiff University.

Musical Director Owen McCarthy has also worked on a number of musicals before, including Dracula Spectacular, Grease, High School Musical, Oliver, and Annie, as well as taking rehearsals with the Pendyrus male voice choir.

Production Manager Henri Page is also a seasoned amateur dramatic, and is currently the treasurer for Cardiff University's theatre society, Act One.

 

Risks & Challenges

Producing a theatrical show is tricky business, and is not without its challenges. Now that we have entered formal rehearsals, the production team need to co-ordinate the efforts of over 40 individuals - cast, crew, band and others- in order to make the show a success. This will require meticulous planning of every aspect, from devising a marketing strategy, to building and designing the set. However, firm financial backing and advance planning will provide us with the best footing from which to launch our project.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would be incredibly thankful if you would do all you can to help spread the word about this campaign and to generate further interest. You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help with this.

We've taken the first steps towards making this impossible dream of ours a reality, all we need now is you!

Thank you,

Quixotic Productions

story:
Our Story:

The Other Theatre Company is a 501c3 Non-Profit Theatre Company based in Chicago. We are collective of artists dedicated to telling stories of those who are othered by systems of oppression. 

Next Up: Our incredible spring show - The Chicago Premiere of "Threesome" by Yussef El Guindi, starring Sadieh Rifai, Demetrios Troy, and Mike Tepeli. Directed by Jason Gerace. 

Leila and Rashid, Egyptian Americans with ties to Cairo, attempt to solve their relationship issues by inviting a relative stranger into their bedroom to engage in a threesome. What begins as a hilariously awkward evening soon becomes an experience fraught with secrets, raising issues of sexism, possession and independence.

Why this story is important:

This play is more relevant now than ever before. Despite the racy title and humorous first act - the second half of this play isn't so funny. "Threesome" is an examination of the mistreatment of women in male-dominated societies. It deals with the aftermath of sexual assault - and it touches on the ramifications of living in our war-torn world. Threesome explores the pain of lost hope, both politically and interpersonally, which will resonate with so many of our audience members right now. 

What We Need & What You Get:

The Other Theatre Company needs your help! Every dollar raised will go toward the following:

2016-2017 COSTS:

Performance Space Rental: $6,000

Equity Wages + Health and Pension + Paymaster fees + 12 Non-Equity Performers + Production Team/Designers/Management: $9,600 

Scenic Budget + Costumes + Makeup + Lighting + Props + Publicity + Marketing Fees: $5,800

THREESOME COSTS:

Performance Space Rental: $7,200

Equity Wages for TWO AEA performers + Health and Pension + Paymaster fees + 1 Non-Equity Performer + Production Team/Designers/Management: $13,340 

Scenic Budget + Costumes + Makeup + Lighting + Props + Publicity + Marketing Fees: $6,950

As you can see - we need all the help we can get! We're only in our third season, and almost 100% of our funding comes from private donations and ticket sales. While we are consistently applying for grants, it can be incredibly difficult for a young company to receive that type of funding. We need YOU!

We have fantastic PERKS! Check out our Perks tab to see what you'll get for donating your hard-earned money!

Please help us reach or SURPASS our goal for 2016!

Other Ways You Can Help:

We know that some of you might not be in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

Please use the Indiegogo share tools! Send our link to everyone you know! 

Thank you for helping The Other Theatre Company make our world a better, more just place for everyone!
