story:
We made our goal! Now what?

We are so grateful to have made our goal! You may be wondering if we still need donations. The answer is YES! The goal we set was geared towards paying for all of the things we mention below, mostly the artists and the space. Additional funds will be used for: 

  • Paying the two creative team members who are currently working as volunteers.
  • Getting the show out to the world! We are filming Sunday's production and will need funds to edit the material in order to market the show to other venues. 
  • Future productions! Any other funds will be put towards the expenses for remounting the show in other venues, and/or making new work. 

Thank you all again for your support. Last night's audience was such a thrill. We are so glad to be back in the theatre and sharing this story!

 

Short Summary

Are you ready for adventure? Join Hero, our clown-like protagonist, as she is called on a hero's journey by her phone. Meet Harry Potter Doll (HPD), E-william Shakespeare (ES), and other characters in this highly theatrical show using puppets, physical theatre, and exposed theatricality to explore grief through play, with plenty of comedy, a puppet co-star (Harry Potter Doll), and music inspired by 80s fantasy. 

 

Team

Emily Zempel Roberts began to write this show in 2020. To make it a reality she joined up with an amazing team, mainly comprised of women and mothers. Some of us are working to create our first projects after parenthood, while attempting to establish a new way of working that can support theatrical artists that are also primary care givers. By focusing on a woman-led production we are also able to create new cultures of working, new perspectives, and a compassionate theatrical environment. 

Emily Zempel Roberts: Emily is a constantly curious actor who seeks to challenge trends of realism in theatre. A professional actor for many years, her love of text and voice work gives her a strong inclination to perform Shakespeare, and her need for movement exploration has made her second love devised work. She is a performer, a PhD student at the Shakespeare Institute, and a lecturer in theatre performance. This is her first solo performance, and her first fully realized script. 

Elizabeth Audley: Elizabeth has worked in professional theater for over 25 years as an actor, director, producer, writer, and teacher, and has a special interest in new and devised work. She recently directed the first workshops and readings of Persuasion, a new adaptation of the Jane Austen novel by Sarah Rose Kearns, which is currently being produced by Bedlam Theater, off-Broadway.  She has a BA from Brown University, and her MFA from Ohio University, with additional training from SITI Company, Pig Iron Theater, The Actor’s Studio, Fiasco Theater, The Alvin Ailey Center, LaMama, and The American Globe. She lives and works in Beacon, NY.

Emily Dykeman: Emily is a devised theatre artist and writer based in New York. She graduated from SUNY Orange in 2010 and Cedarville University in 2012, studying English and Theater. She co-founded Dykeman Donovan Theater Lab in 2015, producing and acting in “Requiem,” which earned a grant from the Orange County Arts Council in 2016, and “The Bear,” which was featured in the Newburgh Illuminated Festival in 2017. She has worked with the Hudson Valley Performing Arts Laboratory since 2018--wearing many hats, including grant-writer, performer, lighting designer, and script writer.

Sarah Byrons: Sarah is a New York-based theatre artist and graduate from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where she earned her BFA in Theatre, with a focus on acting and playwriting. During her time at NYU, Sarah studied with Playwrights Horizons Theatre School, developing a strong background in the creation of new and devised work, and has studied playwriting in both New York and London. Sarah also studied with The Classical Studio, training extensively in Shakespearean verse and performance. Currently, Sarah co-runs and serves as the Creative Producer for the Hudson Valley Performing Arts Laboratory, a company based in Poughkeepsie, New York, that provides accessible opportunities to engage with the performing arts through affordable educational programming and the creation of new and ensemble-based work. She is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild.

Jonathon Roberts: Jonathon is a composer, audio engineer, and sound designer. He is on staff at Gimlet/Spotify where he has worked on scripted podcasts The Two Princes, Motherhacker, Chompers, Story Pirates, and The Final Chapters of Richard Brown Winters. Previously he founded the arts nonprofit Spark+Echo Arts with his wife Emily Clare Zempel, wrote music for slot machines, and toured the US with a one-person show on the Apostle Paul.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our Budget

We received a grant from Arts Mid-Hudson for $1,500, which helped us to get started with rehearsals and production. Our two major expenses are people and space.

Space: We have some donated space, which offsets our cost. For the rest of rehearsal and production, we need $1,600. 

People: We are dedicated to helping everyone receive fair wages for this project. For that to happen we need $5,000.

Set, props, and costumes are simple, for a total of $700.

For marketing and design we need $400. 

Finally, we would like to have $500 for contingencies and emergencies.

The total budget is $7,900. We have already received $1500 from Arts Mid-Hudson to create the show, and expect $900 in ticket sales.

That leaves a deficit of $5,500 to be funded with your help!

 

Perks

$10–Your name will be listed on our website as a supporter.

$20–Your name will be listed on our website, and we will give you a shout out on social media.

$35–All of the above. In addition, if you send us a pic, we will memify you with a big ol' clown nose on your schnoz!

$50–All of the above, plus a sneak peak of the script for the play. 

$100–Your name in the program, on our website, and on social media as a sponsor (Threshold Crosser), and two tickets to the show as available OR special access to attend the dress rehearsal live or via zoom. 

$250–Your name in program, on our website, and on social media as a producer (Helper), two tickets to the show (or dress), and access to a short video created by Emily Zempel Roberts with some simple tips on how to create a few moments of physical theatre from the show.

$500–Your name in program, on our website, and on social media as a patron (Mentor). Two tickets to the show (or dress). In addition HPD (my Harry Potter Doll puppet) will send you a special message of your choice!

$1,000–Your name in program, on our website, and on social media as a Hero.  Two tickets to the show (or virtual dress). In addition you may attend one live rehearsal (in person if vaccinated and masked, or via zoom), followed by a question and answer session with the creative team.

 

The Impact

We are all in an extended period of grieving. The content of our play is based on a loss Emily Zempel Roberts experienced in 2019 and her continued grieving during the pandemic. The hero’s journey framework comes from her own grief experience: she found that she wanted her loss to have a greater purpose–to be a part of some hero’s journey to which she was called.

The chosen style of this production allows for that exploration of grief and loss with laughter and play, rather than unadorned tragedy. The naivete of Hero as a type of theatrical clown will give her the innocence to come to understanding slowly, while sharing her experience with the audience. The depth of loss will be felt not through her tears, but through the form of the work—the dissolution of the fantasy at the end of the play. 

We believe the themes of this piece will help the community to filter their own pandemic-based grief through a work that makes them laugh and hopefully feel a bit less alone. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The pandemic creates some risks for us. We have several plans in place in the event that it is no longer safe to perform inside. First, we will require audience members to be masked and to have proof of vaccination. If that is not sufficient, we will either move the play outside, or record the performance for streaming, hopefully with the opportunity to mount it live in the spring. Either way, the show will go on, as safely as possible. 

 

Performance Details

A Hero's Journey will be performed October 22-24 at 7:30pm at the Beacon Performing Arts Center on Main Street in Beacon, NY.

Tickets are available here; https://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/5237804 

**All audience members must show proof of vaccination and wear a mask during the performance. The performer will be unmasked and socially-distanced. This show is meant for adults. Mature, vaccinated kids age 12+ may attend with parental discretion. There are intense moments, adult themes of grief, and a curse word or two.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help!

Please, get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it on your social media! Help us get butts in seats by sharing information about the performance as well!
story_txt:
We made our goal! Now what?We are so grateful to have made our goal! You may be wondering if we still need donations. The answer is YES! The goal we set was geared towards paying for all of the things we mention below, mostly the artists and the space. Additional funds will be used for: 
Paying the two creative team members who are currently working as volunteers.
Getting the show out to the world! We are filming Sunday's production and will need funds to edit the material in order to market the show to other venues. 
Future productions! Any other funds will be put towards the expenses for remounting the show in other venues, and/or making new work. 
Thank you all again for your support. Last night's audience was such a thrill. We are so glad to be back in the theatre and sharing this story! Short SummaryAre you ready for adventure? Join Hero, our clown-like protagonist, as she is called on a hero's journey by her phone. Meet Harry Potter Doll (HPD), E-william Shakespeare (ES), and other characters in this highly theatrical show using puppets, physical theatre, and exposed theatricality to explore grief through play, with plenty of comedy, a puppet co-star (Harry Potter Doll), and music inspired by 80s fantasy.  TeamEmily Zempel Roberts began to write this show in 2020. To make it a reality she joined up with an amazing team, mainly comprised of women and mothers. Some of us are working to create our first projects after parenthood, while attempting to establish a new way of working that can support theatrical artists that are also primary care givers. By focusing on a woman-led production we are also able to create new cultures of working, new perspectives, and a compassionate theatrical environment. Emily Zempel Roberts: Emily is a constantly curious actor who seeks to challenge trends of realism in theatre. A professional actor for many years, her love of text and voice work gives her a strong inclination to perform Shakespeare, and her need for movement exploration has made her second love devised work. She is a performer, a PhD student at the Shakespeare Institute, and a lecturer in theatre performance. This is her first solo performance, and her first fully realized script. Elizabeth Audley: Elizabeth has worked in professional theater for over 25 years as an actor, director, producer, writer, and teacher, and has a special interest in new and devised work. She recently directed the first workshops and readings of Persuasion, a new adaptation of the Jane Austen novel by Sarah Rose Kearns, which is currently being produced by Bedlam Theater, off-Broadway.  She has a BA from Brown University, and her MFA from Ohio University, with additional training from SITI Company, Pig Iron Theater, The Actor’s Studio, Fiasco Theater, The Alvin Ailey Center, LaMama, and The American Globe. She lives and works in Beacon, NY.Emily Dykeman: Emily is a devised theatre artist and writer based in New York. She graduated from SUNY Orange in 2010 and Cedarville University in 2012, studying English and Theater. She co-founded Dykeman Donovan Theater Lab in 2015, producing and acting in “Requiem,” which earned a grant from the Orange County Arts Council in 2016, and “The Bear,” which was featured in the Newburgh Illuminated Festival in 2017. She has worked with the Hudson Valley Performing Arts Laboratory since 2018--wearing many hats, including grant-writer, performer, lighting designer, and script writer.Sarah Byrons: Sarah is a New York-based theatre artist and graduate from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where she earned her BFA in Theatre, with a focus on acting and playwriting. During her time at NYU, Sarah studied with Playwrights Horizons Theatre School, developing a strong background in the creation of new and devised work, and has studied playwriting in both New York and London. Sarah also studied with The Classical Studio, training extensively in Shakespearean verse and performance. Currently, Sarah co-runs and serves as the Creative Producer for the Hudson Valley Performing Arts Laboratory, a company based in Poughkeepsie, New York, that provides accessible opportunities to engage with the performing arts through affordable educational programming and the creation of new and ensemble-based work. She is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild.Jonathon Roberts: Jonathon is a composer, audio engineer, and sound designer. He is on staff at Gimlet/Spotify where he has worked on scripted podcasts The Two Princes, Motherhacker, Chompers, Story Pirates, and The Final Chapters of Richard Brown Winters. Previously he founded the arts nonprofit Spark+Echo Arts with his wife Emily Clare Zempel, wrote music for slot machines, and toured the US with a one-person show on the Apostle Paul. What We Need & What You GetOur BudgetWe received a grant from Arts Mid-Hudson for $1,500, which helped us to get started with rehearsals and production. Our two major expenses are people and space.Space: We have some donated space, which offsets our cost. For the rest of rehearsal and production, we need $1,600. People: We are dedicated to helping everyone receive fair wages for this project. For that to happen we need $5,000.Set, props, and costumes are simple, for a total of $700.For marketing and design we need $400. Finally, we would like to have $500 for contingencies and emergencies.The total budget is $7,900. We have already received $1500 from Arts Mid-Hudson to create the show, and expect $900 in ticket sales.That leaves a deficit of $5,500 to be funded with your help! Perks$10–Your name will be listed on our website as a supporter.$20–Your name will be listed on our website, and we will give you a shout out on social media.$35–All of the above. In addition, if you send us a pic, we will memify you with a big ol' clown nose on your schnoz!$50–All of the above, plus a sneak peak of the script for the play. $100–Your name in the program, on our website, and on social media as a sponsor (Threshold Crosser), and two tickets to the show as available OR special access to attend the dress rehearsal live or via zoom. $250–Your name in program, on our website, and on social media as a producer (Helper), two tickets to the show (or dress), and access to a short video created by Emily Zempel Roberts with some simple tips on how to create a few moments of physical theatre from the show.$500–Your name in program, on our website, and on social media as a patron (Mentor). Two tickets to the show (or dress). In addition HPD (my Harry Potter Doll puppet) will send you a special message of your choice!$1,000–Your name in program, on our website, and on social media as a Hero.  Two tickets to the show (or virtual dress). In addition you may attend one live rehearsal (in person if vaccinated and masked, or via zoom), followed by a question and answer session with the creative team. The ImpactWe are all in an extended period of grieving. The content of our play is based on a loss Emily Zempel Roberts experienced in 2019 and her continued grieving during the pandemic. The hero’s journey framework comes from her own grief experience: she found that she wanted her loss to have a greater purpose–to be a part of some hero’s journey to which she was called.The chosen style of this production allows for that exploration of grief and loss with laughter and play, rather than unadorned tragedy. The naivete of Hero as a type of theatrical clown will give her the innocence to come to understanding slowly, while sharing her experience with the audience. The depth of loss will be felt not through her tears, but through the form of the work—the dissolution of the fantasy at the end of the play. We believe the themes of this piece will help the community to filter their own pandemic-based grief through a work that makes them laugh and hopefully feel a bit less alone.  Risks & ChallengesThe pandemic creates some risks for us. We have several plans in place in the event that it is no longer safe to perform inside. First, we will require audience members to be masked and to have proof of vaccination. If that is not sufficient, we will either move the play outside, or record the performance for streaming, hopefully with the opportunity to mount it live in the spring. Either way, the show will go on, as safely as possible.  Performance DetailsA Hero's Journey will be performed October 22-24 at 7:30pm at the Beacon Performing Arts Center on Main Street in Beacon, NY.Tickets are available here; https://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/5237804 **All audience members must show proof of vaccination and wear a mask during the performance. The performer will be unmasked and socially-distanced. This show is meant for adults. Mature, vaccinated kids age 12+ may attend with parental discretion. There are intense moments, adult themes of grief, and a curse word or two. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help!Please, get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it on your social media! story:
‘PLAY’ is an audience interactive presentation of original choreography inspired by childhood games, imagination, competition, and chance. Dancers will be challenged with manipulating the work using rules and indicators that are not previously determined, making each presentation of PLAY unique and exciting. 


By contributing to this campaign you are making POPS Dance Co.’s debut performance possible by:

-  Funding the rental of the performance space

-  Funding the creation of original costumes

-  Funding the production of programs, posters, and other promotional materials

-  Providing access to talented dancers and crew members to support the project and make the performance possible

-  Kick starting the public identity of POPS Dance Co.

-  Becoming an integral part of the history of POPS Dance Co.’s development

-  Supporting a new dance movement involving audience participation and accessible performances


Artistic Director, Katrina Grogan-Kalnuk, founded POPS Dance Co. in November 2014. POPS strives to increase accessibility; the company’s work is an invitation for honest reactions to movement. POPS believes that the most valuable contributor to artistic presentation is YOU. Your opinions, emotional reactions, imagination, and inspirations establish the company’s purpose and fuel every creative pursuit. The main goal is removing bias and encouraging an open-minded approach by presenting movement inspired by simple, relatable ideas and eliminating any expectation of reactions. All we want is to move you, for you, and invite you to move with us, in any capacity, through the creation and performance of dance. What you see is what you get, no strings attached, no expectations, no stress, just people doing what they love for people who are willing to join in on the adventure. POPS Dance Co.’s mark on the world is not just presenting performances and providing entertainment, but inspiring all kinds of people to think creatively and daydream every day.

story:
We have created a shadow-theatre moment for all Indiegogo funders and we will present it here as premiere after the first 5000$. Till then the video will keep loading.


Summary


“Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.” Arthur C. Clarke

     Every project is born from an idea and it is achieved with a lot of work, dedication, but above all this, joy.

     We are a team of young artists, which try to find new exciting ways of expressing themselves and the world, eager to explore the depths in art, waiting to discover new forms of it, but at the same time able to acknowledge the values of the past.

      We took our chance to experiment and innovate and came up with an idea that we wish so much to put in to practice: an artistic journey, in which arts connect and cross with advanced technology, practically a live video-game-show. We believe a show of this kind is what the contemporary audience was waiting for: so complex, spectacular, surprising and profound.

     Our show tells the story of two unique characters, which go on an amazing fantastic adventure. Once they complete new tasks, a new door opens in front of them and they jump from one fantastic universe to another, experiencing unbelievable situations. Besides the two main characters, the story revolves around other steampunk characters who perform their entire action in a maze with different fantasy rooms, thus we invented the phobia room, the inverse room and another 9 that we'll keep secret for the moment.


     We believe the show is a complete one, because of the acting, dancing, acrobatics, stage combat, magic and fire-show, which the actors will perform. But what makes this performance so amazing is that we want to add special effects, video mapping and video projection in order to create an immersive experience.

     In this show we're using video projection in all possible forms. We want to use a big video projection screen to split the stage in two halves enabling us to play both in front and behind it as shadows (fig.1). Besides the big projection screen mentioned above, behind it there will be 3 more screens, creating a room composed of 3 walls and a projection floor, making possible the projection on 4 sides/screens (fig. 2).

    As you go further and further into the story, mysterious shapes, graphics and animations are revealed. And what better style to make this fantastic performance expressive and modern, than steampunk costumes and masks, that go against convention,expressing so well one’s individuality individuality.   

 The actors will perform with masks as in Commedia dell' Arte but without using text, only non-verbal language, accompanied by music, video effects, lights and special effects. We want to make this production non-verbal to be understood by everyone, to reach the hearts and attention of the entire world.

     Unlike Commedia dell' Arte, we will use steampunk masks ,as it was said earlier, thus covering the entire face to create unique characters and why not, maybe a new form of theatre characterized by steampunk masks.

    "Steampunk is a subgenre of science fiction and fantasy literature and art that commonly features some aspect of steam-powered machinery, especially in a setting inspired by industrialized Western civilization during the 19th century. Steampunk works are often set in an alternative history of the 19th century's British Victorian era or American "Wild West", in a post-apocalyptic future during which steam power has maintained mainstream use, or in a fantasy world that similarly employs steam power." - Wikipedia

     Of course, the fantastic world connects to reality on many levels, probing relationships between image and self, freedom and restraint, connection and separation, success and failure and uses symbols and generally valid characteristics of the human soul. To add more spice, the story ends in a magical, shocking, unexpected way.

     For this show we're building some amazing stage decor which we will use it as it is for its functionality, but we also want to project on it, using video mapping technology. The decor itself playfully highlights, deconstructs, rotates, recontextualises and generally manipulates geometries, in order to create a new visual dimension and optical illusions.

  .

   We are eager to get our project done and play it all over the world, but we are facing big production costs, especially for the tech part. We do believe this show is complex, complete, spectaculous and revolutionary in the art of theatre, it pushes art boundaries and we trust it will prove to be an amazing experience for the audience. Because we belive in this project so much, we decided to really make it happen but, for that, we need your help to be able to purchase the video projectors, the graphic station, the screens, the smoke and light machines, the decor for each universe that takes shape, the steampunk costumes and masks and an appropriate rehearsal space, to fit all these in and to promote our show internationally.

     We really believe in you and please understand that we can achieve the perfect management only with your support. 

     We would like to thank you for even reading this far and if you are unable to support us financially, even sharing this page to friends and family will help us a lot. 

     Every little help from you means the world to all of us, and we choose to believe that our hard work and efforts won't crumble into a wayward fantasy. 

     We also consider support, if you're in the area, to please come and see the final product. We promise to deliver a fantastic show! No, wait ! We promise that you will not forget us and our show.


"Most funding is for the impulse, which is good, but there is not really funding for crafting the impulse." - Robert Woodruff


Where Does The Money Go?

$15,000 – video projectors,grafic station, smoke machines and other props

$5,000 – Rehearsal costs

$3,500 – Costumes and masks

$2,500 – Lighting, set design and sound

$1,000 – Advertising & media

$3,000 – Managing travels, interviews, photoshoots, play bils and others


Risks & Challenges

     Unexpected costs always arise in the production of a play. Especially the closer you get to the opening. "The show must go on," as they say - and in the end things do tend to work themselves out, but every dollar we can receive over our goal can make those challenges easier for us.

All our love,

Iulian Lungu (director),Diana Georgiana Voion, Massimiliano Nugnes, Andreea Stafie, Alin Popovici , Alex Radu Andrei and all future staff.

story:
We were just contacted by a long-time supporter of the CHS Theater Program and they want to donate FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS to our project!!!! The catch is this - we have to get at least another $5000 in donations!!!

Any dollar you give will be DOUBLED by our generous benefactor! If you're reading this, please donate right this instant. This is the momentum we need to kick this campaign up a notch. Oh, and by the way - your donation is TAX-DEDUCTIBLE through our 501c3 Non-Profit status!

We have great perks and incredible theater waiting for our backers. 

Please contribute now so we can unlock $5000!!!!!

PLEASE HELP US FUND OUR 2015 - 2016 SEASON!

#TheaterChangesLives

Most of our program is self-funded and it's up to the Parents, Friends, Teachers and Volunteers of the Calabasas High School Theater Program to go out and raise the funds necessary in order to keep this program alive. Without this fundraising, our award-winning program cannot exist. We need your HELP!! 

Your Generous Donations are Tax Deductible!

Calabasas High School is a public school within the Las Virgenes Unified School District in Los Angeles County. Each year, the CHS Theater Program produces a professional standard of theater through its innovative productions, stellar student casts, gifted student musicians, and highly-trained student technical crews.

Our Theater Program Director, Bill Garrett, was honored as Teacher of the Year for 2014 by the Los Angeles County Office of Education, an honor bestowed on only 16 of the County’s 75,000 teachers. He was also Las Virgenes Unified School District’s 2014 Teacher of the Year! 

As our students exercise qualities such as hard work, persistence, tenacity, and patience, they also connect with their fellow students and foster an environment of community and acceptance. These qualities stick with them into their college and professional lives, and many of these relationships last for life! We're not kidding when we say #TheaterChangesLives!

On behalf of students, faculty and staff, a 100,000 thank-you's for donating to our campaign and sharing our site with your friends and family!!



FACT: The CHS Theater Program receives only 11% of it's funding from the School District.

The sad truth is that all across the nation schools are seeing their arts funding cut. We saw our community come together to fund the Performing Arts Education Center, but now we need your help to take full advantage of the facilities.

FACT: The artistic education of our students is reliant on the fundraising efforts of our community.

Without the generous support of donors, we would never be able to offer our students a high-quality arts education. Every year, we hold several fundraisers in order to fill the gap. Every year, we barely do it. 
This year, we decided to go big and do ONE fundraiser to rule them all! 

 FACT: By supporting our campaign, you are making a TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation to support Theater Arts at CHS. 

FACT: By supporting our campaign, you are supporting the personal development of the students who work tirelessly to raise the bar on stage and in their academics.

Your TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation will go directly to the funding of our 2015-2016 season and all of the satellite education opportunities associated with the program. 


A few of the items on our budget include:

  • Several Musicals and Plays over the course of the year.
  • Production costs (Royalties & Rights, Sets, Props, Lighting, Sound, Costumes, etc). This includes bringing in talented specialists to work with students on specific skills, such as vocal training and choreography.
  • Support Staff - We fund many of the positions that support each production, such as costume, hair/make-up and sets design, as well as their materials.
  • Comedysportz! A traveling competitive Improv Team.
  • Participation in (2) yearly DTASC Festivals, in which theater students from all over Southern California compete in selections of various theater styles.
  • Murder Mystery Night - A completely student written & produced dinner theater experience. 
  • Student Written & Directed Black Box Play
  • Scholarship Programs for Students in need - CHS Theater awards scholarships to seniors who are continuing their theatrical education, both onstage and backstage.
  • Mentorships - Individualized Stagecraft, Production & Technical Training
This is just a small sample of the some of the main costs. For a more detailed list, you can email our program director directly: billgarrett@chstheater.com

Your Contribution Makes a BIG Difference!

The goal for CHS Theater is to raise $100,000 this year! Money raised will contribute to the continued growth of our program. Remember that your donation is Tax Deductible! 

Why Should I Give?

That's a great question! Allow us to answer your question with some questions:

  • Do you believe that the personal and cultural development of our children is worth investing in? 
  • Do you have a friend, family member, or child who is part of our program? 
  • Do you enjoy theater, dance, or music in any of it's various forms?
  • Do you want to foster a generation of well-rounded students?

Whether you answered YES to any of those questions or are just a generous person, we ask that you dig deep and partner with us in funding our 2015-2016 season! THANK YOU - we are so grateful!

Please Help Us Get The Word Out!

Whether it's $10 or $10000, your donation and support is HUGELY appreciated and we thank you in advance for giving. If you're not able to donate financially, we can still really use your help! Here are FOUR ways you can support our campaign:

  1. Donate Now: When you give, you directly impact the lives of students and send a clear message that our community is stronger because we care! 
  2. Tell Your Friends: Please use the share tools at the top of this page to share our website www.TheaterChangesLives.com on Facebook, Twitter, and email!
  3. Share Your Story: We’d love to hear YOUR story about how theater or the Arts changed or enhanced your life. Share your story by posting in the comment section here on the Indiegogo Campaign or on your Facebook, Twitter, or Instagram accounts!
  4. Please LIKE us on Facebook and FOLLOW us on Twitter & Instagram!

The more social media shares, likes, and tweets, the higher our Indiegogo "GoGo Factor" increases, leading to higher rankings, more exposure, and more donations!

100 bucks is great, and 100 shares can be just as powerful!!

Here are some answers to your most commonly asked questions?

What happens if you don't reach your goal?

If we don't raise our revenue, we'll need to make cuts in our budget. This will most likely mean less student opportunities and less professional support.

I thought Calabasas was a rich area of town. Do you really need this money?

Not everyone in Calabasas is a Kardashian. The majority of our families are working middle-class families. Our Theater Program is self-funded and relies solely on our fundraising efforts.

I don't get this whole IndieGoGo thing. Can I send you a check?

We prefer that you don't as it doesn't move our ticker forward. But sure, send it to:

CHS Boosters 

Calabasas High School Theater 

Attn: Bill Garrett 
22855 Mulholland Hwy
Calabasas, CA 91302

Thank you to our Sponsors for their generosity!
story_txt:
We were just contacted by a long-time supporter of the CHS Theater Program and they want to donate FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS to our project!!!! The catch is this - we have to get at least another $5000 in donations!!!
Any dollar you give will be DOUBLED by our generous benefactor! If you're reading this, please donate right this instant. This is the momentum we need to kick this campaign up a notch. Oh, and by the way - your donation is TAX-DEDUCTIBLE through our 501c3 Non-Profit status!
We have great perks and incredible theater waiting for our backers. 
Please contribute now so we can unlock $5000!!!!!


















PLEASE HELP US FUND OUR 2015 - 2016 SEASON!
#TheaterChangesLivesMost of our program is self-funded and it's up to the Parents, Friends, Teachers and Volunteers of the Calabasas High School Theater Program to go out and raise the funds necessary in order to keep this program alive. Without this fundraising, our award-winning program cannot exist. We need your HELP!! 


Your Generous Donations are Tax Deductible!








Calabasas High School is a public school within the Las Virgenes Unified School District in Los Angeles County. Each year, the CHS Theater Program produces a professional standard of theater through its innovative productions, stellar student casts, gifted student musicians, and highly-trained student technical crews.
Our Theater Program Director, Bill Garrett, was honored as Teacher of the Year for 2014 by the Los Angeles County Office of Education, an honor bestowed on only 16 of the County’s 75,000 teachers. He was also Las Virgenes Unified School District’s 2014 Teacher of the Year! 
As our students exercise qualities such as hard work, persistence, tenacity, and patience, they also connect with their fellow students and foster an environment of community and acceptance. These qualities stick with them into their college and professional lives, and many of these relationships last for life! We're not kidding when we say #TheaterChangesLives!



On behalf of students, faculty and staff, a 100,000 thank-you's for donating to our campaign and sharing our site with your friends and family!!




















FACT: The CHS Theater Program receives only 11% of it's funding from the School District.
The sad truth is that all across the nation schools are seeing their arts funding cut. We saw our community come together to fund the Performing Arts Education Center, but now we need your help to take full advantage of the facilities.

FACT: The artistic education of our students is reliant on the fundraising efforts of our community.

Without the generous support of donors, we would never be able to offer our students a high-quality arts education. Every year, we hold several fundraisers in order to fill the gap. Every year, we barely do it. 
This year, we decided to go big and do ONE fundraiser to rule them all! 

 FACT: By supporting our campaign, you are making a TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation to support Theater Arts at CHS. 


FACT: By supporting our campaign, you are supporting the personal development of the students who work tirelessly to raise the bar on stage and in their academics.














Your TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation will go directly to the funding of our 2015-2016 season and all of the satellite education opportunities associated with the program. 








A few of the items on our budget include:



Several Musicals and Plays over the course of the year.
Production costs (Royalties & Rights, Sets, Props, Lighting, Sound, Costumes, etc). This includes bringing in talented specialists to work with students on specific skills, such as vocal training and choreography.

Support Staff - We fund many of the positions that support each production, such as costume, hair/make-up and sets design, as well as their materials.


Comedysportz! A traveling competitive Improv Team.


Participation in (2) yearly DTASC Festivals, in which theater students from all over Southern California compete in selections of various theater styles.


Murder Mystery Night - A completely student written & produced dinner theater experience. 


Student Written & Directed Black Box Play



Scholarship Programs for Students in need - CHS Theater awards scholarships to seniors who are continuing their theatrical education, both onstage and backstage.


Mentorships - Individualized Stagecraft, Production & Technical Training


This is just a small sample of the some of the main costs. For a more detailed list, you can email our program director directly: billgarrett@chstheater.com

story:
Our Philosophy

Limitless School of Dance is a Christian dance studio that teaches all ages and skill levels from 3 years to adult. Since our purpose is to glorify God through dance, we want to make our classes as accessible to as many families as possible. On average, our prices are less than half of what you would pay at a typical studio.

In a world where dance has become overly sexualized, either in the dance moves themselves, the clothing worn, the lyrics of songs, or in the obscene amount of makeup worn by young dancers, Christians either have to compromise their values or simply not pursue their passions. At Limitless, we keep our classes wholesome and captivating. We do not perform inappropriate moves, our dress code focuses on teaching our students modesty, we only use Christian music, and our dancers wear not much more makeup than lip gloss when performing.

Our Needs

Our dance studio currently consists of one dance room that is only halfway being utilized. The room's dimensions are 34'x35', and we only have dance flooring covering 16'x30'.

  • We need to create a second dance room out of a smaller room that we have in the back of the studio. This room will need construction work, dance flooring, mirrors, paint, etc. This is estimated to cost $5,000.
  • We need to purchase enough dance flooring to finish covering the main dance room. This will cost $2,000.
  • If money permits, we would also like to purchase sprung floors for both dance rooms. On the low end of estimates, this should cost at least $8,000.

Your Impact

Being a one room studio, our class scheduling abilities are very restricted. We can only offer about 20 classes per week during afterschool hours (4:30-9:00 pm). With various styles and levels of dance, those 20 classes get filled up pretty fast. We constantly have to turn families away simply because our studio does not have the capacity to hold more classes. Having a second dance room would allow us to double our class offerings. Also, having more dance flooring in our current dance room will allow us to have larger classes.

At Limitless School of Dance, we do not want cost to ever be the deciding factor for any family. While our tuition is already very low, we do have dancers in families that have lost their jobs or simply do not make very much money at the jobs they currently have. The last thing we want is for the dancer to have to give up dancing because their family cannot afford the tuition. Therefore we have dancers that dance on further reduced tuition or even have their tuition waived.

This hospitality comes with a cost. While we are able to keep our doors open, we are not able to do much more. Your contribution will help us to make dancing in a wholesome, encouraging, Christian environment a possibility for more families.

Spread the Word!

While $15,000 may seem like a lot of money, if we can get 1,000 families to donate just $15, we’ll have reached our goal. The only way we can make this happen is for lots and lots of families to hear about our campaign. Even if you are personally unable to donate, could you please share our story? Use the links on the left to share on Facebook, post to Twitter, or to send an email to your family and friends.

Thank you for your support.

story:
The Art of Motivation: A Play

Accomplished comedy writers John Cuneo and Andrew Thorp created The Art Of Motivation, a look into the challenging and lucrative world of motivational speaking, with all it's hilarious ups and downs.  They recruited some of Chicago's top improvisers and performers to bring the show's characters to life and leave audiences laughing at every turn.

John is an Emmy Award-winning writer/director with Punch Films, who created this piece with original characters, concepts and embedded digital elements to make this play entertaining, unique and open to the possibility of a future filmed-series. 

Andrew has been producing comedy shows throughout Chicago for 7+ years via Thorpedo Productions and collaborates on scripting, auditions and everything in between.

Your contribution will pay actors, fund the marketing campaign, production essentials and so much more.  

Producing theater is no small task.  So this show couldn't happen without you.

Even better! There are amazing perks to take advantage of, including personalized messages from characters, comped tickets to shows, books to help you excel in business and so much more. 

Check out our perks for a complete list!

With your help, we can pack the house and deliver a show that will leave people talking.

Your donation will make this production a professional, polished and hilarious piece of theater while helping actors put food on the table (or pay rent).

Help us get the word out by telling your friends and family - the cool ones with a sense of humor - about the show, share our campaign on FB, Twitter and the like.  

See what your donations create at our live shows every Wednesday in April at 8 p.m.

Theater:  STAGE 773, at 1225 W. Belmont, Chicago

Not in town, check us out on Gigity.tv for streaming and archived shows.

With This Amazing Cast!
Alli Joy Braun
David McNulty
Jonny Nelson
Paige Reilly
Jeff Rogers
Andrew Spatafora
Jenna Steege
Paul Traynor
Ryan Williams

story:
My 7 year old daughter, Echo and I have recently moved close to my hometown of Victoria BC after living on small islands where families all celebrate at events together. My daughter is sad that there are so few fun events and festivals for families to camp out, learn and play together, she is such a circus child (I perform fire hula hoop) and a festival vendor kid (I make fascinators and hair accessories and such to vend at festivals in BC for the last 7 years) …so I am creating one for her! I've volunteered at festivals for 10 years plus both organized and co:created festivals & fundraising events locally and abroad... so we want to make something amazing for families and kids out in Sooke, BC! 

Astoundingly, all it needs to get this new festival flying is $5000!
This money is for booking the land for rental, paying artists deposits, getting promo printed and for hiring folks to do security, first aid, driver services and other vital jobs.  Here are some of the programs that will be offered during this festival: 
+ Circus playshops for kids = aerial silks, acro balance, poi, hula hoop, staff and more
+ Kids radio program = kids will be broadcasting live from the event, with their own stage. 
+ DJ Skills = taught by prestigious local and international talent
+ Arts programs = live painting, mixed media and multimedia programs
+ Crafts creation = bringing what's in your head out into the world
and more!
This festival will influence the future: our kids.
Check out the initial Facebook event page! 
https://www.facebook.com/events/845174728859191/

story:
Video: Shakespeare Downtown's The Seagull - Billie Andersson and Brando Boniver.  Directed by Geoffrey Horne.
(Music credit:  Eugene Onegin PR 20051 Courtesy by PREISER RECORDS)

We hope you will be a part of the new Shakespeare theatre at Castle Clinton.
We have started a new 501(c)(3) nonprofit Shakespeare theatre company in Lower Manhattan, Shakespeare Downtown.  We hope to stage a free Shakespeare play every summer for 4 weeks at Castle Clinton National Monument in Battery Park.  Like Shakespeare's Globe Theatre, Castle Clinton is in the open-air, in the round, on the water.  There will be seating for 300 people a night for a total audience of 6,000 - a new Shakespeare in the Park.  The first production, Romeo and Juliet, is set to open on June 2nd and to run through June 27th (Tuesdays through Saturdays) from 6:30 pm to 8:30 pm.

Shakespeare Downtown has evolved out of 10 years of successful productions.  Geoffrey Horne, the director, is a founder of Shakespeare Downtown, and a long-time member of the Actors Studio.  He has been an acting teacher at the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute for over 30 years.  He also worked as an actor in movies such as The Bridge on the River Kwai and Bonjour Tristesse, and in the theatre and television.  Billie Andersson is the co-founder of Shakespeare Downtown, and an actress and producer of 11 plays.  Filmed excerpts of the plays can be seen at www.shakespearedowntown.org and at www.billieandersson.com.

We have gotten support from Community Board 1, and the Downtown Alliance.  Some well-known members of the acting community - Estelle Parsons, Anna Strasberg, John Douglas Thompson, Terence McNally, and the late Mike Nichols - have said we could use their names as supporters.

All of the artists and all of the technical crew involved in the production are donating their services to make this new theatre possible.  It is our hope that by bringing Shakespeare's plays to Castle Clinton each summer, we will help bring Castle Clinton back into the life of the city, and create a new annual cultural event in Lower Manhattan.  Please join us in our endeavor.

What we need:
$3,000 for the audio rental
$5,000 for the generator/fuel
$9,000 for the lighting rental
$6,000 for security (park ranger)
$6,000 for insurance for the castle
$3,000 for costumes
$3,000 for 300 chairs
$35,000 total

Why we need your help:
Donations (individual or corporate) will make our first production possible.  This will allow us to establish a necessary track record to obtain future grants and sponsorships.   Donations show community support and help us build our audience.  Every single dollar helps us get closer to our goal.

Other ways you can help:
If you can't contribute, you can still help.  Please share this campaign with your friends and family.

You can make a difference.
Thank you in advance for your generous support!

story:
Monroe Community Players, who have been a part of Monroe Michigan for nearly seventy years, are struggling with rising production costs which are now threatening to end their tradition of presenting live dramatic theater in the area.

Monroe Community Players do not own their own building or have their own performance space. The majority of the funds we are seeking are to cover the cost of the theater rental.  The cost for renting the performance space alone is now over $3,000 for one production. 

We perform at Monroe County Community College, so the money we spend there helps our local community college and our local community.

A Man For All Seasons is a sponsored project of Monroe Community Players, a non-profit arts service 501(c)3 organization located in Monroe Michigan. Contributions for the purposes of producing A Man For All Seasons must be made payable to Monroe Community Players and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 


Keep dramatic theater alive! 

Monroe Community Players is currently the only all-volunteer group in the area still producing Shakespeare and classic dramas. 

In the past MCP has produced such dramas as The Crucible, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, Of Mice and Men, and many others in Monroe Community Players’s long history.  Monroe Community Players also has a tradition of bi-annually producing Shakespeare plays. Past shows include A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Macbeth, Romeo and Juliet, and most recently King Lear.

Monroe Community Players is an entirely volunteer organization, with no paid positions. From Board Members to performers, all are volunteers donating their time and talents because they believe that theater matters!

We are reaching out to everyone who supports locally produced dramas.


Where your donation will be used

We need to pay for the rental of the facility.

Our goal is set at $5000.  This was to cover the rental of the La-Z-Boy Center Meyer Theater, publicity costs and materials for the set.  (We did round up ;-))

We need $3170 to cover the rental of the La-Z-Boy Center Meyer Theater.  This covers two weeks of use: one in the scene shop where we build our set, and the second the week of actual production.  Included in the facility rental is an in-house lighting director, security and maintenance.  It does not include use of the sound system. If we want to use the in-house sound system, we would have to pay for a sound technician.  As of this writing, we intend to cut costs by doing the sound effects off stage and not use the Meyer's theater system.


We would be spending $1000 for publicity.  The majority of this will be going towards advertising in our local newspaper, The Monroe News.  We feel that we should support local business and our advertising dollars stay in our own community this way.  We will be using it to place five ads:  two the week before the show and three the week of the show.  This will allow us to take advantage of a cheaper rate The Monroe News offers for non-profit organizations.

We estimate the set materials at $700. While we will be re-using materials (4x4s, 2x4s, platforms and stairs) that we have from previous productions, we will still need to buy additional lumber, foam core sheets, hardware, and paint.  Our goal is to be as frugal as possible, and we hope to be under this estimate.

Perks!

We are grateful for any donation of course!!  If we were able to reach out to 5000 people, and if they all donated $1 we would be set!  But if you are able to donate a bit more, we are offering a variety of perks for all different levels!  From your name as a donor in our program, seats to the show to a special meet and greet with the cast and the director, there is something for everyone!  We are very thrilled to offer at the $100 level a special "theater geek" t-shirt.  Please let us know your size in a private message in your donation!

Wrap Up

Any and all funds Monroe Community Players raise during this campaign will go directly to its production of A Man For All Seasons  by Robert Bolt, produced with special arrangement with Samuel French.  

If we raise funds above the $5000 goal, they will go directly to the next production in the Monroe Community Players Main Stage Series for  2014-15.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute? You can still help us out!

Spread the word about our campaign via social media!

Like us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Monroe-Community...) or check us out online at www.MonroeCommunityPlayers.org

We are always looking for new actors, directors, and volunteers. Email us at MonroeCP@MonroeCommunityPlayers.org  with your information.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the love!

Thank you!!!


Monroe Community Players, P.O. Box 23, Monroe, Michigan, 48161
story_txt:
Monroe Community Players, who have been a part of Monroe Michigan for nearly
seventy years, are struggling with rising production costs which are now threatening
to end their tradition of presenting live dramatic theater in the area.


Monroe Community Players do not own their own
building or have their own performance space. The majority of the funds we are
seeking are to cover the cost of the theater rental.  The cost for renting the performance space
alone is now over $3,000 for one production. 


We perform at Monroe County Community College, so the money we spend
there helps our local community college and our local community.

A Man For All Seasons is a sponsored project of Monroe Community Players, a non-profit arts service 501(c)3 organization located in Monroe Michigan. Contributions for the purposes of producing A Man For All Seasons must be made payable to Monroe Community Players and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 



Keep dramatic theater alive!  

Monroe Community Players is currently the only all-volunteer group in the area still producing Shakespeare and classic dramas. 



In the past MCP has produced such dramas as The Crucible, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, Of Mice and Men, and many others in Monroe Community Players’s long history.  Monroe Community Players also has a tradition of bi-annually producing Shakespeare plays. Past shows include A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Macbeth, Romeo and Juliet, and most recently King Lear.



Monroe
Community Players is an entirely volunteer organization, with no paid positions. From Board Members to performers, all are volunteers
donating their time and talents because they believe that theater matters!




We are reaching out to everyone who supports locally produced dramas.
Where your donation will be used


We need to pay for the rental of the facility.
Our goal is set at $5000.  This was to cover the rental of the La-Z-Boy Center Meyer Theater, publicity costs and materials for the set.  (We did round up ;-))
We need $3170 to cover the rental of the La-Z-Boy Center Meyer Theater.  This covers two weeks of use: one in the scene shop where we build our set, and the second the week of actual production.  Included in the facility rental is an in-house lighting director, security and maintenance.  It does not include use of the sound system. If we want to use the in-house sound system, we would have to pay for a sound technician.  As of this writing, we intend to cut costs by doing the sound effects off stage and not use the Meyer's theater system.


We would be spending $1000 for publicity.  The majority of this will be going towards advertising in our local newspaper, The Monroe News.  We feel that we should support local business and our advertising dollars stay in our own community this way.  We will be using it to place five ads:  two the week before the show and three the week of the show.  This will allow us to take advantage of a cheaper rate The Monroe News offers for non-profit organizations.
We estimate the set materials at $700. While we will be re-using materials (4x4s, 2x4s, platforms and stairs) that we have from previous productions, we will still need to buy additional lumber, foam core sheets, hardware, and paint.  Our goal is to be as frugal as possible, and we hope to be under this estimate.
Perks!

We are grateful for any donation of course!!  If we were able to reach out to 5000 people, and if they all donated $1 we would be set!  But if you are able to donate a bit more, we are offering a variety of perks for all different levels!  From your name as a donor in our program, seats to the show to a special meet and greet with the cast and the director, there is something for everyone!  We are very thrilled to offer at the $100 level a special "theater geek" t-shirt.  Please let us know your size in a private message in your donation!

  Wrap Up

Any and all funds Monroe Community Players raise during this campaign will go directly to its production of A Man For All Seasons  by Robert Bolt, produced with special arrangement with Samuel French.  If we raise funds above the $5000 goal, they will go directly to the next production in the Monroe Community Players Main Stage Series for  2014-15.
Other Ways You Can Help
Can’t contribute? You can still help us out!Spread the word about our campaign via social media!Like us on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Monroe-Community...) or check us out online at www.MonroeCommunityPlayers.orgWe are always looking for new actors, directors, and volunteers. Email us at MonroeCP@MonroeCommunityPlayers.org  with your information.Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the love!Thank you!!!


Monroe Community Players, P.O. Box 23, Monroe, Michigan, 48161

story:
Here's the plan...

     Hello! Let us start by introducing ourselves. Our names are Peter Base and Francesca Genovese. For the last ten years we have both been dancing professionally with a small ballet company in Greenville, SC... and dating now for 2 of those years! Looking towards the future, we both have goals and ambitions to do greater things in both the dance world and beyond. Some of these goals include choreographing, theater work and voice over work. Our current goal though, is to both dance in more established, stable companies.
     We have already narrowed down our search of companies that we are interested in, and have split the results into two categories; companies we plan to visit and audition in person, and companies to send resume and performance footage to. Because of the number of companies we are planning to visit in person, we will be splitting our 'Audition Tour' into at least two trips.

Here's how you can help...

     There are a number of costs associated with trips like these; of course gas, lodging and food being the obvious ones. Being gone for (potentially) weeks at a time comes with it's losses. Between the both of us we teach 28 classes weekly, resulting in a combined income of $950 a week... income lost while we would be traveling.

Help us cut costs by:
  • Reaching out to anyone you may know that you think would be willing to house two dancers for no more than one or two nights. The cities we have narrowed down our visits to are Chicago, IL, Louisville, KY, Cincinnati, OH, Columbus, OH, Cleveland, OH, Pittsburgh, PA & New Brunswick, NJ.
  • Help us keep an eye out for any deals (i.e. Living Social & Groupon) to help us eat affordably while we travel. Also any coupons or those old dusty gift cards you may have laying around are an excellent way to contribute as well!

Risks...

     Any new adventure, like the one we are about to take, comes with it's risks. We have narrowed our selected search based on each prospective company's repertoire, the living costs and appeal of the cities they are in, and proximity to our families. What these companies are looking for in a dancer is completely unknown to us. With all of our efforts being made to travel to audition, and impress as much as we are able, there is the chance that we will not be what they are looking for.
     We want to take that risk.

What else can you do...

     Help us spread the word, and please share our story with anyone you think would be willing to listen.
     This is about more than just two dancers out there looking for jobs. We are only two of millions. Please support the arts in any way you can, and help ensure that the companies (like the ones we are interested in) will be around for years to come.

story:
Please support the World Premiere of Paul Lucas’s Trans Scripts at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this August! Your tax-deductible donation* will ensure that the authentic voices of transgender women sharing their stories, in their own words, will be celebrated at the largest performing arts festival in the world.

About:

In the past several years, transgender visibility around the world has exploded.  A wide range of public figures have announced their trans identity to the world:  People like actress Laverne Cox, model Andreja Pejic, celebrity Chaz Bono, director Lana Wachowski  have led the charge, but it was Olympic legend Caitlyn Jenner whose declaration sparked a media frenzy and forever thrust transgender identity into the light of day.

Transgender characters are popping up regularly in film, television and even comic books, but what does the average person really know about the true, lived experience of being transgender?  Not the life of someone in the public eye, but the day-to-day reality of being trans in Western culture.  For the general public, questions lead to more questions and the answers are elusive.

While wonderful shows like Transparent are to be applauded for adding trans staff writers, there are still no plays, films, or televisions series featuring a broad cross section of transgender people telling their own stories, in their own words.  And it is only by removing the stigma of "other" from the trans experience that we can truly begin to build bridges of understanding.

As Laverne Cox, the first openly transgender person to ever appear on the cover of  Time Magazine said in the  accompanying video interview last year:

"A lot of it is just about listening to transgender people and taking the lead from trans folks... I don’t represent the entirety of the trans community.  There’s multiple experiences and multiple relationships to one’s identity, and so it’s really about listening to individuals in terms of how they define themselves and describe themselves and taking people at their word – being willing to let go of preconceptions we have about people who are different from us and taking people on their own terms."

Trans Scripts is the result of four years of research and interviews conducted by writer Paul Lucas, who traveled across the US, Europe, India, and Cuba to interview people of transgender experience.  With the help of respected dramaturge, Morgan Jenness, Paul has created a groundbreaking theatrical experience that brings to life the real stories of a broad cross-section of extraordinary trans women as they embark on a journey to embrace their authentic selves.

The stories of these brave trans women are, at turns, compelling, surprising, inspiring, funny and harrowing, but foremost, they are human.  The moral of the piece is that our similarities far outweigh our differences, and it is from this truth that understanding is built.

It is time to bring this conversation out in the open.  It is time to connect, put away smart phones, preconceptions and prejudices and embrace our humanity -- to build bridges, not to burn them, and to erase the fear of others and open minds...

This summer, we have the opportunity to bring Trans Scripts to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest performing events festival in the world and the premiere platform for launching important new writing.  Our team has had tremendous success in Edinburgh in the past, producing over a dozen shows since 2006 and receiving three Fringe First and Herald Angel Awards (the highest honors awarded at the Fringe).  We know the landscape and are confident that the Fringe is the perfect platform to debut this important new work.

Edinburgh is an expensive undertaking, but not when compared with trying to open a show of this size off-Broadway, which would cost a minimum of $500,000.  The Fringe will afford the opportunity for the play to be seen by some of the most important producers in the world for a fraction of the cost.  Our basic productions budget is $100,000, and we are looking to raise a minimum of $75,000 to complete our financing.    Our previous successes in Edinburgh have resulted in extensive, critically-acclaimed tours of the US, the UK, Ireland, Germany, Sweden and Australia, and we have every reason to believe that Trans Scripts will enjoy this level of success, or greater, because of the topical subject matter of the play and the moving, funny and brave stored contained within it.

Trans Scripts Is premiering during what CNN has dubbed "Our Culture's Transgender Moment."  People are hungry for information and insight into the transgender experience, and Trans Scripts provides this, while at the same time entertaining and inspiring audiences.

Stretch Goals:

Cast & Crew:

I have engaged two long time collaborators for the project: Director Linda Ames Key, a two-time Fringe First Award winner, and Associate Producer Gail Winar, a critically-acclaimed actress, director, teaching artist and Fringe veteran.  Together with an extraordinary cast from Broadway, film and television, we are primed for success, but we need your help in order to mount this production. 

Watch this space for exciting casting announcements to come!


About the Playwright:

Writer Paul Lucas has produced over a dozen shows at the Fringe since 2004, and has received numerous five star reviews, as well as both a Fringe First Award for "What I Heard About Iraq," and a Herald Angel Award for "The Be(A)st of Taylor Mac."  His productions have toured extensively throughout the US, the UK and Australia and have continued to garner awards around the globe.


The population of Edinburgh more than doubles during the Fringe, and everything is at a premium during this peak season.  Five bedroom apartments (and we need TWO of them!) rent for $7,500.00 for the month and airfares from New York to Edinburgh soar to $1,600.00 per person.

While many productions on the Fringe feature young university companies, we are engaging an extraordinary cast with major credits in order to best serve the material.  These actors are generously working for a minimal fee, but they still need to be paid for their time and talent, and we need to hire a staff of three to manage the production, marketing and promotion of the show, as well as interfacing with producers, promoters and the press.

Each venue charges a minimum rental deposit up front against ticket sales, and being listed in the Fringe Program, Venue Program and major media outlets is essential and costly.  We also will need to set up an office in Edinburgh with a printer and other office basics.

Finally, we need to print promotional materials including flyers, posters and press releases.

About the Fringe:

Thank You

On average, a transgender woman is murdered somewhere in the world every 29 hours. The next generation of trans men and women needs us to make the world a better, safer, more accepting place by promoting awareness, education and acceptance.  Trans Scripts aims to be an important part of this movement.

Thank you in advance for supporting this important project and its message of inclusion. 

Paul Lucas and the Trans Scripts Team.

Paul Lucas with "Orange Is The New Black" star and trans activist Laverne Cox.

* Lucas Tours is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Trans Scripts must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Blood and Fire is a New Musical...

Libretto by Jeffrey Couchman, Music by Lisa Heffter.
Music Direction by Vadim Feichtner. Directed by David Elliott. 

Produced by Perry Street Theatricals

Launching a new musical is a tremendous challenge. So when we were given the opportunity to present BLOOD AND FIRE as a Staged Reading in the 2015 TRU Voices Series, we were thrilled. Staged Readings occur throughout the year in NYC as new musicals and plays take their first step in development to becoming fully realized productions. 

It was a perfect start in what we knew would be a huge step forward in the process. And so... the venue was booked -- a beautiful 175-seat concert hall -- the actors were ready -- we had been rehearsing diligently for five days -- and we were all set to take the stage to bring the show before an audience. Our date, however, was January 26th -- which had its own billing as "the snow storm of the century" -- and with NYC totally shut down -- we were forced to cancel the presentation. 

It was impossible to reschedule in the short term as many in the show had other commitments or were going on to other shows. We have rescheduled for March 16, 2015 – that’s good news! But will this require us to go back into the rehearsal room, re-hire the actors (and re-cast some of the roles), and pay the creative fees. Unfortunately, the capital we had was spent for the initial presentation.

Who are the Players?

Perry Street Theatricals is an award-winning producing and general management organization in NYC (pstheatricals.com). TRU (Theatre Resources Unlimited) was created to bring together a supportive network of both established and newly developing producing organizations in the New York area in order to interface these producing organizations with other potentially valuable resources both within and beyond the theatrical community.

Together we will "re-present" this developmental staging of BLOOD AND FIRE... but we need your help to bring this beautiful new work to life.

What Do We Need & What Do You Get?

Mounting a staged reading is the first step in the development process of creating a new show. The funds raised will help to offset the costs of the presentation. 

We are hoping to raise $10,000.

  • Funds will provide compensation for all the artists involved, from actors (we have 13), and stage managers to the writers and director and music director.
  • Scripts, scores and programs need to be reprinted, the rehearsal hall needs to be booked. Creative fees are due. 
  • Certain funds will also be used to offset the losses incurred due to the cancellation and any additional costs that we incur that were unforeseeable at the time of creating the budget.
  • After the presentation, we will cut a BRAND NEW demo recording of 5 or 6 of the songs from the show. Your contribution will help pay for this too!

By contributing to BLOOD AND FIRE, you will be cordially invited to the March 16th staged presentation (we will send you the RSVP details later) – and you can see the show for yourself! Once we finish the demo recording, we will send you either a link to a download of the music or a CD, whichever you prefer. And of course we will keep you up to date on future developments of this exciting project.

Won't you please join us in making this first crucial step?

A Brief Description of the Show 

Its 1892. An irreligious physician from London’s wealthy West End falls in love with a woman of faith from London’s impoverished East End. Meanwhile, a mob of ruffians bands together to destroy a brand new organization called the Salvation Army. The Army’s larger-than-life founder, General William Booth himself, marches across the stage alongside an array of Dickensian characters. Rich, poor, reformers and thugs all collide in a musical tale at once intimate and epic. 

Blood and fire guaranteed...

Don't take our word for it - a few of the songs!

Something Must Be Done


Booth is Coming


Faith


Who's Who - The Creative Team

JEFFREY COUCHMAN (Libretto) has written screenplays for Imagine Films, Warner Bros. TV, and other studios. He has published fiction in many literary journals. Another musical for which he wrote book and lyrics, Battleship Potemkin (music by Eric Allaman), was presented in the York Theatre Company’s Developmental Reading Series (July 2014) and will be produced in Berlin in the upcoming season by Gallisas Theaterverlag. He is author of the book “The Night of the Hunter”: A Biography of a Film and is currently editing three volumes of James Agee’s screenplays for the University of Tennessee Press. He teaches screenwriting at the College of Staten Island.

LISA RALIA HEFFTER (Music) lives in relative obscurity as a prolific composer.  Although her foundation is in the classics as a master’s graduate of The Juilliard School (Heffter’s impressionist quartet “Eschape” premiered at Carnegie Recital Hall and was reviewed by the New York Times as "astonishingly beautiful."), her passion is writing music for great stories. Most recently, Heffter’s rock opera, “Atom & Eve” was staged as a concert reading in October 2014 at the Mary Lea Johnson Performing Arts Center. Rolling Stone Magazine's Betsy Hill reviewed: “I was totally blown away”; Heffter’s one act rock opera “Permission” was directed by John Tedeschi at The Triad for a sold out two week run, and “Oh! The Sport of Love” a bawdy comic operetta for mezzo-soprano, has been performed from intimate parlors to starlit stages worldwide. Heffter is currently collaborating with Jean Witter, librettist, on “Mars: 2076,” a futuristic musical based on the American Revolution of 1776.

VADIM FEICHTNER (Music Director) served as music director/dance arranger for the Broadway production of The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee. His Off Broadway credits include: Ordinary Days, Elegies: A Song Cycle, The Burnt Part Boys, The Public Theater's As You Like It and Lincoln Center American Songbook's Songs of Innocence and Experience (both co-composed with William Finn), I Sing!, Infinite Joy, Cam Jansen and V-Day. His regional credits include: Little Miss Sunshine, My Life is a Musical, The Unauthorized Autobiography of Samantha Brown, The Memory Show, Party Come Here, The Mysteries of Harris Burdick andSee Rock City. He has worked on concerts for Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Leslie Kritzer and Lisa Howard.

DAVID ELLIOTT (Director) his directing work has been seen at Olney Theatre, The Culture Project, The Irish Repertory Theatre, Metropolitan Playhouse, The Zipper, The Players, New York Performance Works and at Rattlestick’s Exposure Festival. Member SDC.

PERRY STREET THEATRICALS (Producer) My Life is A Musical (Bay Street),Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike (B'way, Tony Award), Lend Me A Tenor The Musical (West End, Olivier nom.), Bedlam’s Hamlet/Saint Joan (Culture Project, Off Broadway Alliance Award), an oak tree (Barrow Street, OBIE ), In The Continuum(OBIE), Exits and Entrances (Edinburgh), Shylock, Treason (Perry Street Theatre). Credits for Mr. Elliott: The Exonerated (Drama Desk). For Mr. Platt: Here Lies Jenny (Zipper), Gumboots, Nixon’s Nixon (West End). As General Managers: My Life is A Musical, WikiMusical (NYMF), The Mapmaker’s Opera (NYMF), Ethel Sings(Beckett), Bedlam’s Hamlet/Saint Joan (Lynn Redgrave Theatre) Date of A Lifetime(NJ Rep, and upcoming for Off Broadway '15), White People (Atlantic). Upcoming: In Bed With Roy Cohn (The Lion), Hamlet (Sheen Center), A Craiglist Cantata (Off Broadway), My Name is Rachel Corrie (Lynn Redgrave Theatre).

We thank you in advance!
