beautiful 175-seat concert hall -- the actors were ready -- we had been
rehearsing diligently for five days -- and we were all set to take the stage to
bring the show before an audience. Our date, however, was January 26th -- which
had its own billing as "the snow storm of the century" -- and with
NYC totally shut down -- we were forced to cancel the presentation. 
It was impossible to reschedule in the short term as many in the
show had other commitments or were going on to other shows. We have rescheduled
for March 16, 2015 – that’s good news! But will this require us to go back into
the rehearsal room, re-hire the actors (and re-cast some of the roles), and pay
the creative fees. Unfortunately, the capital we had was spent for the initial
presentation.
Who
are the Players?
Perry Street Theatricals is an award-winning
producing and general management organization in NYC (pstheatricals.com). TRU
(Theatre Resources Unlimited) was created to bring together a
supportive network of both established and newly developing producing
organizations in the New York area in order to interface these producing
organizations with other potentially valuable resources both within and beyond
the theatrical community.

Together we will "re-present" this developmental staging of BLOOD AND
FIRE... but we need your help to bring this beautiful new work to life.
What
Do We Need & What Do You Get?
Mounting a staged reading is the first step in the development
process of creating a new show. The funds raised will help to offset the costs
of the presentation. 
We are hoping to raise $10,000.


Funds will provide compensation for all the artists involved,
from actors (we have 13), and stage managers to the writers and director and
music director.


Scripts, scores and programs need to be reprinted, the rehearsal
hall needs to be booked. Creative fees are due. 


Certain funds will also be used to offset the losses incurred
due to the cancellation and any additional costs that we incur that were
unforeseeable at the time of creating the budget.


After the presentation, we will cut a BRAND NEW demo recording of 5 or 6
of the songs from the show. Your contribution will help pay for this too!


By contributing to BLOOD AND FIRE, you will be cordially invited
to the March 16th staged presentation (we will send you the RSVP details later)
– and you can see the show for yourself! Once we finish the demo recording, we
will send you either a link to a download of the music or a CD, whichever you
prefer. And of course we will keep you up to date on future developments of
this exciting project.
Won't you please join us in making this first crucial step?

A Brief Description of the Show 
Its 1892. An irreligious physician from London’s wealthy West
End falls in love with a woman of faith from London’s impoverished East End.
Meanwhile, a mob of ruffians bands together to destroy a brand new organization
called the Salvation Army. The Army’s larger-than-life founder, General William
Booth himself, marches across the stage alongside an array of Dickensian characters.
Rich, poor, reformers and thugs all collide in a musical tale at once intimate
and epic. 
Blood and fire guaranteed...Don't take our word for it - a few of the songs!Something Must Be DoneBooth is ComingFaith


Who's
Who - The Creative Team
JEFFREY COUCHMAN (Libretto) has written screenplays for Imagine
Films, Warner Bros. TV, and other studios. He has published fiction in many
literary journals. Another musical for which he wrote book and lyrics, Battleship
Potemkin (music by Eric Allaman), was presented in the York Theatre
Company’s Developmental Reading Series (July 2014) and will be produced in
Berlin in the upcoming season by Gallisas Theaterverlag. He is author of the
book “The Night of the Hunter”: A Biography of a Film and is
currently editing three volumes of James Agee’s screenplays for the University
of Tennessee Press. He teaches screenwriting at the College of Staten Island.
LISA RALIA HEFFTER (Music) lives
in relative obscurity as a prolific composer.  Although her foundation is
in the classics as a master’s graduate of The Juilliard School (Heffter’s
impressionist quartet “Eschape” premiered at Carnegie Recital Hall and
was reviewed by the New York Times as "astonishingly
beautiful."), her passion is writing music for great stories. Most
recently, Heffter’s rock opera, “Atom & Eve” was staged as a concert
reading in October 2014 at the Mary Lea Johnson Performing Arts Center. Rolling
Stone Magazine's Betsy Hill reviewed: “I was totally blown away”;
Heffter’s one act rock opera “Permission” was directed by John Tedeschi
at The Triad for a sold out two week run, and “Oh! The Sport of Love” a
bawdy comic operetta for mezzo-soprano, has been performed from intimate parlors
to starlit stages worldwide. Heffter is currently collaborating with Jean
Witter, librettist, on “Mars: 2076,” a futuristic musical based on the
American Revolution of 1776.
VADIM FEICHTNER (Music Director) served
as music director/dance arranger for the Broadway production of The
25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee. His Off Broadway credits
include: Ordinary Days, Elegies: A Song Cycle, The Burnt Part Boys, The
Public Theater's As You Like It and Lincoln Center American
Songbook's Songs of Innocence and Experience (both co-composed with
William Finn), I Sing!, Infinite Joy, Cam Jansen and V-Day. His
regional credits include: Little Miss Sunshine, My Life is a Musical,
The Unauthorized Autobiography of Samantha Brown, The Memory Show,
Party Come Here, The Mysteries of Harris Burdick andSee Rock City. He
has worked on concerts for Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Leslie Kritzer and Lisa
Howard.
DAVID ELLIOTT (Director) his directing
work has been seen at Olney Theatre, The Culture Project, The Irish Repertory
Theatre, Metropolitan Playhouse, The Zipper, The Players, New York Performance
Works and at Rattlestick’s Exposure Festival. Member SDC.
PERRY STREET THEATRICALS (Producer) My
Life is A Musical (Bay Street),Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike (B'way,
Tony Award), Lend Me A Tenor The Musical (West End, Olivier
nom.), Bedlam’s Hamlet/Saint Joan (Culture Project, Off Broadway
Alliance Award), an oak tree (Barrow Street, OBIE ), In
The Continuum(OBIE), Exits and Entrances (Edinburgh), Shylock, Treason (Perry
Street Theatre). Credits for Mr. Elliott: The Exonerated (Drama
Desk). For Mr. Platt: Here Lies Jenny (Zipper), Gumboots, Nixon’s
Nixon (West End). As General Managers: My Life is A Musical,
WikiMusical (NYMF), The Mapmaker’s Opera (NYMF), Ethel
Sings(Beckett), Bedlam’s Hamlet/Saint Joan (Lynn Redgrave
Theatre) Date of A Lifetime(NJ Rep, and upcoming for Off Broadway
'15), White People (Atlantic). Upcoming: In Bed With Roy
Cohn (The Lion), Hamlet (Sheen Center), A
Craiglist Cantata (Off Broadway), My Name is Rachel Corrie (Lynn
Redgrave Theatre).
We thank you in advance!

story:
My  Story


My name is Carter Sinclair and I am a 12-year-old dancer at Louis Nunnery School of Classical Ballet.  I have been dancing since the age of 5.  I have always liked ballet, but last year I became much more serious about it.  In last year's spring performance, I had a sweet dance duet with my sister, and it inspired me to work harder and do more.  This year, I am incredibly excited to be featured in the role of Tinkerbell in the Nunnery School performance of Peter Pan.  While practicing for that, I got the news that I have been accepted to Joffrey Ballet School in New York City.  It seems to be my time to dance!


Joffrey In My Eyes

I am so excited that I might be spending a week at Joffrey! Dancing all day with amazing teachers and other dancers like me from all over the world would truly be a dream come true. Joffrey will be a place where I can reach my full potential as a dancer, and I know I'll never forget the experience.

What Will Your Donation Fund?

It's expensive to spend a week at Joffrey Ballet NYC, but the experience will be priceless. 

Between tuition, airfare, room/board, and dance gear, it will cost me almost $5,000 to go to Joffrey.  My family is very supportive, but it’s important for me to have a stake in this, too.  I am already earning part of this by babysitting, pet sitting, and doing odd jobs.  But I will need the help of my family and friends to meet my goal in time to pay for school.  So hire me for an odd job or contribute to my campaign, Either way, I will appreciate your help very much.  You can be sure that I will work hard and do everything to the best of my abilities. Your money will make my dream come true!  If you know of other supporters of the arts who would like to help, please share my story!  THANK YOU!

Dance with me to NYC!

BIG thanks to Sally Fanjoy for beautiful photography and Alan Sides for amazing videography, editing, and production!

story:
Well as of 2/25/15 My business partner backed out of our arrangement leaving with the funds for the purchase of The Bob White theatre and for the much needed updates,

2/27/15

We have a few options that have come to light, We are by no means out of luck on the purchase but we still need your help to make it happen, what was 10 days to raise 770 thousand is now looking like 30 days to raise 350 thousand, a grand goal still but much more achievable. please share the link below and tell every one you know, We can pull this off! there will be other ways to help out as well! stay tuned, it's not over till the fat lady stops singing!


Quite simply, I am asking for you're help to Keep The Bob White Theatre in the right hands and in the Family, I am not looking to buy a theatre for myself but for the community of Portland, For Music, Theatre. Movies. and other events. This is Your Theatre, this is for you and every one in our community.

It seems like a monumental task, but We as a community can concur any challenge that arises, we just have to come together and believe in it,  And I will do everything in my power to keep it open to you,

We have been working strongly towards a  COMMUNITY FIRST EVENT HUB for south east Portland, The impact of the Bob White can be seen in many lights, From attracting new people to the Foster-Powell community,  The Portland Music Community, Support for the arts in both theatre and music, and a true community-first venue everyone will enjoy helping breath life into

  • Your contribution helps us bring you not only quality entertainment but pride in the fact that you were a part in preserving Portland history,
  • We have attracted attention from major players in the sound and production industries, confirming our ability to bring about a complete rebirth of both venues.
  • No matter what, every little bit helps, and we will ensure your donation comes back to you ten-fold in the long term.

Risks & Challenges

We see the risks in this venture like any other, but we have gone to great lengths to surround this effort with great minds from near and far to ensure its success, Understand there is no How-To for this sort of thing'we will have struggles and hard times but the knowledge and will power to prevail over any and all problems that arise.

Futher more, THIS IS YOUR THEATRE, Help keep it in the family for the well being of our Community 

If you have interest in seeing the Business plan for The Bob White Theatre please contact me at infothebobwhitetheatre@gmail.com, I will gladly send you a copy 

Thanks, and much Love, Nick Haas

story:
What we're up to...

Dancing Sky Theatre launched it's first Twinkle Lights Campaign about 10 years ago, and were able to raise funds in order to purchase our own, although older, lighting system.  The time has come to upgrade our system and update some equipment, so it's time to bring back the Twinkle Lights Campaign!

What we need...

We needed to do some repairs on one of our two dimmer packs (which are integral to the running and operating of our theatre lights), and since they are older models, it became quite clear that if we don't take steps now to upgrade them we could be in big trouble if something happens to them while in production.  Parts for these models are not readily available, so the plan was hatched to buy two new dimmer packs, and keep our existing packs for added flexibility.

We started the Twinkle Lights Campaign during our last production, The Haunted Man, and we're off to a very good start.  Our hope is that by the end of our most recent production, The Lucky Ones by Kelley Jo Burke, we will have raised the funds to buy the two new packs as well as refurbish some theatre lights that were donated to us.

How it will help us...

Being a small professional theatre company, and the only one located in rural Saskatchewan, we have always managed to do big things with little resources. By upgrading the system it will give us piece of mind as to the state of our system, but more importantly it will give us the ability to expand how many lights we can have as part of our lighting designs, which will increase our options artistically for each production.


Why Indiegogo...

We have a very loyal base of supporters here in the Meacham area, however, the number of people that come through our doors during a production is only a portion of the friends and supporters we have out there.  So, we're turning to Indiegogo in order to put the word out about our fundraising objective.

If you can't contribute...

Any amount will help, but if you find that you can't contribute financially at this time, please spread the word about our campaign.  Being from small town Saskatchewan, we know that word of mouth is extremely important. Thanks so much!

story:
Short Summary

Weird City Theatre Company announces a world premiere stage production of HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL, adapted from director William Castle's 1959 Vincent Price thriller. A nurse will be on hand each night to care for those who faint from terror and guests are encouraged to sign up for life insurance in case they die of fright!

The party begins when eccentric millionaire Frederick Loren brings together 5 strangers with the promise of $10,000 if they stay the night in his haunted house, but soon these skeptics are all trapped with ghosts and a very real murderer in the House on Haunted Hill. This chill-filled production, adapted by WCT company member Robert L. Berry, combines elements of Castle's films and his frightening gimmicks. House on Haunted Hill marks Weird City Theatre's own resurrection after a three year hiatus.

Performances run October 8 - October 24, 2015 at Ground Floor Theatre, 979 Springdale Road, Austin, TX at the corner of Springdale and Airport. Performances are Thursday through Saturday nights at 8:00PM.

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise funds to help with both the costs of production and to help PAY OUR ACTORS!  We very much believe artists should be paid for their work.  The more money we can raise, the bigger and better the production becomes, and the more we can pay this awesome cast!

Directed by company member Jenni Bauer, the cast includes Mackenzy Cade as Lance Schroeder, Nene Clayton-Jones as Ruth Bridges, Saige Hilton as Mrs. Slydes, Davon Johnson as Mr. Slydes, Craig Kanne as Watson Pritchard, Kelsey Mazak as Nora Manning, Ian Prikryl as Frederick Loren, David Theis as Dr. David Trent and WCT company member Chris Romani as Annabelle Loren.

The Impact

Weird City Theatre's mission is to encourage the growth of the artist and represent the uniqueness and vitality of Austin through re-envisioned classics and original works. Keeping a child-like sense of play, we focus on the process of the actor and we are playing our part to keep Austin weird!

Weird City Theatre was started by John F. Carroll with a production of Treasure Island at the Hideout Theatre in Austin, TX.  Patti Neff-Tiven came on board in 2008 with WCT's first horror movie adaptation, Night of the Living Dead at Hyde Park Theatre.  The show was such a success that John and Patti began an ambitious production schedule for the next few years, producing classics such as Sherlock Holmes and The Rivals, and WCT became known for their Halloween shows- Nosferatu, the original piece The Servant Girl Annihilator, and another successful remount of Night of the Living Dead.  After 2012's Halloween show Grotesque & Arabesque: Poe Retold, Weird City Theatre Company decided to take a break in producing.  Now we're back and ready to celebrate our favorite holiday the way we know how!

Risks & Challenges

We want to pay our people as much as possible.  Actors in Austin don't make anywhere near a living wage plying their craft, but Weird City is committed to paying them something for their time and talents.  This production is happening- the money we raise will be used to help defray the costs of set and costumes, but mostly it goes directly to the cast and crew.  If you believe that art is important and artists should be paid for their work- this is how you can help!

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show!  Thurs - Sat. Oct. 8 - Oct. 24 at Ground Floor Theatre.  Spread the word about our campaign and about the show itself.  THURS. OCT. 15 is an "Actor's Benefit Performance"- all proceeds from ticket sales will be split among the cast and crew.  Help us sell out that performance!

story:
Help WARP get stronger.

What Writers and Actors Reading and Performing (WARP) Theatre does:

  • provide opportunities for any individuals to explore the craft of theatre.
  • help writers write and produce short works for stage.
  • help connect theatre professionals from all over Washington State.

For nearly 20 years, WARP has created a safe place for anyone to write, read, perform, and discuss theatre. We do not censor our artists and our goal is to reach out to underrepresented communities which could best benefit from the expression of theatre. Our mission is to be the most accessible theatre organization in Seattle.

What We Need & What You Get

These are our annual running costs:

  • Weekly Tuesday Night Meetings: Rent at Stone Soup Theatre is $120/mo ($1440/yr.) across the year. Because we meet at 7 - 9pm, we often like to have something eat and drink for everyone and have budgeted $25/wk ($1200/yr). 
  • Biannual Showcases: Rent at Theatre Puget Sound, Theatre 4 is generally $1300 per showcases ($2600/yr). We would like to invest $300 to offer food and merchandise in order to raise additional funds for the future. We plan to spend $100 on total printing costs (programs, promotional materials). Ideally, we would like to pay a small stipend to those who contribute talent in the showcases ($600/yr).
  • We are hoping to solidify WARP Theatre by registering as a 501c3 organization within the fiscal year. Your donations will help us cover fees and costs ($1475).  
  • WARP Theatre is fun. Sometimes we're edgy!  We're welcoming of people from all walks of life and backgrounds. We're a stepping stone for many theatre professionals new to Seattle or theatre in general - and we're about to hit our 20 year mark of service to the arts. 
  • Our priority is paying for rent. If the rent is paid for both weekly meetings and our biannual showcases, everything else is secondary.

The Impact

Your donation will:

  • Financially ensure WARP Theatre's continued survival. Help us reach our 20th year of existence!
  • Support the participatory craft of theatre at its most fundamental roots.
  • Give us a realistic budget to take this organization farther than its ever been. By achieving 501c3 status, WARP Theatre can expand on its mission, raise greater amounts of money, and reach more people than ever. 

Risks & Challenges

We depend on donations from members and friends and family to keep this organization functioning. While there are thankfully many wonderful theatre organizations in Seattle: 

  • we offer a more casual, relaxed atmosphere to explore the craft of theatre.
  • we reach out to folks who have little-to-no experience with theatre.
  • we strive to give underrepresented communities (immigrants, seniors, people of color, people with disabilities) a voice through the opportunity to have writers' works seen on stage. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • donate concessions and prizes we can use to raise more money at the showcases.
  • help volunteer as an usher, ticket taker, will call, props, helping actors change costumes, etc.  You name it!  Just let us know you're interested and we'll find something for you to help with.

Thank you for your help and your time and consideration. ♥

We would like to invest $300 to offer food and merchandise in order to raise additional funds for the future. We plan to spend $100 on total printing costs (programs, promotional materials). Ideally, we would like to pay a small stipend to those who contribute talent in the showcases ($600/yr).
We are hoping to solidify WARP Theatre by registering as a 501c3 organization within the fiscal year. Your donations will help us cover fees and costs ($1475).   WARP Theatre is fun. Sometimes we're edgy!  We're welcoming of people from all walks of life and backgrounds. We're a stepping stone for many theatre professionals new to Seattle or theatre in general - and we're about to hit our 20 year mark of service to the arts.  Our priority is paying for rent. If the rent is paid for both weekly meetings and our biannual showcases, everything else is secondary.    The Impact Your donation will:  Financially ensure WARP Theatre's continued survival. Help us reach our 20th year of existence! Support the participatory craft of theatre at its most fundamental roots. Give us a realistic budget to take this organization farther than its ever been. By achieving 501c3 status, WARP Theatre can expand on its mission, raise greater amounts of money, and reach more people than ever.     Risks & Challenges  We depend on donations from members and friends and family to keep this organization functioning. While there are thankfully many wonderful theatre organizations in Seattle:   we offer a more casual, relaxed atmosphere to explore the craft of theatre. we reach out to folks who have little-to-no experience with theatre.
we strive to give underrepresented communities (immigrants, seniors, people of color, people with disabilities) a voice through the opportunity to have writers' works seen on stage.     Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  donate concessions and prizes we can use to raise more money at the showcases. help volunteer as an usher, ticket taker, will call, props, helping actors change costumes, etc.  You name it!  Just let us know you're interested and we'll find something for you to help with.   Thank you for your help and your time and consideration. ♥

story:
Aphrodite INK

A good friend asked the age old question, “Why do you do what you do” or why start an event planning business, and honestly it’s because of the masquerade.

In undergrad, as an English major, we had to read a play called “The Rover.” If anyone has ever said that a story changed their lives, this one was the play that did it for me. Sounds cheesy or scripted but honest to God it’s true. It was the first masquerade I’ve read. It was during Carnival where people dressed in masks to hide their true identities or nobility, or gender even. People who were arranged to be married to someone else, or was arranged to be in the nunnery, prostitutes who wanted love, or people who weren’t of noble blood but wanted to marry above them, they all dressed in masks and paraded around to be someone else; the person they truly wanted to be. The idea of the masquerade is to be able to express your true self while disguising your prejudged appearance.

So I first tried to put on a masquerade ball as a fundraiser in college, It wasn’t as successful as we hoped, due to low attendance, but it was a rush knowing that I produced an entire school wide event.   

And then I fell in love with Greek mythology and the goddess Aphrodite. She was the goddess of love, passion, and procreation, and that was exactly me. I’m passionate about this craft and I want to create event for people to love.

And that’s what I strive for. I want to put on events to allow people who are nervous, shy or afraid of confessing what they are in to or want to try, and can experience an event like no other. I wanted to make events that people can call a one of a kind truly exceptional experience. Something exotic or strange or liberating, something they can dress up sexy to or seductive; something that’s not their typical norm. And what better way than a masquerade. They allow people to express their inner most desires by parading around as the wild souls they are deep down inside, or let their inner goddess out.

I loved the grand scale events that my twin sister, Kamyla, and I watched in movies or in plays. Having stage backgrounds, we loved theatre and films and I always wanted to be a part of it and producing those type of creative events that moved people. That’s how I got into creative writing and imagining these fantastic events. And this is where the INK in Aphrodite INK comes from. So that is what Aphrodite INK strives to do.

We are Aphrodite INK, LLC Event Planning and Event Services.

  • Our mission - Creating Creative Events for Creative People.

What We Need & What You Get

Our initial $5,000 funding goal  or to sell 300 tickets (pre-sell) before the date of September 1, 2015, or whichever comes first, will secure our ideal venue location that fits the theme of a masquerade ball along with securing the catering and cash bar for the night. Any following support will go towards securing the additional entertainment, DJ, photographers & videographers, etc.

The event includes:

  • Food with assorted desserts & cash bar

  • Unlimited professional photos taken at the event

Your $30 Perk includes:

  • Being considered a VIP member

  • Limited time offer t-shirt while supplies last

  • Access to the VIP lounge with bottle service

The Impact

Here's how your contribution will make a difference not only for us, but for you as well:

  • We are a new company motivated by helping people experience one of a kind events that are not your typical Friday night clubs or parties. These events are detail oriented and creative and require a lot of extensive work put into them in order for it to be successful. So the time, patience, and funds it takes to create events like this are on the grand scale.
  • Our events success will be more valuable to you, the contributor and to the world because it will show that you support a passionate business trying to make a difference in the way people enjoy their creative side. A new experience like this will allow you to step out of your comfort zone and try new things that you normally wouldn't. How many people can say they've gone to a masquerade ball for one, and without having to pay a fortune to attend.
  • If the goal is not met in time, the funds will go towards pushing back the event to a later date, rather than the estimated Halloween season. The show must go on, as they say, and we will still have this masquerade ball, just with a different theme and at a later date. So your support will still get you the opportunity to attend one of our masquerade balls.

Risks & Challenges

With any venue or event, there are deadlines to meet, and we've run into our fair share of set backs and hurdles.

  • The venue has to be confirmed with a down deposit, which is where your help and support comes in, from this campaign. We can't make anything official, including event dates, times, locations, etc. without your generous support. And that will be our biggest challenge, securing a date for this event, without having the necessary foundation to begin with.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you cannot attend, the smaller contributions are available and welcomed.
  • Ask friends and family members, neighbors, your hair dresser or whomever you know, to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use texts, email, social media, or whatever you come across to let people know about this campaign, to help support a passionate drive. And you can now use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

We greatly appreciate the support.

story:
The Blade Sign

With the community's help, The Paramount Theater is poised to rebuild and reinstall the 33-foot vertical blade sign, an iconic element of our historical façade. The return of The Blade will restore this lost piece of Charlottesville history, enliven the downtown streetscape, and fully return The Paramount to its former glory. Installation is scheduled for December 2015! When completed, the sign will be dedicated to the children of Charlottesville.

All contributions from this campaign are eligible for awesome benefits, and will be matched dollar-for-dollar by generous individual contributions.

The Blade was a brightly illuminated beacon that hung above the marquee from the Theater's construction in 1931 until it was removed in the 1960s. We are rebuilding The Blade to the exact historical specifications as the original sign, but with 2,000 upgraded energy-efficient LED Lightbulbs. The cost of the entire project, including installation, is $175,000, and we are reaching out to the the community for its support!


Let's Talk Numbers

The entire project costs $175,000. We are asking the community for $25,000 to get the project off the ground.

The Paramount has received A MATCHING CHALLENGE GRANT of $25,000 from generous individuals. Therefore, any donation received through this Indiegogo campaign will be matched dollar-for-dollar!

The remaining funds will be raised from other sources:

  • Community grants (historical and environmental)
  • Individual donors
  • Selling "Bring Back the Blade" buttons throughout the Charlottesville area

The $175,000 price tag will cover the cost of the entire project, including planning, fabrication, engineering (to ensure the 1930s building can handle the weight of the new sign), and installation. The cost also includes purchasing the 2,000 new LED light bulbs that will illuminate The Blade!

    A Beacon for the Community

    Following its Thanksgiving Eve 1931 opening, Charlottesville's Paramount Theater became a landmark overnight. One of Charlottesville’s premiere destinations, The Paramount made movie-going a special experience. Audiences numbering in the thousands each week would come as much to escape into opulent surroundings as to watch a show. For four decades, the grand movie palace hosted hundreds of films, war bond drives, fashion shows, cartoons for kids, and popular rock-and-roll concerts, entertaining multiple generations of area families. 

    The Paramount remained Charlottesville’s crown jewel until closing its doors for good in 1974, as businesses and shoppers began to move away from the downtown area. Even as the lights dimmed on the marquee, the theater was not forgotten: almost from the moment it closed, efforts were launched to save the theater from real and constant threats of demolition. In 1992, the non-profit Paramount Theater, Inc. purchased the building and spent the next 12 years raising the funds necessary to complete not only the meticulous restoration of the theater, but also the creation of new facilities enabling The Paramount to step into its new role as a regional performing arts center. 


    The Paramount Theater opened its doors to the public once more in December 2004 – more than thirty years after it had closed. The re-opening of the Theater marked a resurgence in downtown traffic and served as a springboard for bringing businesses back to the downtown area with the Theater as its anchor. Now, ten years later, the Downtown Mall is again a vital part of our city. The Theater is an iconic destination on the Downtown Mall, a showcase for the performing arts, and a gathering place for Charlottesville and the region.

    While The Paramount is a home to the performing arts, it also is a home to the community. The project to restore The Paramount has been one of the largest community efforts in our history. The reconstruction of the blade sign, the final remaining element to be restored, will complete The Paramount Theater - a fitting tribute to its 10th Anniversary - and preserve the Theater’s history for years to come. It's time to help us Bring Back The Blade!

    Risks & Challenges

    The Paramount has been working to reinstall The Blade Sign since the 1990's, when a group of ambitious community members undertook the massive fundraising and renovation project. However, as the construction progressed, the funds were needed elsewhere and The Blade Sign was scrapped as plans were scaled back. We are finally ready to do it! After years of careful planning, now is the time. We have already overcome the most significant challenges:

    1. Receiving approval from engineers and architects who have verified that the Theater's historic façade can hold the weight of the new sign.
    2. Receiving approval from the City of Charlottesville's Board of Architectural Review and the Virginia Department of Historic Resources. We are grateful for their ongoing support.

    Other Ways You Can Help!

    Please help spread the word about The Blade to everyone in our community. This is truly a community effort that will impact the downtown area and far beyond.
    • Share this page on social media and encourage your friends to support the project.
    • Purchase a "Bring Back the Blade" button (available at The Paramount box office and many area retailers and restaurants) and wear it proudly.
    • Come celebrate the Illumination of the new sign on December 15!
    Historic photos by Ed Roseberry / C'ville Images

Other Ways You Can Help!

Purchase a "Bring Back the Blade" button (available at The Paramount box office and many area retailers and restaurants) and wear it proudly.
Come celebrate the Illumination of the new sign on December 15!

story:
My name is Bisakha Goswami and I am teaching musicology at Rabindra Bharati University in Calcutta. I have been conducting research on female musicians in West Bengal previously and would like to visit London for two months to do archival research at the British Library about the anti-nautch campaigns that targeted female dancers and musicians of colonial India around 1900.

I would like to analyse how public opinion about female performers was shaped in colonial India in the time period from 1880 to 1920. During this time, colonial authorities branded devadasis, nautch girls, baijis and other professional female dancers as prostitutes and thereby contributed to the marginalisation of female performers in Indian society. The views of the authorities were contested as over-simplified by Indian artists and intellectuals, but publications like the newspaper ‘The Englishman’ and the ‘Indian Gazette’ propagated the official standpoint and thereby influenced public opinion significantly. At the British Library, complete yearly collections of relevant publications like these two are available, as well as personal diaries of British government officials employed in India around the turn of the 19th century. The views propagated by the colonial authorities continue to reverberate in public opinion in India until the present day. I would like to examine the ways in which public opinion was influenced in colonial India in those days.

Gender-related researches in the field of fine arts are generally not encouraged in India. But researches in this field are very essential for the improvement of gender equality in India.

Since my early student days, it has always been my deep wish to pursue a course of higher education in Europe. Although I have had several offers to do so, the high  fees made it impossible for me to study abroad so far. For this research project, I have established contact with academic staff of the School of Oriental and African Studies in London, who would be willing to guide me. Unfortunately, the funding poses a huge problem for me. Currently, I am working as assistant professor in India and my monthly salary is about 40000 Indian Rupees or 400 £ per month, which is not enough to save money for a visit to the United Kingdom. I also have some family members in India who are financially dependent on me.

I am taking this approach via crowdfunding to reach out to you for your support in the funding of the project. Please help me and make my dream of a research visit to the School of Oriental and African Studies come true.

Bisakha
